(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criteria for entry to such courses. (iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22 per cent of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threaten Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.

PETITION.TITLE: Deregulation of Trading Hours: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia be lifted.

3. Past performances have proved that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the notices of intention to withdraw which I gave yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, when giving notice of disallowance of the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations (Amendment) on 13 October 1981, I indicated to the Senate that notice had been given in order to preserve the Committee's rights while continuing its consultations with the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). The Committee had been concerned to have a right of review of decisions of the Director of National Parks and Wildlife inserted in the Regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to be able to report that the Minister has agreed to the Committee's proposal that an amendment to the National Parks and Wildlife Regulations be made providing for the right of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions by the Director, where appropriate. In the light of the Minister's undertaking, and in accordance with notice of intention given yesterday, I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 for the next day of sitting, standing in my name.

Mr President, when giving notice of motion, on 27 October 1981, to disallow the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Regulations, I indicated that, while the Committee was satisfied that the Regulations accorded with the legislation under which they were made, the Committee was pursuing with the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) the matter of notification of rights to persons who may be eligible for services without charge as hospital patients.

After review and consideration, the Minister has advised that practical, and possibly legal, difficulties stand in the way of adopting the Committee's suggestion. The Committee accepts that the difficulties perceived by the Minister may preclude adoption in the Regulations of a notification procedure, and on that basis I now withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 2 for the next day of sitting, in accordance with the notice of intention given yesterday. I inform the Senate that the Committee has drawn to the Minister's attention the inadequacy in this regard of the agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, to which the parent legislation has given effect.

(d) expresses concern that by its tinkering with the Land Commission the Tonkin Liberal Government has paved the way for an escalation in prices of building blocks in South Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I think he has had some notice of this question. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a circular dated 10 January 1979 by Mr K. R. Constantine, the Chief Veterinary Officer of the Department of Primary Industry in New South Wales? Did that circular warn meat inspectors about corrupt practices in the export trade? Did these alleged practices include the substitution of horse and kangaroo meat for beef? Can the Minister say whether the director of meat inspection, Mr Gee, knew of the allegations and whether he in turn informed the Minister for Primary Industry at the time, Mr Sinclair? If Mr Sinclair was informed, what action did he take to see that these practices were stamped out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Leader of the Opposition indicated, I had some notice that he intended to ask a question concerning this area. I am pleased about that, because I did not hear AM this morning and would not have been aware of the statements made by Mr Hallam on that program. I have now had the opportunity to see a transcript of what was said and to obtain some information from the Minister for Primary Industry. Because of that, I am now aware of the circular to which the honourable senator has referred. I have a copy of it with me. If it were wished, I could table that copy in the Senate for the information of honourable senators. The circular did not warn meat inspectors about corrupt practices in the export trade, unless, I think, one takes a fairly broad definition of the word 'corrupt'. In its terms, it reminded meat inspection staff of the need to check product description on all meat export packs.

ANSWER.PARA: The circular was issued to Department of Primary Industry officers in all States, to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and to industry organisations. This was following some complaints that had been received by the Bureau of Animal Health in Canberra about the removal of cuts from some packs; the substitution of mutton for lamb, young sheep for hogget and cow for heifer; and some incorrect trade descriptions of skirt and salt beef. There was no suggestion, however, as was raised in the question, of any species substitution such as horse meat or kangaroo meat being substituted for beef. The Central Office advice was carried out within the normal administrative processes of the Veterinary Public Health Branch of the Bureau of Animal Health. The Director of the Bureau of Animal Health, Mr Gee, was not informed of the circular, which was a routine reminder to all inspection staff of their responsibilities. I am advised that the then Minister would also not have been advised of the circular.

The matter was raised on AM this morning by the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture, Mr Hallam, who has taken this issue out of context and has been blatantly dishonest in his approach to it. Indeed, he and the Leader of the Opposition seem to be more intent on trying to destroy the credibility of Australia's export meat trade than trying to support it and to rebuild its reputation following the recent unfortunate horse and kangaroo meat substitution issue. Notwithstanding the excitement on the Opposition benches, I would have thought we would all be united in our wish to have effective meat inspection services and also united in our wish to have a healthy meat export industry, which is important not only to supporters of the Government but also to the tiny proportion of people who support the Opposition.

Mr Hallam claimed on AM this morning that the circular demonstrates that the federal meat inspection service was not up to scratch whereas, in fact, the circular demonstrates that it was the opposite. It was issued following complaints and it was issued to remind inspection officers of their responsibilities. It pointed out quite clearly that correct trade descriptions and common codes must be applied at all times for all destinations, and also pointed out that failure to do so undermines the credibility of the inspection service and reflects adversely on the Australian meat industry. I think the attempts on AM this morning to continue the concern about the industry were most inappropriate in the light of the measures which have been taken to ensure that procedures are satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.
—I table the statement. I am quite happy to table the information from which I have quoted.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who represents the Minister for Health in this chamber. I refer to health insurance arrangements for remote Aboriginal communities, a matter which was raised with me by the Pitjantjatjara communities in South Australia whom I visited last week on the Minister's behalf. In the past, persons who live in remote Aboriginal communities have not needed to make any special arrangements for health insurance because they have had free access to local community health clinics and to public hospitals in the nearer, major population centres. Under the new health insurance arrangements, persons in remote Aboriginal communities have now to write out applications either for health insurance cover, if their income exceeds the cut-in of the means test for publicly provided insurance, or for the publicly provided insurance. There are two special difficulties in remote Aboriginal communities. Firstly, many adults are not literate. Secondly--

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I suggest that the honourable senator, in his endeavour to highlight the situation, is, in fact, giving information to the Senate contrary to previous rulings by you and your predecessors and is not asking his question.

—I have been listening closely. The honourable senator is framing his question. Again, I ask honourable senators to make an earnest endeavour to keep their questions as short as they possibly can. The shorter the question the more questions can be asked in this place. I call Senator Teague.

—Secondly, seasonal work may lead to very large variations of income. Will the Minister give consideration to administrative arrangements that will sensibly assist all persons in remote Aboriginal communities being ordinarily covered for health insurance? Can consideration also be given to some form of blanket cover being specially arranged for the members of these communities, perhaps on an annual basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt that the Government is likely to change the basis of the health arrangements, but that does not mean that we are not sensitive to the problems which have been raised by Senator Teague. I note that he was in the Pitjantjatjara area last week for the handing over of the title deeds. I remind the Senate that that was an historic event. The questions which he raises and which relate to people in some of the remote communities are real questions. It is true that many of the people are not literate and that someone is required to fill in forms for them. It is fair to say, however, that most of the Aboriginal people in those areas have an income sufficiently low that they would qualify without any doubt for the health insurance cover scheme which the Government has announced for low income earners. If they do qualify they qualify for six months. The honourable senator will be aware of that. I believe he may be correct in saying that there will be an extra load on some of the community advisers in terms of the paper work required. We will certainly try to investigate that aspect.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator referred to variations which might occur in people's income. The arrangements provide that people can earn up to 125 per cent of the qualifying level in any four-week period before they lose their entitlement. But again, there could be some extra administrative work for those people who have a fluctuating income. The matter really is one which affects my colleagues the Minister for Health and the Minister for Social Security. I will undertake to make Senator Teague's concerns known to them and to see whether we can look at the arrangements.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I preface it by referring to the mission impossible that the Department inherited in the imposition by the Public Service Board of an unreal staff ceiling under which, in the last couple of years, the Department has had to process at least 9,000 applications made during the mini-amnesty, a work load that led to a nine months' backlog in processing citizenship applications-at least in Sydney, if not in Melbourne-and has had to cope with the revised criteria on migrant selections. It is in that context that I ask the Minister: What hopes have we that the Public Service Board Luddites will finally agree to a much needed infusion of additional staff into that Department? As a postscript-I am trying to be helpful and base this suggestion on observations I have made in Sydney-I ask whether it would be possible to utilise the manpower of some of the surplus clerks in the Public Service Board who are located on the eighteenth floor by transferring them to the eleventh floor where the work is.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am glad that the close relationship Senator Mulvihill has with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is not impaired by the honourable senator's question; I see that he is still seeking assistance for that Department. At present the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is analysing its staffing. For instance, the recent changes in the migrant selection policy are being reviewed with a view to taking the matter up with the Public Service Board to ensure that the necessary resources are available to enable the kind of service that is expected from a department of that type to be given. The review of citizenship procedures is also being undertaken in co-operation with the Public Service Board. It is hoped that that review will be completed by the end of this month. ANSWER.PARA: I have noted what was said in the latter part of the question with regard to the transfer of staff which, in Senator Mulvihill's mind, might not be as adequately employed as some staff members in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I will draw the attention of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the question and will see that the urgency of the matter raised by Senator Mulvihill is given the Minister's attention to ensure that, as soon as possible, adequate staff is provided in that Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I do so more in sorrow than in anger, as the Minister will appreciate. In the processing of citizenship applications the number of Australian Federal Police officers used was the responsibility of the Minister for Administrative Services. I know that the Minister for Finance will take on board what I have to say. I asked a question relating to this matter earlier when we were considering the Supplementary Estimates and so far Mr Newman's people have not given me an answer. I sympathise with the Minister for Finance and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on the evasiveness of the Minister for Administrative Services.
—Does the Minister wish to respond?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I respond only to note the additional request of Senator Mulvihill with regard to the Department of Administrative Services. I will see whether we can get an early answer to that.
—My question is directed to Senator Chaney as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, or possibly in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce.
—Make up your mind.

—The Minister may answer in either capacity. Is the Minister aware of the advertisement released a few weeks ago by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia in combination with General Motors-Holden's Ltd? Did the advertisement advocate an indefinite continuation of broadly the present level of tariffs, quotas and content protection for the motor vehicle industry? Is the average cost to the consumer of the present level of protection $3,000 per car? Is the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation now demanding both a $30 a week pay rise and a 35-hour week? What would be the additional cost to the consumer per car if these demands were met? How does the behaviour of these workers compare with that of overseas workers employed by companies such as Chrysler and even British Leyland who showed pay restraint when their companies were in difficulties? Is it apparently assumed by the VBEF that the Government should protect its members' jobs through tariffs and quotas regardless of their pay demands? Will these facts be taken into account when the Government reconsiders its policy for the protection of the motor vehicle industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is basic to the honourable senator's question that it is not merely the decisions of government which affect the shape of industry in this country. Quite clearly, the attitudes which are taken by trade unions, like the decisions which are taken by government with respect to measures such as taxation and protection, do have an effect on the shape of manufacturing industry in Australia. The question raised by the honourable senator specifically referred to an advertisement which was inserted by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation in combination with General Motors-Holden's Ltd. I am aware of that advertisement. I think it would be fair to say that it opposed the adoption of the proposals contained in the draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission. General Motors-Holden's and the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation gave evidence to the IAC and both advocated change to the existing assistance arrangements, although both support the retention of some form of content plan and some form of market sharing.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose the feature of this area is that all the interested parties, whether they are trade unions or those who are involved as employers and manufacturers, do have a great diversity of stance. The only common point seems to be that they all want some change, but the fact is that they all seem to seek varied changes. In broad terms, the IAC has estimated that the consumer tax equivalent of the current assistance arrangements is about $1,000m per annum. Using that figure it would be possible to derive a notional estimate for the assistance provided per car produced, but I am not sure that either figure of itself has any particular significance. The figures are influenced as much by the size of the industry as by the assistance received and involve a lot of assumptions, including difficult judgments about the likely price of cars in a theoretical free trade situation. Again, some very differing views are being put forward, both publicly and privately, on that point at the moment.

If the honourable senator wishes to draw a comparison between the assistance accorded to this industry and that provided to other areas of manufacturing, I would refer him to the IAC's specific comments on this. The Commission has estimated that the assistance accorded to the industry is about four times the average for the manufacturing sector overall. As far as the industrial claims mentioned by the honourable senator are concerned, my understanding is that the union did submit a log of claims earlier this year seeking both a $30 a week wage rise and the introduction of a 35-hour working week. The subsequent history of those claims is complex but I understand that the present position, in essence, is that the claim for a 35-hour working week has been absorbed in the general Australian Council of Trade Unions program on this issue and is no longer being pursued separately by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, and that the wage claim has been before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but that the Commission's award of $9 a week for non-tradesmen and $14 a week for tradesmen has been rejected by some members of the union. The dispute at Ford's Broadmeadows plant flowed from that.

I cannot quantify the cost per car if the demands were met and they were fully passed on in terms of car prices. As to the influence which these issues may have on the outcome of the current review of assistance arrangements, I can only repeat the advice previously given, that in reaching its decisions on future assistance arrangements for the industry the Government will be guided by what it considers will best serve the overall national interest. There have been a number of questions from both sides of the House. In response to all of them I have been at some pains to emphasise that the Government will very carefully consider the employment and other considerations which obviously are very significant in this whole area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns a statement attributed to the Treasurer today that the Government will not grant tax cuts or increase family allowances if the Australian Democrats allow legislation for higher petrol prices to pass through the Senate. I ask: Was not the Government elected on a clear and unqualified promise by the Prime Minister during the last Federal election campaign that any future revenue from higher petrol prices due to the crude oil levy would be passed back to the Australian people as tax cuts or higher family allowances? Is not the circumstance that the Government might be getting less revenue than it expected totally irrelevant to this issue since the Prime Minister's election promise was not qualified? The Democrats, and no doubt the Australian people, would like a straight answer on whether this breaking of an election promise is a considered change of policy to apply not only to the petrol price rise projected from 1 January but also to all such future rises based on world parity pricing arrangements.

—I did not hear the Treasurer's statement except that part in which he stated, as I said yesterday, that the present trend of production of oil from Bass Strait, owing to the interruption by industrial unrest, would result in a shortfall of about $220m overall this year compared with the Budget estimate and that, even allowing for an adjustment on 1 January, there would be a shortfall of about $120m. In fact the revenue will be less and not more. I do not believe that the Government has broken any promises in this regard. I repeat that the Government has placed great emphasis upon the development of the family. In this Budget there is emphasis upon the family and there will be for the future. I repeat what I said yesterday, that the thrust of our overall Budget and monetary policy is to do the most significant thing possible for all families, that is, to get inflation down and to bear down on interest rates. No better help than this could be given to the Australian family. Indeed, over the past six years the inflation rate, which six years ago was running at 17 1/2 per cent and moving higher, has fallen. The inflation rate during past governments in Australia was numbered amongst the highest in the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Australia now has one of the lowest inflation rates. Whereas six or seven years ago its ability to trade was being shrunk out of the world, we are now widening and improving our trading ability better than we have done in 10 years. The picture is a good one. Since I have not seen the full text of the Treasurer's statement I am unable to comment on the remainder of the question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am surprised that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is not aware of the Treasurer's statement, which was broadcast today as considered Government policy. However, do we take it from Senator Carrick's view that the Government has not yet made up its mind whether this proposed breaking of an election promise will become its permanent and considered policy?

—That is such a convoluted supplementary question that it requires no answer. I make it clear that I have not seen or heard the Treasurer's statement, except an extract with regard to the shortfall of money. As to the Government's policies with regard to taxation reduction or family benefits, they, being policy matters, will be announced in due course. They are not matters for response at Question Time, as the honourable senator should know.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it true that coal liquefaction projects have received funding in the sum of $8.1m between the years 1978-79 and 1980-81 on the recommendation of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council? Is it also true that funding for coal gasification has been less than 5 per cent of that sum? In view of the expiry of the gas contract to South Australia in 1987, and in view of the fact that reports of the South Australian Department of Mines and Energy put the cost of gas produced at the Wakefield coal deposit at no higher than the cost of Bass Strait natural gas as appears in the NERDDC funded Davy McKee Paper, what is the justification for such apparent discrimination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no discrimination. On the contrary, the Commonwealth Government has been busy talking to the States to try to get some agreement that the linking of the Wagga Wagga and Albury pipelines would allow for the future a real assurance of additional gas supply to South Australia in the event of any other non-negotiability of contract after 1987. A very great deal of work has been done in that regard and in other matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me respond to the four parts of the question. It is true that $8.1m has been allocated for research into coal liquefaction in recent years and that coal gasification research has been in the order of $0.34m over that period. The allocations, which are recommended to me by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council and are set out in its booklet, are based on the criteria of the priorities in this regard. The Council identifies a need to support sufficient activity in the coal liquefaction area to enable a proper assessment of the process routes for conversion of Australian coals to liquid fuels. Coal gasification is considered important not only for the production of synthetic natural gas but also for the generation of hydrogen or synthesis gas for liquefaction processes. However-and this is the important point-coal gasification processes are already available, have been commercially applied and are viable.

The study called the Davy McKee study on market and production aspects of the use of methanol as a gasolene extender assumed a notional natural gas cost of $3.90 a gigajoule. In addition to investigating the production of gas from coal of course it would be appropriate for the South Australian authorities to pursue commercial negotiations for gas contracts beyond 1987. The development of exploration for gas and liquids in the Cooper Basin has shown a healthy sign. The proposed linking of the pipeline from Wagga to Albury is another significant assurance for the future. The Commonwealth is in continuous discussion with South Australia. I believe it should be readily possible for South Australia to have an ensured gas supply for the indefinite future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services of the numerous questions I have asked about the variability in electorates in Australia and the need for the Minister to make some statement about such changes that are apparent. I therefore ask: Is the Minister aware that the time for the notification by the Chief Australian Electoral Officer of the figures relating to the number of seats in the House of Representatives for each of the States expires on 24 November? Has the Minister already received such notification from the Chief Australian Electoral Officer? Will the Minister give an assurance to the Senate that honourable senators will be informed of the result before the Senate rises?

—The advice to which Senator Gietzelt refers is between the Chief Australian Electoral Officer and the Minister whom I represent. Therefore, information as to whether notification has been given is something that I will have to obtain from the Minister. I understand Senator Gietzelt's concern that there may be an expiry date of 24 November. I will take that up immediately with my colleague and attempt to come back to the honourable senator as soon as I can.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment inform the Senate of the outcome of a meeting at lunchtime today aimed at settling the strike by the Australian Ballet, which strike is now in its twentieth day? What is the Government's attitude to the situation of Australian taxpayers subsidising a grant of $1.6m to the Ballet in this year's Budget alone which is enabling the company to remain on strike? Has the Government considered withdrawing the grant?

—Senator Walters is quite correct to be concerned about the Australian Ballet which is one of our great cultural assets. I am one of the subscribers who has been affected by the cancellation of the season in Sydney. I am informed by my colleagues that the season in Brisbane has also been cancelled. It may come as no surprise to the honourable senator that I am not aware of the outcome of a meeting held at lunch time today. In fact it may come as no surprise to the honourable senator that I was unaware that there was a meeting being held at lunch time today. But anything that can be done to settle this dispute between the Australian Ballet and its management would be endorsed by everyone. I will find out from the Minister whom I represent whether there is a result and make that information known to the honourable senator.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not answer the last part of my question, which was: Has the Government considered withdrawing the grant?

—I recall that Senator Hamer, who is not here at present, has very definite views about the Budget strategy by which the Government ensured that the Australian Ballet had a specific Budget item allocated to it. So to that extent the Government is endorsing the allocation to the Australian Ballet. The honourable senator is perhaps now suggesting that current events make that a matter which may require reassessment. That is something which I will also put to the Minister whom I represent.

—The Leader of the Government in the Senate will no doubt be aware that today is the sixth anniversary of the sacking of a democratically elected government. The Minister will also be aware that for almost the whole of that time the former Governor-General, John Kerr, has been banished from Australia by his Government. Can the Minister now inform the Parliament what the total cost has been to the Australian taxpayer, excluding the period when the Governor-General's salary was paid, for the political agistment of the former Governor-General? Will the Minister include in the totals such important items as travel expenses, pension arrangements, office and secretarial costs, both in London and elsewhere, expenses relating to international and domestic phone calls and entertainment expenses, including living away from home allowances which may be paid to him by the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that six years ago today a democratic process, fully constitutional, was undertaken as a result of which the electors of Australia overwhelmingly endorsed that constitutional process, threw out the former government and put in a Federal Liberal government, and twice subsequently has done the same. I am equally aware that a Governor-General appointed by the Whitlam Labor Government and acknowledged by that Government many times as being a very distinguished Australian, a very great Australian lawyer and a very great student of constitutional law-a man whom the Whitlam Labor Government praised-acted constitutionally to bring about the result six years ago. It is a most extraordinary thing that the Australian Labor Party, which appointed and praised this great Australian, should now turn and snarl at him because he did not do its bidding. That ought to be put in context, because it does no Australian any good at all to denigrate somebody who acted within the Constitution and within his service to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, there is a request as to the costs. My understanding is that the costs of maintaining that particular Governor-General, Sir John Kerr, are comparable to those for all previous Governors-General. If there are any different matters which require comment, I will seek them out. I will see whether there is any additional comment. I repeat that Sir John Kerr, acknowledged by both sides of this House as a very distinguished Australian and a great Australian jurist, did his job. It was in fact the Opposition of the time, the present Government, that took the steps at that time which enabled the people of Australia to vote to throw out the Whitlam Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I am sorry that the Minister has avoided replying to the question that I asked. I repeat the words. I said 'excluding the period that the Governor-General's salary was paid'. I wanted to know what the total cost was to the Australian taxpayer for the political agistment of the former Governor-General. I asked to be included in the total: Travel expenses outside this country, pension arrangements, office and secretarial costs for services which the Government maintains for him in London and in other places, the costs of his international and domestic telephone calls-which have been a cause of much comment in this chamber on many occasions by a number of my colleagues, as the Minister would know-what living away from home allowance is paid, and any other payments that may have been made to him by the Australian Government, not during his term of office as Governor-General but while the Government has had him on political agistment.

—The phrase 'political agistment' is a form of invective used by an Australian Labor Party which lost its toffee apple, and that is the simple situation. I repeat that the Labor Party appointed a great Australian and acknowledged at his appointment and throughout the whole of his journey as Governor-General, until 11 November 1975, how eminently suitable he was to be Governor-General, how highly qualified he was in law, and in all such matters what a great constitutional lawyer he was. It praised him until he made a decision which went against its self-interests. Now it turns invective upon him and snarls at him. I reject the phrase 'political agistment'. I repeat what I said: Sir John Kerr is and was a great Australian who did his duty as he saw it and understood it. He is today a retired Governor-General. If there are any additional costs that require comment, I will seek them out.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, relates to the Zeidler Committee of Inquiry into Electricity Generating and the Sharing of Power Resources in South-east Australia. As the Zeidler report states that there is no economic case that can be established at this stage for developing an interconnection of the electricity supplies of Victoria and Tasmania, what alternatives does the Minister see Tasmania having for future power generation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Zeidler Committee has released its report and it is true that at this stage the Committee does not see it as economic to make a cable link under Bass Strait. It does not see a highly integrated grid on the mainland as being economic at this moment, but it does see some benefit in the study of a lesser concept of a link between Victoria and South Australia. The supply of electricity to Tasmania, the nature of that supply, how far the State extends its hydro-electricity or how far it extends alternatives, must be primarily determined by the State Government concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: There are, of course, known coal deposits in Tasmania. Some of them are not of high quality. I am not aware of the extent to which they have been investigated or developed and I am not aware of how far the State Government has considered the alternatives of coal power. At this moment there is no known natural gas deposit for generation. It may well be that in the existing development and exploration of Bass Strait an alternative source of energy will turn up. I understand that today the Tasmanian Government, like the Irish, has its troubles. The question of how the Tasmanian people will get their electric power supply has been judged by the people and the Parliament as being one of utter bungling and confusion. It is time the Government went back to the drawing board and came to an effective conclusion so that an island which has many great assets can also have effective electric power.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is he aware of Northern Territory Public Service General Order 11H which concerns public comment by public servants and which has excited a good deal of controversy in the Territory since it was introduced last July, not least because public servants, I understand, constitute some 40 per cent of the Territory's working population? Does the Minister accept that these provisions are quite out of line with the provisions relating to public comment by Commonwealth public servants to the extent that they virtually outlaw any public comment on politically controversial issues-whether within the public servant's own field of employment or not-fail to endorse a public servant's right to take part in political activities and explicitly bar criticism when it reflects on the Northern Territory Public Service? What is the Government's attitude towards these kinds of provisions, particularly given the fact that Northern Territory public servants were compulsorily transferred to the Territory from the Commonwealth on the promise of a full transfer of rights? Does the Government regard these provisions as a good advertisement for the Northern Territory's commitment to democratic principles if and when it achieves full independence politically, and ultimate statehood? If not, will the Prime Minister bring to bear some pressure on the Northern Territory Government to bring its General Order back into line with the present Commonwealth law?

—I am not aware of General Order 11H to which Senator Evans has referred. It presumably is an order made by the self-governing Government of the Northern Territory. I would need to look at it and to study it to determine whether there is any validity in the remainder of Senator Evans's comment. He has asserted that it has some harsh characteristics. I am unable to comment on them because I have not seen them. He has not previously drawn my attention to them.
—Senator Robertson has.
—Yes, I have, months ago.
—There was an interjection: 'Yes, I have, months ago'.
—I raised it with you formally 18 months ago and you said you would look into it, as you are saying now-exactly the same words.
—If Senator Robertson did, and if he will draw my attention to it I will follow it up.
—That is what you said before.

—I have no such recollection at all, but if he will be kind enough to do so I will follow it up. I will have a look at the matter. I also invite Senator Robertson to give me the chapter and verse of his previous request and I will put it under study. If the Government feels that comment is necessary, that will be forthcoming.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. I refer to the financial support provided in previous years, limited though it might have been, by the Commonwealth for the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. I ask: Does the Government intend to keep contributing towards this scheme in partnership with the Queensland Government so as to enable the next planned and badly needed extension to bring another 1,131 hectares under irrigation in the Bingera area?

—The Bundaberg irrigation scheme has been financed as part of the national water resources program of the Government in recent years. It has a substantial allocation of funds in the current year's Budget. The matter is, of course, reviewed year by year and it is also reviewed on the basis of the priorities given to it by the Queensland Government. Fundamentally, the national water resources program is based upon a matching dollar principle. From memory, this year the amount is something in the order of $4.5m. That is only a figure from memory. Next year the Government will seek similar inquiries from the Queensland Government. We have indicated our interest in that irrigation scheme and our interest to see that the stages now under construction should be completed. I will look at it further to see whether there is any additional information that the honourable senator might feel necessary.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. By way of introduction I remind the Minister that on 9 September I asked him a question relating to the suspension of the export operations of all independent boning rooms in Victoria and the consequent stand-down of some 2,500 employees, and I sought compensation for the loss of wages by these people. On 24 September I asked the Minister a question relating to the reported discovery of horse meat from Steigers Meat Supply Pty Ltd of Northcote. I now ask: Is it a fact that around 100 employees of that firm have been laid off for over six weeks? Has the company refused certain compensation and other payments to these employees, only a handful of whom have obtained alternative employment? Is the company or some part of it still actively trading in meat? Will the Government take steps to ensure that the company carries out its obligations to pay fully its employees and again consider the question of compensation to the innocent victims of alleged malpractice in the meat industry?

—Senator Primmer indicated that he has asked me a couple of questions in this area. I have given him partial responses in the chamber and rather more lengthy written responses. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It relates to the seagoing watchkeeping experience of our naval officers. At a recent symposium on sea transport technology, the Chief of Naval Materiel, Rear-Admiral Rourke, is reported to have said that the Royal Australian Navy had problems providing adequate sea time for junior and more advanced officers and would welcome approaches from shipping companies willing to take naval officers to sea on their ships. Is this so? Can the Minister tell us why this is so? What steps are being taken to ensure that naval officers obtain sufficient practical experience to retain their competence to command our ships?

—It is a fact that, at a symposium on sea transport technology, Rear-Admiral Rourke was questioned as to the past arrangements to allow naval officers to go to sea in merchant ships to broaden the experience of their operations. He was asked whether he thought these arrangements should be reintroduced. My understanding is that the Royal Australian Navy is currently planning to attach junior officers to merchant ships to further their training, to broaden their experience and to promote good will between the RAN and the merchant service. Commanding officer designates of specific fleet units are currently planned to sea ride in merchant ships to gain further experience. In addition, merchant shipping involvement in naval exercises is increasing all the time. Arrangements to form an Australian shipping defence council are currently well advanced with the aim of developing a better liaison between the RAN and the shipping companies and to promote greater co-operation between the two in both peacetime and wartime.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Firstly, how much will the proposed amalgamations of tertiary institutions recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions cost? In particular, what sums will have to be paid because of the amalgamating or closing of colleges to staff who have entitlements to severance pay, accrued annual leave, accrued sick pay and, where their determinations include this, any accrued long service leave? Secondly, why was an eight-month deadline set when the Tertiary Education Commission and the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission suggested three years as appropriate and overseas experience shows that such amalgamations can take five years to accomplish satisfactorily? Thirdly, how will access to tertiary education and the quality of education be improved since the evidence points to the reverse? Fourthly, why was there virtually no consultation carried out with the colleges, their councils, staffs and students, all of whom have suffered by these proposed amalgamations? Finally, when can I expect an answer to an earlier question on guidelines for amalgamating institutes which I asked on 10 September in this place? Is it the case that no such guidelines exist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original recommendation for amalgamation of colleges and universities arose from the Tertiary Education Commission and was taken up by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions. It is important to realise that the Tertiary Education Commission is an objective body of education specialists headed by a very distinguished Australian, Professor Karmel. The Commission and its concomitant councils are to be in daily contact and consultation with the institutions concerned and, therefore, are required to have very specialist knowledge. Senator Siddons, therefore, must keep in mind that, in the days when the demographic population trends in Australia were such that our youngsters were expanding in numbers and primary and secondary education was expanding, there was a burgeoning of teacher training colleges. There was also the development of single purpose teacher training colleges in Australia. The Tertiary Education Commission and other educationists believed that these single purpose colleges in themselves were wrong in concept and that they ought to be multi-purpose. Indeed, the demographic trend was such that they could not be viable on their own and, therefore, amalgamation was necessary. All those things are basically sensible conclusions. In the view of expert educationists they are to the benefit of education.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked some questions relating to costs. I do not have that figure at my fingertips. I was asked also about the eight months deadline. I will seek information on those matters. I will look into the final matter relating to the question that was asked on 10 September. If no answer has been forthcoming I will seek its expedition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction to the latest figures on building society housing loans which show that lending for housing in September was 38 per cent lower than it was 12 months ago. Is this not clear evidence that the Fraser Government's economic policies are denying thousands of Australians the chance to own their own homes? Is the Minister aware that housing approvals are now at their lowest level for two years? When can we expect to see an end to this Government's repressive economic policies which are obviously causing hardship for thousands of Australians? What specifically does the Minister propose to do to assist prospective home buyers in this depressing economic climate?

—Senator Foreman would know that the situation in the housing industry is complicated by a number of factors, not just those to which he referred. The detailed questions which he has outlined really require detailed information which I do not have available at the moment. I undertake to seek that information for him from the Minister for Housing and Construction. As to the last matter that he mentioned with regard to housing policy, it is clear that the Government's housing policy is to encourage people to own their own homes to the highest extent possible. It is true that 71 per cent of the Australian population own their own homes. That is very much in line with experience over the last few years. In fact, this trend has continued. I will refer to the Minister the remarks which Senator Foreman has made, and make sure that I get an early reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to an article in the Sunday Mail of 8 November which quoted the Premier of Queensland, the Honourable Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, as having said:

QUESTION.PARA: 'You'll have to send all your troops, Air Force and Navy to stop us getting an offshore strip along the Barrier Reef'.
'Their armed forces or court orders won't stop us', he said.

Has the Minister read this article? If so, does he agree that such statements not only are inflammatory, intemperate and imprudent but also smack of anarchy and political opportunism? Is the Government going to proceed with its stated intention of declaring the whole of the Barrier Reef a marine park, or will it once again bow to the idiosyncratic demands of the Queensland Premier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not--
—Come on!

—I would be very happy to answer this question because we have a very proud record indeed. I did not have the opportunity of reading the Border Morning Mail of that day, either in black and white or in the technicolour in which Senator Bonner has described so I cannot respond to the questions about it. But as to the question whether the Government is to proceed, I say emphatically that the Government intends to proceed on the course it has defined. Let me make that clear. So that there is no confusion let me say a few things. The problem of defining the Barrier Reef and declaring it a national park is no simple matter; it is a highly complex one. The Government has made a categoric and absolute guarantee of protection of the reef. I have spoken on many occasions of the permanent preservation of the reef.

ANSWER.PARA: There is much confusion in many minds over the Great Barrier Reef and its region. There is a general tendency to make no distinction between the two. The reef is drawn in the broadest possible way to ensure that none of the widely scattered reef is excluded. The Great Barrier Reef consists, in fact, of over 2,500 reefs and islands spread over almost 2,000 kilometres with, in many places, large areas of open water between important areas. The definition of the reef and the identification of the ecologically vital areas are work which is complex, detailed and still proceeding. It is unreal, in administrative terms, to talk glibly of proclaiming the whole region. The preparation of zoning plans to allow for protection of the reef, shipping lanes, existing and essential professional fishing, amateur fishing and tourist activity necessarily involves much detailed work. This Government has done more to protect the reef than has any other government. Its actions have been in accordance with the findings of the royal commission into petroleum drilling on the reef. We will continue to proceed co-operatively with Queensland on this matter. We have already declared one region, the Capricornia region. The Cairns region is now under consideration. I have no doubt that with good will what we propose will be done. We are making progress. No other government sought to do what we are doing. They had the opportunity to do it and they did not try to do it. So let those who now seek to criticise look to themselves and wonder why they did not take the opportunity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —I indicated that for those parts of the question for which I did not have specific information and on which I had not responded, I would seek to get Mr Fife to do so. I will so do.

—The first part of Senator Giles's question was about the qualifications and dates of appointment of two persons who have taken up positions in the Commonwealth Institute of Health with regard to the agent orange study. —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an article appearing in the Australian of 2 November which claims that Lebanese, Turkish and Greek migrants are being manipulated in the current stacking of Australian Labor Party branches in New South Wales. Will the Minister comment on the claims by Mr Peter Indari, Editor of Sydney's Arabic newspaper, An-Nahar, that 'Labor's infighting is dividing Lebanese people into ''them and us'' factions? Is the Minister aware that Mr Indari is preparing a formal complaint to be lodged with the Commissioner for Community Relations, Mr Al Grassby, on the grounds that Labor's factions are endeavouring to cultivate racism and sectarianism among Lebanese people by stirring up trouble between Moslems and Christians? If so, I ask the Minister: Will the Federal Government take action to ensure, firstly, that there is a full investigation of these serious claims,' and secondly, that facilities will be made available to prosecute any breaches of the Racial Discrimination Act that may be disclosed?

—I have noted that the article in question mentions that a Mr Indari is preparing a formal complaint to be lodged with the Commissioner for Community Relations. I do not know whether a formal complaint has been, in fact, lodged with the Commissioner. If it has, the Racial Discrimination Act requires the Commissioner to inquire into the complaint and to endeavour to effect a settlement. If this is unsuccessful the Commissioner may issue a certificate enabling the aggrieved person or persons to commence proceedings in the courts. A decision as to whether court action should be taken is one for the aggrieved person himself, of course, and not for the Government. If, in fact, there is a basis for the complaint being made it is deplorable that a political party is creating racial divisiveness in this community. The strongest action should be taken both to condemn it and to wipe it out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 Senator Watson asked me a question relating to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the granting of an export licence to the company Phil-Bai International Pty Ltd. I have had an answer supplied by the Minister for Primary Industry. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

In December 1979 the Philippines Government established Phil-Bai, a state trading organisation, to undertake the import of meat and livestock from Australia and New Zealand. Phil-Bai is controlled by the Philippines Bureau of Animal Industry. Following this decision, a company, Phil-Bai International Pty Ltd, was established in Australia with 90 per cent Philippine Government and 10 per cent Australian interests.

In July, 1980, Phil-Bai International applied to the AMLC for export licences for meat and livestock. The application was refused on the grounds that the Corporation was opposed to granting an Australian export licence to the purchasing arm of a foreign government sole import agency. This general policy of the AMLC is designed to protect the interests of the Australian industry in dealing with foreign sole importing agencies by preserving for the Corporation the right to step into the market itself as a sole seller so that it can, if necessary, deal with a sole buyer on equal terms.

As Phil-Bai has been able to arrange purchases of meat in Australia and arrange with licensed exporters to export the meat to the Philippines, the policy decision by the AMLC has not materially affected Phil-Bai's commercial interests. A number of Australian meat exporters have expressed satisfaction with the trading links they have established with Phil-Bai. There does not appear to have been any significant diversion of trade away from Australia to New Zealand because of the AMLC's action. Total exports of meat to the Philippines from Australia in 1980-81 were around 4,800 tonnes, compared to 5,300 tonnes for 1979-80.
I wish to state clearly that the Philippines is a valued trading partner of Australia and the Australian Government will do whatever it can to facilitate trade with the Philippines.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: USE OF HOBART BY JAPANESE FISHING VESSELS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 Senator Townley asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry on the matter of access by Japanese tuna longliners to the Australian fishing zone. The Minister for Primary Industry has provided me with a written reply. I seek leave to incorporate that reply in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

Negotiations on a new tuna longline agreement for the twelve months commencing 1 November 1981 have now been concluded. Under the new agreement, access by Japanese tuna longliners has been maintained to waters south of Tasmania, south of 40*S Latitude and east of 140*E Longitude, except for the 12-mile excluded area. Additional area and catch restrictions to those instituted under the previous agreement have been agreed in respect to Japanese operations in particular waters between 30*S Latitude and 40* S Latitude which are of importance to Australian fishing operations. However it is not expected that there will be any significant effect on port calls at Hobart by the tuna longline vessels.

The Government is aware of the economic significance of calls by longliners to the port of Hobart and other Australian ports and this matter has been taken into account during the negotiations with the Japanese.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October Senator Robertson asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. This question concerned the operation of prawn trawlers in Northern Australia. I have been provided with an additional reply to that question. I seek leave to incorporate that reply in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

On 4 November 1976 applications were invited from persons who satisfied any one of five published criteria to fish for prawns in the area known as the northern prawn fishery which extends from Cape Ford (Northern Territory) to Cape York (Queensland) as from 1 January 1977.

Applications received up to 1 December 1977 were considered and at that date, 286 had been approved. Five additional applications were subsequently approved following consideration of supporting information sought from the applicants prior to 1 December 1977 and received after that date. Following hearings before the High Court of Australia, an additional vessel was licensed to operate in the fishery in 1980.

The boatbuilding subsidy payable under the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 is payable for the construction of boats, including prawn trawlers which comply with the minimum dimensional requirements specified under that Act. Since 1973, over 100 trawlers constructed under the scheme are known to have been used in the northern prawn fishery.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: Recent evidence of the ineptitude of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the confusion caused in the community by attempts to implement it.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now some time since the publication of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the so-called razor gang, decisions. It is time, of course, that we reviewed and revisited some of those decisions to see actually what has happened to them since. It is now about six months since those decisions were made. At the time of the Review of Commonwealth Functions the series of decisions made by the Government, the so-called razor gang decisions, were touted about as a triumph for small government and lower taxation. In view of the Government's stated philosophy at the time, a lot of symbolism was attached to those decisions. The symbolism is important because increasingly the symbol is beginning to look like a monument. We will be drawing attention to that monument from now until the next election. In fact, the very day before the razor gang report was delivered half-tax-indexation was abolished and, effectively, the Government announced its intention to slug Australian taxpayers another $500m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the miraculous age of small government was heralded by the razor gang we have had a Budget which promises to take 22 per cent more in pay-as-you-earn taxation and $1,000m more in sales tax from the Australian people. That indicates just to what degree the razor gang was for real, and the reasons stated for its decisions were for real, in terms of bringing about lower taxation. It demonstrates the extent to which the Review of Commonwealth Functions was nothing but a stunt. Most of the actual decisions made in the course of the so-called review were made because the Government wished to be seen to be bringing in small government. They were not hard decisions. They had very little, if any, effect upon Government outlays. However, they were mostly bad decisions. They were certainly ad hoc decisions.

Perhaps the most extraordinary and spectacular example of this ad hoc approach was provided by the last minute excisions from the razor gang report itself. Certain sections were blacked out in printer's ink. In the statement brought down by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) the day before the report was presented changes were also made in the printed text to accommodate the views of particular Ministers. The statement itself might have been called a collage. It had been cut up with scissors, put together with sticky tape and re-photocopied within hours of its delivery.

I mention these things not just to demonstrate the degree of political turmoil which exists at the very highest levels of this Government and not just to demonstrate that its decision-making processes are like those which mark the essay writing of a poor student whose approach is characterised by months of dithering and weakness followed by a frenzied and desperate activity as the deadline approaches. I mention them because they belie in the clearest way the Government's portrayal of its decisions as the rational and thoughtful implementation of a political philosophy. Let us look at a few examples of the approach adopted by the Government.

In March, 1981 the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) opened a new building, constructed at a cost of some hundreds of thousands of dollars, for the Australian Curriculum Development Centre. In so doing, the Minister said:
In the five years since its establishment the Curriculum Development Centre has undertaken a formidable array of projects which have resulted in an enrichment of the fabric of Australian education.

One month after he made that statement and the money had been spent the razor gang put the existence of the Australian Curriculum Development Centre into jeopardy. That is a classic example of the question of whether the function of government is one of delivery of services or of something else. That question mark hangs over the whole of the deliberations of the razor gang. We still do not know the fate of the Australian Curriculum Development Centre, which Mr Fife praised to the skies in March of this year. That led to the conclusions that were drawn by Liberal back benchers such as Mr Burr, who said of the Government's performance, when speaking in the House of Representatives in September:
The Government on many issues is simply firing from the hip with ad hoc policy decisions that do not seem to correspond perhaps with other policy decisions that have been made in the past.

With respect, I could not have described it better myself. What better example is there of that than the fact that more than 40 committees were abolished by the razor gang. Over three-quarters of those 40 committees were established by Liberal-National Country Party governments. Half were created by governments led by Malcolm Fraser. All of the latter were created with a great song and dance, a great display of bravado about what they were going to do in terms of the performing of functions for the Australian people and the delivery of services by the Government. It is a case of, 'Now you see them, now you don't'. The Fraser Government announces a whole series of committees and a year or so later in many cases it abolishes the same committees. One would have thought that to be a wasteful process of government or of human activity in whatever area one is talking about.

More than one-quarter of the committees which were abolished were created in the last three years of the Fraser Government. Several advisory committees which the razor gang abolished and which arose from election promises either had never been established or had never met. In fact, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) misled the Parliament and the Australian people, when they stated, for example, that the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health would be abolished. Not only had no such body been established but also the Government had already decided never to go ahead with it, although it was the subject matter of an election promise by the Fraser Government. I suppose that the crowning achievement of all was the Government's abolition of the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Advisory Committee and the Technology Transfer Advisory Board. The Government abolished these committees, it said, to save money. Both committees were giving their services to the Government voluntarily and without any charge whatsoever.

When the report of the razor gang first saw the light of day I was concerned about what some of the implications of the decisions of the Government in relation to these matters would be. I placed a number of questions on the Notice Paper seeking information as to why various decisions had been taken. One such decision was to sell assets and to contract work out to the private sector. I asked whether the changes would make things more efficient, save money or lower prices. In hardly any case did the responsible Minister answer these questions in a way which suggested that these favourable results would follow. In most cases the Ministers concerned admitted that they had no idea what the effects of the decisions would be. The Department of Science and Technology, for example, will contract out the operation of the Baseline Air Pollution Station to private enterprise. That was a Government decision. Will it save money, will it promote efficiency? Nobody knows, least of all the Minister concerned. In answer to a question he said:
At this time it is not possible to make comparative economic assessments between (private and public) . . . operation of the facility.
When I asked the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) what would be the result of selling the Experimental Building Station, he had no idea. He said:
It is not possible at this stage to make a financial assessment.
When the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) was asked whether greater private contracting would save money he said that no cost comparison had been done. He went on to say:

. . . Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions are based not simply on cost savings but on the basis that many activities are undertaken by government which in the view of the Government would be more appropriately left to the private sector.

Why is that decision made in the case of a committee which is concerned with Commonwealth functions? What is the explanation for that extraordinary answer? In other words, the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions-the razor gang decisions-were not made on the basis of equity and efficiency. They are founded on ideological prejudice.

One of the great requirements of any government is the requirement of accountability to the Parliament and to the people through the media. That is no mean or insignificant requirement of government. It is fundamental for the workings of democracy as we know it that people have access to government, that they can ask questions of the Government about what it is doing and what its instrumentalities are doing. They ought to receive answers from the Government so that they know what it is doing and how it is using their money. I make this charge about accountability with some seriousness because this Government has the worst record of accountability of any Australian government since Federation. At the same time, I assert that a lack of accountability in government constitutes a strong threat to any nation that cherishes small government or decentralisation of power. Nothing sets the scene better for centralisation of power than a lack of accountability to the people about government decisions. The Government's record in this area has been a disgrace. I refer to the evasive answers to questions, the failure of Ministers in the Government to disclose publicly their financial interests and the financial interests of their families, the failure of the Prime Minister to grant access to the media, and so on.

The very document we are considering, the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, is an appalling document in the sense that it flouts the whole principle of accountability. We were given a list of 350 decisions, some of which were so vaguely worded it was impossible to extract a meaning, but none of the decisions is ever really explained. All the efforts were directed towards a public relations stunt and nothing was made clear about the functional aspects of a decision. We are told nothing about previously existing schemes and programs which were cut, or about existing arrangements which will be cut in the future. Because of the nature of this report I asked several hundred questions on notice seeking information which ought to have been provided by the report itself. I have quoted from some of the answers. As the razor gang was alleged to produce an eventual ongoing saving of $560m to the Commonwealth Government, I asked for the breakdown of that saving. I received an extraordinary answer from the Prime Minister. He said:
Many of the decisions were not of a kind where the savings could be stated at the time.

The savings could not be stated at the time, but out of the blue we get a figure of $560m, which is all part of the stunt of the razor gang announcing a $560m cut in Commonwealth expenditure. Yet when we ask how that cut is calculated no information is available at all. The Government had no idea what any particular decision of the razor gang would save but it said that all the ingredients total $560m. When a journalist from the National Times, Julie Flynn, spoke to senior public servants about the $560m which would allegedly be saved, most of them laughed, she reports. One said:
We don't know what the savings will be. No costing has been done of how much some of the recommendations will actually cost the Government.
Another one said:
Pick a number, any number and multiply by two. You've got just as much chance of being right as anyone in the Public Service.

So much for the $560m which the Commonwealth Government says it will save. So is it any wonder that the razor gang report is seen as a stunt and an example of incompetence and confusion rather than anything else? The razor gang has given rise to more than 200 Public Service reviews-committees on committees and things of that kind. I thought that sort of monumental inefficiency was reserved for the Parliament. That means that one in every two recommendations of the razor gang involved the setting up of a review. In the Public Service Board alone, 60 reviews are occupying the full time of 65 people. That represents a cost to the Public Service Board of $1m so far.

In the Education portfolio there is a degree of chaos resulting from the razor gang decisions. No one knows what is happening to the Australian Curriculum Development Centre. Of the 30 colleges of advanced education scheduled for rationalisation, one was reprieved and six remain in limbo. At Question Time today Senator Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, was unable to answer any question from Senator Siddons about costs and alleged efficiencies which will arise from those decisions. It has become clear that implementation of the decision on fees for second degrees would be an administrative nightmare. Fortunately the Government may be saved by a wise decision of the Senate in relation to that matter. Six months on from the razor gang, confusion reigns as to what will become of the Australian Wool Testing Authority and the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, to name just two of the Government's more ill-advised sales to private interests-if those sales, in fact, ever take place.

All that adds up not to cost cutting or small government but to bad government, confused government. It is little wonder that this Government, lurching from one political crisis to another, can seize events such as that as merely public relations stunts. It is very little wonder that the Government's own back bench members criticise it for being ad hoc. It is little wonder that the business community in Australia is at the end of its tether. Sir Roderick Carnegie, Chairman of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, when talking about the present Government put it this way on 1 September this year:

It has created uncertainty in the minds of buyers about Australia's reliability . . . They're changing the rules of the game all the time. It is very hard for people who are approaching things in the short term perspective of politics to understand the long term damage they do.

There is very little wonder at that when one looks at the abolition of 40 committees, 20 of which were established by the present Government in the last two years. The President of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr Hugh Morgan of Western Mining, said of this year's Budget, in the same sort of context:
The Government did not understand what it was doing.

The razor gang was heralded in a blaze of Government rhetoric about small government philosophy. The difference between the Opposition's and the Government's philosophies in this area is marked indeed, but it is not a permanent difference in attitude on the size of government spending and it is not a fundamental difference in attitude on the expenditure by the Australian Public Service which should be justified. One would have hoped it was not a difference in relation to the accountability of a government for its decision making, but we suspect it is. We would insist on much greater degrees of accountability than this present Government is concerned with. The basic difference between the Government and the Opposition is that the Opposition has a conception of the role of government in a healthy mixed economy. That does not mean that the ideology should be so overbearing as to exclude an assessment of what functions government and private enterprise can provide in a healthy mixed economy.

The Opposition does not believe in hacking away at one sector of the economy without undertaking a much more considered review than the Review of Commonwealth Functions-the so-called razor gang. One would hope that in a review of the functions of government there would be an assessment of the sorts of questions which I can briefly enumerate in the time available to me: Does this function of government promote or otherwise the welfare of the most needy sections of the Australian population? Does this function of government provide objective information for the Australian community and the private sector of the economy? These questions can be thought about in the light of the various bodies which were abolished. Further, should government intervene in the economy to stimulate competition and to promote efficiency and social justice? Do the decisions made by the government do that? Do they promote the decentralisation of political power in Australia or rather do they promote the centralisation of political power and the absence of accountability? These are fundamental questions to which any review of the functions of the Australian Government and the Australian Public Service should address itself. None of these issues were addressed by the razor gang. That has led to the confusion which is very apparent in the Australian community at the present time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button submitted to the Senate a matter of public importance. He raised matters which he claimed were evidence of the ineptitude of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the confusion caused in the community by attempts to implement its recommendations. I want to say a number of things on this subject.
