SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button made a most reflective speech. It was a speech which I think, in his own terms, showed that he realised that we needed to come to terms with the size of government in this country. That is not unique to Australia. All around the world, countries are looking at the size of government, the intrusion of government and the role of government. I was fascinated to hear Senator Button talk about the decentralisation of the power of government. I welcome the comment which he made along those lines. If we are to look at the matters that were raised, perhaps we should look at the background and the reason why the Review was undertaken at the time when it commenced last year. The Government decided to take the initiative to look at a number of the functions of the Commonwealth Government and to try to determine-it is not easy to do that, given the size of government-whether some of those functions could be better or adequately undertaken by the private sector, by another level of government or by individuals. This is reflected in the report and in the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) when the report was introduced into the Parliament. Perhaps we ought to reflect on why the Australian Labor Party feels there is some threat from this report. Perhaps it does reflect the fact that there was community support for the philosphy of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to us, to the people. We don't feel threatened by it at all.

— No. I think there is community support for the fact that government is prepared to look at itself. I think it is high time that it did. I was fascinated by much of what the honourable senator said. In the conservative nature of his approach to government Senator Button said that there is no room for change with government-that because one sets up 40 committees ipso facto for ever and a day one needs those 40 committees to continue. It does not matter whether their relevance has been lost, whether the paper work which they produce is of assistance to government, whether the people who are giving voluntary time and at the same time causing work in the departments to service them are of value and that the time that those people are prepared to give could be appreciated and used by government. I believe the report was a far-reaching one. It represents a significant undertaking by the Federal Government. I hope that we are prepared to continue to look at the size of the departments, the range of advice that comes in to government and the way in which this can be ultimately reflected in the role of government and in the decisions taken by government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the report recognised one matter that was very timely: That was the desire of the Australian community for smaller government. We sometimes hear people talking these days about more limited government. That is not a new term either. At the same time when people talk of smaller government, they link with that lower taxation because they realise that government does not generate its own wealth. The resources of the Australian people are used to provide this level of government and to provide the size of government that has grown. People are looking also at the regulatory style of government that we have and whether it relates to business or to any other aspect of community life. I believe that there is a mood in the community to recognise that less centralised control of government is a good thing. I was glad to hear Senator Button expressing the same sort of proposition.

The report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions did express the Government's determination to make sure that the Commonwealth Government's operations are as streamlined and as efficient as they can be. That is not something that one is able to do, or is able to pretend that one can do, by one review over a number of months by a servicing unit and a small number of Ministers. To talk of streamlining governments of the size that exists in Australia at the Commonwealth level at least is to identify an enormous task. It is an ongoing task and we ought to be prepared to look at it. I wonder whether the Australian Labor Party does recognise that the Australian community wants lower taxation and that the only way to get this is to reduce the size of government and to make the public sector more efficient. Perhaps the people should be asked whether they do want continuity of these services, which we have decided are the services that they want and for which they will pay, regardless whether they feel that they are of benefit to them.

From time to time we have heard Senator Button and other Opposition senators urging, in this place and on other platforms, more Government spending in a host of areas. Of course, that has one inevitable consequence. According to the Australian Labor Party, more money is needed for education, welfare benefits, construction in Canberra and any sort of shopping list that one might like to mention. Every time a Bill is introduced the Opposition says that either we do not need to raise the revenue or that we ought to have more expenditure. That equation just does not work. We cannot have more expenditure and less revenue. Yet that has been the whole pattern of this session of the Senate in considering proposals relating to the 1981 Budget. If Senator Button sees his role as being a spokesman for all the interest groups that come to his party, perhaps he recognises that the review of government that was undertaken might have the consequences that we find. Perhaps criticism of the fact that we have removed some committees and that we have endeavoured to rationalise some of the things that were being done has made every interest group come to him and put forward its proposals. If he has that sort of pressure upon him perhaps he feels that he has to raise a matter of public importance of this kind and to ventilate the issues in order to try to explain exactly what role the Labor Party is taking with regard to the size of government and the continuity of these things that over the years we have added to.

I think we search in vain now for responsible suggestions from the Opposition as to how Government expenditure can be restrained or how it can be reduced. I would have thought that the ALP always expressed the philosophy of an expanded public sector; that it had a program for curing every ill in the community; that a government should make life a new Utopia for the Australian people. I think what Senator Button has done today is very welcome indeed. When we were facing the electors at the last election the Australian Labor Party attempted to portray its policies in so many areas as being similar to those of the Fraser Government. This is what we are seeing again today. There seems to be something like a consensus with regard to government. Maybe that is how it is going to work out. Are we all going to be prepared to review things and have efficiency and accountability? That sounds good on a day such as this but we would have to argue that accountability in government was not exactly the experience of the Australian people when the present Opposition was the Government. Efficiency was also not one of that Government's notable features. If we now have a new understanding of accountability and efficiency in government, we are well along the way to finding some responsibility that we can share in the role of government in Australia.

I think there is one area in which the ALP will find it difficult to walk down the path with a Liberal and National Country Party Government; that is the area of lower taxation. We have found in all the speeches from the Opposition throughout this Budget session a reference to the need for more expenditure in every area that has been mentioned. There has been limited acceptance of some of the Bills but always it was said that there ought to be more expenditure. That makes it extremely difficult for us to fulfil perhaps one of the prime objectives at the time that the Review of Commonwealth Functions was set up-to see how we can have efficiency in government, how we can have the accountability that was mentioned, and at the same time reduce the burden on the Australian taxpayers who have to provide the resources for government programs which have grown to such a large extent.

In the last few days the Press has reported further attempts by the Australian Labor Party to develop a new range of taxes, such as wealth taxes and capital gains taxes, to finance its policies. If there is to be restraint in government expenditure one would need to ask why there is this constant interest in the raising of additional taxes. That is one of the areas where we part company with the Labor Party because we are looking at restraint in government expenditure. That is a constant thread that has run throughout the six years of Fraser Government. We want to restrain expenditure so that we are able to reduce the burden of tax collections that need to be made to finance government programs. I think Senator Button has the intelligence to recognise the electoral difficulty of the Australian Labor Party in such policies with regard to the collection of taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not be sure of that. That is putting it too high.

— We do not hear the honourable senator getting up too often advocating wealth taxes and capital gains taxes. I think that he probably has the intelligence to recognise what the reaction of the Australian people would be to those matters. I think they are very lucky to have the honourable senator sitting where he is sitting.
—You are the best looking senator here, too.

—Yes, I think we can probably agree on a number of things. The honourable senator has to recognise-I am sure that he does-that big government means high taxation and it cannot be funded in any way other than through collections in various ways from the Australian people. The Review of Commonwealth Functions committee was perhaps able to take just one small step forward to stop the growth of big government.

SPEECH.PARA: If real growth in Budget outlays can be held down, the consequences, especially in terms of an enhanced potential for income tax reductions, are more obvious than they otherwise would be. No one can suggest that it is easy to put together the expenditure side and the revenue raising, tax collecting and other government charges side of the Budget and come out with the sort of result we have achieved on this occasion. But this is one of the reasons why we have made a continued attack on expenditure. It is perhaps one of the reasons why there is a continued attack on this report. The fact that through this exercise we were prepared to look at ways in which government might try to restrain its growth and contain its expenditure is probably why we have been attacked. The result of that sort of achievement would be a greater capacity to lower the tax collections from the people of Australia.

We certainly believe the Review of Commonwealth Functions is making an important contribution to the objective of further reining in government expenditure. This makes room for private sector growth and paves the way for significant reductions in the burden of taxation. These are the principles underlying the review. I would also draw attention to the fact that the Prime Minister said when he introduced the report that the philosophy behind it went further than simply the restraint of expenditure. The restraint of expenditure is at the heart of the Government's overall approach to economic policy but it also is this Government's belief that we should emphasise the right of individuals to economic self-determination by reducing bureaucratic barriers to fair competition and by reducing the burden of overblown government on the economy.

Senator Button mentioned that we had not been able to put into effect many of the decisions made in the report; that it was a report that really had no substance and no achievement. But considerable progress has been made towards giving effect to the Government's decision. I stress that considerable progress has been made. Legislation passed by the Parliament last session gave legislative effect where necessary to a number of the decisions and administrative action has been taken to implement many others. Far from there being a disorderly process plagued by ineptitude, as the matter of public importance submitted by Senator Button claims, the reverse is in fact true. The implementation of all Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions is being carefully monitored by a committee of senior Ministers chaired by Sir Phillip Lynch which meets on a regular basis to oversight the implementation of all of the decisions. At the end of October about 270 or 75 per cent of the originally announced decisions had been implemented or were very close to final implementation. That, in such a short period, is the sort of achievement that we were looking for from the implementation of the report. The remaining decisions are being vigorously pursued and certainly some of them do take time to implement.

The committee and the responsible Ministers, where decisions affect their area of responsibility, are carefully working toward the implementation of the remaining decisions where this is possible. It was never envisaged that overnight all the recommendations could be implemented, because some involve highly complex legal and administrative questions and some require lengthy negotiations with State governments and other bodies. The sale of a number of government assets, for example, has thrown up some difficulties which could not have been foreseen at the time, but progress in all of these cases is satisfactory and proceeding according to schedule. Expressions of interest need to be sought if we are to look at the disposal of government assets or government functions, and there will always be a need for negotiations with interested persons or bodies to take place and for consultations with the individuals, staff associations, unions and others who are involved. In all of this, the consultation and the consideration are being processed as quickly as practicable.

As was stated by the Prime Minister in his statement, on the basis of staffing assessments made to that date a reduction in staffing of the order of 16,000 to 17,000 public servants was expected. That target remains the expectation. In other words, there was an expectation from all the recommendations that there would be a reduction in staffing of some 16,000 or 17,000 Commonwealth public servants. Instead of a growth in the public sector, as we have so often seen, we find through this staffing assessment a deliberate reduction. Surely that shows the reasons behind the decisions that were taken and the effect of them. The Review indicated ongoing savings of some $560m. Decisions taken in the Review now merge with other decisions that were taken in the Budget, which is still before the Parliament. Many of the decisions taken in the Budget context are reflections of recommendations and decisions taken on recommendations in the RCF. So I imagine that were Julie Flynn or someone else to ask a Commonwealth public servant how costings were made, she would need to go to every department and she would need to go right through the Budget and look at the reflection of these decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to every Minister.

— If Senator Button were to enhance smaller government and then were to reflect on the questions that he placed on the Notice Paper, perhaps one thing that would be shown would be that he has a very active research capacity in his office and a very vibrant mind to dream up questions. But perhaps he has very little understanding of the need to conserve the resources of government for the more practical things he mentioned in his speech as being desirable to help those in need or those who require the services of government. The total Budget package provides savings, against the 1981-82 forward estimates, well in excess of the $560m mentioned as savings as a result of the decisions of the RCF.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate for the brief time allocated to me to support Senator Button's contention that the recent evidence of the ineptitude of the committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions and the confusion caused in the community by attempts to implement its recommendations are matters of importance to this Senate and, indeed, to the whole country. One realises how correct Senator Button was in bringing up this matter of public importance when one hears the reply from the good Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who has just sat down. We got 10 minutes of her version of the Australian Labor Party's policy in various areas and her version of the Labor Party's debate on taxation policy in recent times, and then various comments on how difficult it was really to assess just what the Review of Commonwealth Functions Committee had done and would do and how difficult it was to assess how much would be saved. I do not remember any mention of any item in the review or any attempt to justify just what has happened in the six months since the report on it came down.

SPEECH.PARA: We did hear from the Minister that the review carried out a couple of important functions of this Government. They included looking at means of lowering taxes and consulting with people about whether they wished to continue with the services already in existence. I suggest that in the activities of the Review-the so-called razor gang-one has had no evidence at all of any consultation with any community group or with very few Public Service groups as to what we should do about the various services we have in the community. The Minister sits as Minister for Finance in the Government which is, in fact, the highest taxing government in our history. Taxes are a higher proportion of gross domestic product than they have ever been in this community, a fact pointed out not only by the Opposition and by politicians in this country but also by Mr Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association and every economic observer in existence.

In fact there is no evidence that this Review will result in reduced taxes. As the Government is attempting to apply more indirect taxes in the form of sales tax, to put up charges to people in the community, particularly in the health area and in the pharmaceutical benefits area and to restrict social security benefits, it is hard to see how anything that has resulted from this Review or from any of this Government's actions will reduce costs on the people in this community. It certainly will not reduce costs on the disadvantaged people of this community. The Committee consisted of a group of senior Ministers sitting together in what they were happy enough to describe, and in what everyone else described, as the razor gang. They treated it as a great little effort. They had their photographs taken for the newspaper with the leader of the gang, Sir Phillip Lynch, sitting there with a razor, all with big rosy smiles on their faces, to promote this so-called Review of Commonwealth Functions.

Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, on 7 May this year called the results of their deliberations imaginative decisions. If one accepts the definition of imagination as being the mental faculty forming images of external objects not present to the senses-in other words, a dream-like situation-then one can understand that that is in fact what happened. Those Ministers sat down and dreamed up images out of the air. They worked out roughly where they could make these reductions as though they were all sitting round smoking pot or taking LSD and having a collective hallucination, and this report was a result of that. The Prime Minister announced that this was a serious attempt, as the Minister said here today, to reduce government functions and that the Committee had had a serious look at what was happening in the community so far as the functions of government were concerned. It had reviewed these functions and decided to rationalise some and to reduce others.

One can suggest that the words 'review', 'rationalise' and 'reduce', which are repeated over and over again throughout this report, mean that the Committee was cutting out wherever it could, willy-nilly, like some Jack the Ripper with a razor. Since then there have been several reviews of the review. Some changes have been made, some things have been cut out and in some cases it was decided that it was impossible to carry out some of the functions that the Review suggested should be carried out. We have had confusion in the community, demonstrated by Senator Button and by statements like those of Sir Roderick Carnegie, and we have had this demonstration of the ineptitude of the whole exercise. If one looks through the Review, it seems to do several things. In some places it announces the abolition of non-existent authorities or non-existent functions of government. We will come to that later. In other cases it gives an excuse for the Government to back off from unwise decisions that were made by the Prime Minister, decisions that in themselves were stunts, decisions that were thrown out as election gimmicks but which never got off the ground. If one looks at page 30 of the Review of Commonwealth Functions one sees it has been decided:
The Government will withdraw its offer of assistance for the proposed Sydney-Melbourne railway electrification in view of the lack of priority accorded to this project by the States.

This project was announced by the Prime Minister without any consultation with the States. The States did not want it. The people knew that it was too expensive and not appropriate to be introduced at the time. What better chance for the Prime Minister to get out of this nonsensical promise that he made than to say that this Review of serious Ministers has decided that because of the States' actions the Government will not go ahead with it.

As Senator Button has pointed out, some 60 consultative committees established in the last few years by the Government-many of them in existence for fewer than two years-were also cut out by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. We know that some of them should have been cut out. We said so when they were established. Many of them were established with enormous fanfare by the Minister for Finance, who is sitting at the table. She used to come into this place and announce the setting up of another consultative committee the members of which she, of course, always picked herself. They were mostly not allowed to report to the Parliament and to talk about their consultations with the organisations to which they belonged. Of course the committees were an embarrassment to the Minister because they were phoney when they were set up. They were never meant to be consultative committees. What better opportunity to get rid of them without embarrassment than to have this senior group of Ministers in the guise of cutting government functions to make up for the Minister's mistakes!

There was another series of decisions which were obviously ad hoc, ill conceived and ill thought out. They caused much confusion in the community and have since been changed. There were silly little decisions-decisions which harmed many people and which cost very little. One of the first results of this Review was to suspend a publication from the ethnic Press. Only the publication was suspended. It was a small publication distributed to a few thousand people and contained a review of the various sections of the ethnic Press translated into English and distributed throughout the Public Service and the community members who were vitally interested in what was happening in the ethnic Press. The Government still continued to have the information collected and correlated. The Government still had the information printed for its own purposes within the responsible department but for a few thousand dollars it stopped distributing this information and therefore affected a group of people who were concerned about one of the great disadvantaged groups in our community-the migrants, and particularly the newly arrived migrants. It was not surprising when another journalist-I refer to another well-known female journalist, Jenni Hewett from the Sydney Morning Herald-looked into the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions when it was produced and also decided to contact senior members of the Public Service and indeed senior members of the Government. The answer she got was similar to the answers that Julie Flynn, whose remarks Senator Button quoted, got. One gentleman said:
'The Government is-ah-essentially restating-no, ah-clarifying its position with respect to this.'
'Look, have you seen that TV show, Yes, Minister. It explains a lot.'
Another said:
'Doesn't mean a bloody thing. It's nonsense. We do it already.'

This is the sort of derision with which this review and this report were in fact treated by the Public Service. There were small absurdities in the report, like the abolition of positions such as the controller of prices, the receiver of scalps and the rent controller which had not been operational for many years. These positions were costing nothing and were doing nothing, yet their abolition was announced with great seriousness as a means of cutting down. The decision to abolish the Legislative Drafting Institute merely meant that when Mr Neil Sexton retired his position would not be filled. This was the area used in the training of overseas people interested in legislative drafting skills. That small piece of assistance has now gone out of the window. It is that sort of decision which really makes no great difference to our budgetary situation but in fact may make a great difference to our reputation overseas.

There were more serious changes, of course, such as the abolition of the collection of statistics including the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics. We no longer know how many people are registered for jobs and in particular we do not know how many registered jobs are in specific areas. These were the only figures which showed the distribution of unemployment difficulties in our community. But the review committee, by some of its decisions, upset even those who were normally the friends and supporters of the Government. One can cite no better example of this than the decision to dispose of the Australian Wool Testing Authority to private enterprise. This decision, as every honourable senator knows, created considerable uproar amongst the private wool growers, the wool distributors and others in the community. The Government decided to get rid of the Authority. There was an uproar in the industry because private enterprise had worked in this area and it had failed. There were then some grave doubts as to whether the Government could get rid of the Authority at all. There was some uncertainty as to whether the Government was in a position to get rid of the Authority because of the ownership of it.

Now, after much confusion-confusion which continues-we know that the Government has been negotiating with the Australian Wool Corporation and that it has informed the Government in a letter dated 13 October that, in fact, the result of transferring this organisation, as apparently the Government wishes to do, may mean an increase in costs ranging from 8 per cent to 14 per cent-in some cases up to 20 per cent-in the area of wool testing. The letter states:
. . . the preferred option set out in the Report is largely a matter of cosmetic accounting which is far removed from any commercial sale.

That is the sort of 'commercial sale' advocated in the review committee's report. The review committee came down with a firm decision to get rid of the Australian Wool Testing Authority willy-nilly and hand it over to private enterprise. We then had the situation in which the Government was uncertain whether it could do it. Its own supporters did not want it to do it. When the Government eventually cut through the confusion and approached the Wool Corporation about the matter, the Wool Corporation said, in fact, that we are indulging in a cosmetic transfer of the accounting methods and a transfer of the assets of this organisation. To do so would cost the wool grower and, therefore, the community some 8 per cent to 14 per cent more for wool testing. That is a perfect example of the ineptitude of the Government in an area in which it, through its colleagues in the National Country Party and those rural members of the Liberal Party, claims some expertise. It is a perfect example of the ineptitude which Senator Button points out in this matter of public importance. I believe that I need go no further. There are many other examples throughout the whole system. The reviews ordered by this committee into the area of social security have not been completed. They are being conducted with great confusion and have created confusion among those people who so much need the services of the Department of Social Security.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chaos that is being caused and will continue to be caused by the razor gang cuts is a typical example of one of the basic problems facing our economy. I refer to the ad hockery, to the lack of long term direction and to the lack of indicative planning from which this country suffers. If we are going to save costs in Australia we have to do it first by clearly sorting out what our long term objectives are. We cannot have everything. We do have to make choices in this country. It is reasonable that those choices be quantified. In arriving at the sorts of long terms objectives and the sorts of areas where we want to concentrate our resources in the interests of our long term development, an attempt should be made for a bipartisan approach to these long term objectives. It can be done. The costs of what we are attempting to do can be quantified.

SPEECH.PARA: What have we seen with the razor gang? We have seen a whole series of decisions made without any attempt to quantify their cost-effectiveness. I illustrate what I mean by taking a very simple example. We have been told that we are to save $560m and 16,000 places in the Public Service. I suggest that those figures can be taken with a grain of salt. I take this simple example to point out exactly why that is the case. I refer to the Commonwealth Parliament Offices in Victoria. It had a staff of cleaners who were conscientious and enthusiastic in their jobs. As a result of the razor gang cuts they were told one day that they were to be retrenched, that their services were no longer required. Some of them were temporary and some of them were permanent public servants. Those senators who have offices in the Commonwealth Parliament Offices in Victoria went to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and asked: 'How much saving will this result in? What alternatives are there to keep the offices clean?'. We were told that a firm of contract cleaners would be brought in. There has been no attempt to cost the alternative cleaning approach.

It was very clear in the discussions that we had that the prime consideration of the Minister and, I presume, of the Government, is to reduce the size of the Public Service, to get people off the payroll of the Public Service. This is presumably so that at election time the Government can say: 'There are 16,000 fewer people employed by the Government'. That is not good enough. We have to look at the cost-effectiveness of what is being done and we have to look at the cost of the alternatives.

I want to illustrate the chaos that the razor gang's ad hoc decisions have caused in two important areas: Firstly, in education and, secondly, in the proposed closure of two important Government factories producing our defence requirements. In the case of education, I believe one of the worst ideas emerging from the razor gang's report was a decision that 30 of our colleges of advanced education had to merge with other colleges by the end of this year. It has proved a most disastrous decision both to individuals and to the colleges concerned. Mr Geoff Maslen, the education editor of the Age, wrote:

The list of 30 colleges named by the Razor Gang was taken from a table in the last Tertiary Education Commission's report-a table unrelated to any proposals for mergers and which simply listed colleges mainly involved with teacher education. In the process, the Razor Gang overlooked several colleges with fewer than 1,000 students which might have benefited from a merger.

Moreover, instead of accepting a reasonable proposal from the TEC that the colleges be allowed until 1984 to draw up 'flexible plans and options' for amalgamation, the Commonwealth plumped for 8 months. The result has been inevitable confusion, great hardship to individuals, particularly teachers, and a general lack of morale.

I wish to quote from a letter I received from Peter Norman, a teacher of 31 years service with the Education Department in Victoria and who has written at great length on education. He has been told that come the end of this year his services will no longer be required. He wrote:

During 1981, I have been pushed from pillar to post-a year of total confusion. Early in the year, there was serious talk of Frankston combining with Rusden. As Rusden was shorter of science staff than Frankston, I was asked to go to Rusden 1 1/2 days a week in addition to my work at Frankston.

He went on to say that he was then sent to the Caulfield Institute of Technology because there was some possibility of an amalgamation. Now he has been told that his services will no longer be required. That is just typical of thousands of cases of hardship that are arising from the razor gang's decision to merge colleges of advanced education rapidly, without any real reference to the staff and without any real planning. We cannot hope to save money unless we plan to do so.

The other example I want to take is the case of the Government defence factory at Bendigo and its clothing factory at Coburg. Decisions were made regarding these factories without due regard to the possible repercussions on our defence preparedness. This applies particularly to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, where we have a nucleus of expertise, highly technical staff who could be used in the event of an emergency rapidly to expand their expertise in private industry. Presumably we went ahead with these decisions on the basis that it was not very difficult to obtain defence equipment from overseas. That is not the case. I quote from a recent article in the US News and World Report which states that the arms buildup in the United States is already in deep trouble. It continues:
The effects of a shortage of metals and raw materials already are apparent, both in higher prices and long delays in weapons production.

We have orders on the United States for vital defence equipment, equipment that could well have been made at the Bendigo Ordnance Factory but instead was ordered on the United States. We now find that deliveries of that vital equipment from the United States have been drastically extended and we have no real commitment as to when we are likely to get it. It is very apparent that with the problems the United States has in producing defence equipment for its own purposes, in building up its own defence production capacity, this vital equipment required by Australia will be further and further delayed. Those are two examples-education and defence production-where long-term implications have not been taken into account, and of course that applies to a whole range of other areas.

I conclude, in the short time I have available, by saying that we are talking about a very basic problem, the ad hockery of Government decisions. Very shortly in this place we will debate another area of ad hockery, namely, the rate of protection of manufacturing industry in this country, particularly as it applies to the automotive industry. All these areas must be looked at in terms of where we are heading. The Japanese can do it very well. They have a planning department called the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, or MITI. They have representatives in most countries who quantify the demand in all countries. They then get these long-term projections before the companies that are involved in the manufacture and discuss their projections with them. They get agreement with interested parties, industry, trade unions and the community as to what is the likely demand for a particular product. They then look at their own resources and the development that can be expected in certain areas. The Japanese said that they were going to concentrate on two areas-the manufacture of motor cars and the production of steel. They did so with great efficiency. But everybody in that country knew in which areas the encouragement of development would take place. In Australia we have no idea. We do not know from one day to the next whether we want manufacturing industry or what sort of manufacturing industry we want. We do not know whether we are going to spend money on education or to what degree and in what areas. We are then told that these ad hoc, short term decisions, as in the case of the razor gang, are being made to save money. There is only one way in which we will save money and that is to get our priorities in order and to plan carefully the best way and the most efficient way in which to achieve these objectives in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I sincerely reject the view put forward by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator John Button, claiming ineptitude in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Similarly, I wish to squash the thought which may be in the minds of the community that there is some confusion on the Government's part. I contend that, if there is to be any allegation of confusion, that confusion is certainly not of the Government's making; rather, it has been insidiously generated by those who have some vested interests to protect or who have a philosophy which is out to destroy the Government's philosophy. From that remark it is fairly obvious that he has not read the statement.

I believe that our Government has wisely set out its objectives and followed these objectives in implementing its decisions. The Government's first objective is to make sure that Commonwealth Government activity does not crowd out the private enterprise sector by inhibiting private sector expansion in the area of job opportunities. I believe that in this debate there has been a degree of nitpicking and a flippant attitude by those who are putting forward this charge against the Government which is intended to cloud the overall picture of what our Government is trying to do and the philosophy that it is pursuing. The Australian Labor Party, on the one hand, seeks to increase the high degree of government intervention at all levels in the lives of individuals in our society, which ultimately tends to sap people's initiative, tends to destroy morale and tends to lead towards a high degree of negativism. On the other hand, we have a Liberal Party philosophy which is manifest in these recommendations of the review committee, which seeks to reward initiative and to motivate individuals and at the same time to care for people in our society who are in genuine need. This is something that is often overlooked. We have a basic concern to care for those who are in genuine need.

How will we go about achieving these objectives? We will streamline and fine down Commonwealth operations by partly withdrawing from functions that are more appropriately those of State governments or even of private enterprise. At the same time we will rationalise the functions which properly belong to the Commonwealth Government. I must congratulate the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for lifting this debate to a very much higher plane than other speakers. The starting point of the whole exercise lies with individuals. Our Liberal Party philosophy places importance on individuals. Page 1 of the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions states:

The Review's starting point is that Australia's greatest resource is the Australian people and that the role of government is to enable people to exercise their abilities, their skills, their imaginations and their enterprise.

I readily acknowledge that the Review of Commonwealth Functions has come as somewhat of a jolt to those who have self-created little empires which they now wish to continue to preserve. Naturally, they have felt under attack. They are rebelling. If there is some confusion it is surely coming from this quarter.

If there is any criticism of this committee maybe it is because it has taken such a long time to get a committee established and to set up all the necessary mechanisms and the machinery so that we can evaluate Commonwealth functions and consider those that are really irrelevant to the needs of this day and generation. The Review really goes much further than that. It is part of a whole program whereby we are seeking out cost cutting measures over a range of Commonwealth expenditure. This philosophy was manifested in the Budget. In the Budget, for the first time in many years, we have a domestic surplus. Most of us realise that running a nation is not very much different in economic terms from running the ordinary household. True, there are many differences in the scale of operations and in the quantum of money, but the economic principles are much the same. We cannot continue to live beyond our means or continue to service by debt recurrent expenditure of government, such as the paying of politicians' salaries, public servants' salaries and the cost of pensions. This is all part of this whole economic philosophy of living beyond one's means. Perhaps it is good economics to finance, partially, long term capital assets that will serve future generations through the creation of debt. It is certainly bad economics to live beyond one's means by creating debt to pay for recurrent expenditures of government.

I believe that we should make a positive contribution, that this review should be part of an on-going plan rather than be a one-off exercise. Whilst the imposition of staff ceilings may be a short term measure necessary to save government money, in the long term we must look at more appropriate measures. I use an analogy from the University of Tasmania. The department of information science, a growing faculty, is housed in prefabricated buildings. The staff ceiling imposed does not recognise the growth departments and departments in need. Therefore, I believe that we have to look at programs that will evaluate the whole function of government in terms of the needs of our present society. I believe that we must seek, therefore, to develop programs and functions that are appropriate to the needs of our decade rather than to continue to build on programs, patterns and administrations that have grown like Topsy, that inhibit communication and that are too costly in terms of modern technology.

Earlier I mentioned some of the problems of negativism. We must seek to adopt modern technology, provided always that in so doing we employ adequate safeguards. For instance, we could with advantage introduce microelectronics techniques. I believe that, with the aid of mini-computers, we could have a degree of centralised policy-making yet carry out administration in decentralised areas of importance, or in the States, so that there could be personal contact with people. It is true that some old jobs will disappear, but if we hold back too long, whether in government or in private enterprise, in adopting such technology and cling instead to outdated techniques, we will be surpassed by those nations which do adopt it and, in the long term, will see our present standard of living disappear.

Last weekend His Grace, Archbishop Young, in addressing the Catholic Parents and Friends Association's annual meeting in Burnie, spoke of the dangers of nominalism. He was not using the term in a political context but his thoughts bear further examination. When we think of nominalism we can relate it to our church, to our ideals, to our morals and even to our political pursuasion. Although we speak of liberalism in many ways I believe that in the Review of Commonwealth Functions we have a demonstration of the application of that philosophy-along a line that we are pursuing for the first time. We are trying to amend things to ensure that they fit that philosophy.

To return to the subject of nominalism, all too often we hear research scientists and people from universities lament the proportion of students moving away from mathematics and physics studies and choosing instead what are really the soft options. That epitomises what is happening in our society today. We are seeking the easy way out and possibly tending to increase the range of government activities irrespective of need. In so doing we impose increasing burdens of taxation. As a party we must seek to loosen the shackles from the necks of the people. We must try to lift some of the burden of taxation. I believe that the Review of Commonwealth Functions was a first attempt in that direction. In other words, we must begin to appraise some of the sacred cows that gradually are being permitted to graze on what must, after all, be a limited pasture.

Every farmer knows that he must make allowance for the problems of drought and the difficulties of winter. We must look to the future. We must fine-tune government programs and philosophies in order to provide a worthwhile future for our children.

My colleague, Senator Martyr, recently suggested that we should be looking at ways of removing some of the antiquated statutes, regulations and ordinances that no longer are applicable to our society. Too many people in our community believe that the Commonwealth has an unlimited purse, but we must remember that what they are advocating is the spending of the taxpayers' money. All too often we see deviations from the original intent of a statute, instrumentality or agency of government. Recently an example was provided by Qantas Airways Ltd. Unfortunately Qantas ran into financial difficulties as a result of unprofitable trading situations. When we look behind the balance sheet we find, first, an imbalance between debt and equity capital which is more synonymous with a highly geared finance company than a suitably run airline and, secondly, an involvement in hotels, in constructing new buildings and so on which take over $100m to complete. While the board of directors is concentrating on these things a proportion of its time is diverted from its true purpose, that of conducting an airline.

I believe that we need continuing monitoring from the Parliament to ensure that these statutory corporations are operating according to the dictates of the statute or ordinance that creates them. Let the managers manage. Regrettably there is interference from far too many interdepartmental committees. Some people on our side of politics have stated that these cost cutting measures have not gone far enough. I believe that the Opposition has failed to sustain the charges that have been levelled. I believe that we have a philosophy for the future. I move:

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: Pollution of the River Murray

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Jessop, I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on the continuing scrutiny of pollution of the River Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment is charged by the Senate to maintain a continuing scrutiny of the problems of pollution and under this general reference the Committee, since March 1979, has been examining action taken to control pollution of the River Murray and to manage the adjacent environment. During its examinations the Committee has placed particular emphasis on the need for co-ordinated management of the River Murray. The report that Senator Collard has just tabled dealing with the problems caused by low flow in the River Murray and the closure of the Murray mouth is the third report that the Committee has made to the Senate dealing with the problems of the River Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that on 30 April 1981 there was a complete closure of the mouth of the River Murray at Goolwa. This event aroused considerable interest, particularly in South Australia, and a number of adverse consequences were feared-in particular, that the sea would break through the Sir Richard Peninsula and contaminate the terminal lakes and the River Murray and that the high salinities in the Corrong could not be diluted by an inflow of water of lower salinity from the Southern Ocean. Evidence given to the Committee indicated that the closure of the mouth of the River Murray is not a particularly unexpected event in view of the conditions applying at the time, namely: No river flow for some 200 days; a long period of calm weather with the beach well built up; and a period of very small neap tides for a week or so preceding the actual closure.

Evidence given to the Committee indicates that it is extremely unlikely that the sea would break through the coastal dunes and bypass the Goolwa barrage. However, in this regard it is important to stress that the condition of the coastal dunes must be maintained and the Committee has drawn attention to the problems caused by off-road vehicle traffic. The South Australian Government is well aware of these problems and has been considering more stringent controls on off-road vehicles for some time. In the report the Committee has suggested that these be introduced as soon as possible. Following heavy rain, the opening of the Goolwa barrages and the cutting of a channel by the South Australian Engineering and Water Supply Department, the mouth of the Murray was reopened on 16 July 1981.

The Committee has drawn attention in the report to the pressing need for a co-ordinated approach to the problems of the River Murray and has reiterated its previous recommendation that the River Murray Commission be empowered to administer a co-ordinated strategy for dealing with the River Murray. The Committee has also recommended that the Commonwealth and the States should consider the establishment of a national body to determine water quality standards and to set guidelines with respect to the future development along all Australian river systems. The Committee welcomes the recent amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement giving powers to the River Murray Commission in respect of water quality. However, the Committee has again restated its view that the agreement does not go far enough. What is still lacking is a co-ordinated and effective implementation of the technical solutions to the problems of the River Murray. The Committee has drawn attention to the incredibly protracted process by which amendments were agreed to. The process commenced in March 1973 with a meeting between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the three Premiers, with final agreement being reached in October 1981-a period of over eight years and which makes changes in the decision making process quite imperative. The Committee notes with interest that the new agreement will enable account to be taken of the quality of tributary inflows and man-made outflows in determining the entitlements of each State to Rivery Murray water. However, the rules by which such a system would operate have yet to be developed and agreed to. The Committee would hope that such a vital element for river management will be agreed to without delay.

Finally, the Committee welcomes the recognition by the Commonwealth and the States that improved irrigation techniques are a vital element in combating salinity and drainage problems and that a Commonwealth-State working party has been set up to look at possible future incentives to hasten the introduction of improved techniques. In this regard the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth give immediate consideration to providing additional finance to the States for such purposes.
