PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Evans) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution in relation to the duration of the House of Representatives, the holding of elections for the Senate and House of Representatives, disagreement between the Houses with respect to proposed laws and the appointment, and the termination of the appointment, of Ministers of State, to be cited as the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- (5.22)-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Problem

Six years ago today the Whitlam Government was dismissed from office and forced to a premature election by the then Governor-General, following the failure of the Opposition-dominated Senate to pass the annual Appropriation Bills. The 1975 constitutional crisis was undoubtedly one of the most traumatic events in Australia's political history, with the community deeply divided-not always on strict party lines-as to the legitimacy of what occurred. A legacy of bitterness was created by the actions of the Senate and the intervention of the Governor-General which still shows little sign of dissipation. Perhaps even more importantly, an institutional legacy was also clearly established by the events of 1974 and 1975, whereby no government lacking a secure majority in the Senate can any longer look forward to seeing out its full term. If an opposition see it as politically advantageous to use them, the weapons are ready to hand every six months with the recurring Supply and Appropriation Bills. The potential for instability inherent in the letter of the Australian Constitution has at last been fully realised.

Since 1975 nothing has changed. The Constitution has not been amended in any relevant respect. It remains within the power of the Senate to block Supply and within the power of the Governor-General to dismiss governments retaining the confidence of the House of Representatives and to dissolve the Parliament. Moreover, since 1 July this year the practical preconditions for the exercise of these powers have once again been created, with the Government's loss of control of the Senate. Until now the new Senate has exercised its power in a cautious and principled way, with neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Australian Democrats being willing to block in any way the passage of those money Bills crucial to the survival of any government in office, or to interfere with those measures for which the Government could reasonably claim a mandate. But nor have the Opposition parties, which with Senator Harradine constitute a clear cut 33-31 majority in this chamber, been inhibited in forcing major changes to measures-such as sales tax, social security and tertiary fees-in respect of which the Government may not be able to claim an explicit electoral justification, but which are undoubtedly important to its overall governing strategy. Nor can it be assumed that, as parties, personalities and the political environment change, the present non-Government parties will always maintain their absolutist opposition to using their greatest weapon. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Country Party may yet reap the whirlwind they have themselves sown.
The Whitlam and Court Solutions

Most of the debate so far about amending the Constitution to avoid a repetition of the events of 1975 has centred around the two more or less extreme solutions which have been championed respectively by Mr Whitlam on behalf of the ALP and Sir Charles Court on behalf of the Liberal and National Country parties at meetings of the Australian Constitutional Convention. The Whitlam solution is simply, without more, to remove from section 53 of the Constitution any power of the Senate to reject or 'in any other manner block' money Bills. The Court solution, on the other hand, would confirm and institutionalise the Senate's existing stranglehold over the House of Representatives by requiring an automatic double dissolution, without vice-regal intervention, in the event that the Senate failed to pass a Bill 'appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government' within 30 days.

When these propositions were debated at the Perth Constitutional Convention in July 1978, the Court proposal was adopted following a close division on party lines. Standing Committee D of the Convention has subsequently given the Court proposal detailed drafting consideration, but, given the record of abject failure of referendum proposals that have failed to secure a significant measure of cross-party support, it remains unlikely that it will ever be put to referendum. Equally it must be acknowledged that the Whitlam proposal, were it to be put to referendum in the reasonably foreseeable future, would probably not have a much greater chance of success.
The Fixed Term Parliament Solution

If we are to have some sane resolution of a constitutional situation which has been acknowledged on both sides of politics to be manifestly unsatisfactory, and which is likely to blow up again at any time, it is evident that a search has to be made for an amendment formula which is acceptable, albeit perhaps as a second best, to everyone. A solution has to be found, the acceptance of which by either side of politics does not involve either a confession of past error or loss of present face, and the implementation of which offers advantages for both sides.

It is in this spirit that the proposal for a constitutional amendment to implement a system of fixed term parliaments has been developed, written and talked about by a number of people over the last two years. For example, I refer to the article by Geoffrey Lindell entitled 'Fixed Term Parliaments: The Proposed Demise of the Early Federal Election', in Australian Quarterly of autumn 1981 and the references to the work of Dean Jaensch and others cited therein. It is in that spirit that the proposal is now advanced by me on behalf of the Australian Labor Party in this private member's Bill. Although there are many possible variations of detail when one gets down to questions of actual implementation of the fixed term concept, the essence of the fixed term proposal for me, and for almost everyone else who has supported the concept, is this: The government of the day, so long as it retains the confidence of the House of Representatives, is guaranteed its full term of office and cannot be forced against its will to an early election, by a hostile Senate or anyone else, but in return for that security the government loses the power to manipulate election dates to suit its own political advantage.
Advantages of Fixed Terms

A system of fixed term parliaments or, to be more precise, fixed House of Representatives terms-since Senate terms, of course, have always been fixed-has a number of distinct advantages, quite apart from its impact on relations between the two Houses. Most obviously, it creates a stable political environment in which governments could plan and execute policy in a more coherent and systematic way than they seem able to at the moment.

Regularly recurring cycles make all forms of planning, and especially forward budgetary programming, much easier. The advantages of stability are not necessarily confined to governments, as Professor Colin Howard pointed out in his paper to the 1981 Australasian Study of Parliament Group workshop on fixed term parliaments, oppositions should be better able to prepare and present policies of greater depth and durability than tends to be the case when baskets of electoral ammunition have to be kept ready to hand at all times against the threat of a snap election. Also from an Opposition viewpoint, the introduction of a fixed term system would of course remove one of the major advantages of incumbency, the ability of a government to bring on an election at a time of its own choosing. Governments will always have more means available to them than oppositions to manipulate a favourable electoral climate, but fixed term parliaments at least do something to even the race.

From another perspective entirely, fixed term parliaments have the advantage of removing from the unelected office of Governor-General much of the discretionary power to dismiss and dissolve now vested in it, which power in recent years has necessarily tended-with unhappy results of which we are all aware-to politicise that office. Again, to the extent that this is an advantage-and I suggest it is seen as such by most Australians who regard themselves as having something of a surfeit of electoral democracy-fixed term parliaments would be likely to result in a reduction in the number of elections held over any given 10 to 15 year period. But important as all these considerations are, the central and overriding advantage of the fixed term concept is simply that, as a possible solution to the constitutional problems of 1975, it is really, as an American might say, 'the only game in town'. It is not only a principled solution to the problem of 1975, but it is also a politically more realistic solution, simply because it does involve significant elements of trade-off or compromise in a way that the Court and Whitlam proposals, and others like them, do not.

On the one hand, the government of the day is, for all practical purposes, guaranteed a full term notwithstanding the existence of a hostile Senate: The constitutional possibility of there being an early election means that, even in the absence of any direct amendment of the Senate's powers under section 53-and it may be a matter of argument as to whether there needs to be such an amendment-there would simply be no point in the Senate blocking Supply. The resulting chaos if it did would be seen as all the Senate's own work, and there would be no possibility of political rescue by the Governor-General from an unpopular position, as occurred in 1975. What the Whitlam proposal sought to do directly, the fixed term parliaments proposal does very indirectly: The limitation on the Senate's powers of life and death over the properly elected government is a corollary of a major institutional change having a number of advantages in its own right, rather than itself being the be all and end all of the change. As I have said elsewhere, fixed term parliaments offer a way of clambering round the Senate obstacle without actually dynamiting it out of existence. And whereas the sole beneficiary of the Whitlam proposal was the government of the day, whichever it was, the fixed term parliament proposal does have an obvious countervailing advantage for oppositions in the removal of the government's power to fix election dates.
Possible Disadvantages

Are there any major and obvious disadvantages of the fixed term concept which should be stated at this stage and weighed in the balance? I refer here to objections of a general kind, and not to criticisms of matters of detail going to the mode of implementation of the concept, which I will outline below and about which there are bound to be differing views which in turn may or may not be able to be accommodated at the Committee stage of this debate. The likely second reading type objections fall into four categories.

In the first place, of course, there will be those who argue that there is simply no problem inherent in the present balance between the two Houses, in the overriding discretionary powers vested in the Governor-General, and in the way those various powers were exercised in 1974 and 1975. As to this, it is perhaps sufficient to say that the Bill is premised on the assumption that there is a problem, one that is likely to recur in future for both sides of politics, and one which both sides genuinely want to solve. Even Sir Charles Court's resolution was premised, it will be recalled, on the necessity-or at least desirability, so it was argued-of removing the Governor-General's independent discretionary power in the event of another Supply crisis.

A second objection, put for example by Senator Lewis at the Australasian Study of Parliament Group workshop on fixed term parliaments last August, to which I have already referred, is that while the fixed term system might work well enough now, it will break down in the event that clear and stable majorities in the House of Representatives cease to become the norm in future, for example, as a consequence of the introduction of proportional representation. Is it not the case, the argument goes, that in this situation-or indeed even now in the event of a party split or a series of by-election defeats-it may often happen that no government can command a sustained vote of confidence, and does not this mean there is then the possibility that, as Senator Lewis put it, 'the nation could have suffered irreparable damage while a government thrashed about aimlessly but secure in the knowledge that nothing could force it to the polls'? Assuming for the sake of argument-but not conceding-that the possibility of greater fragmentation in the House of Representatives is a real one, much of the answer to this kind of objection depends on how the 'no confidence' provisions in the scheme are drafted: If, as is provided in the present Bill, an extraordinary early election can, and indeed must, be called in the event that a government loses a no confidence resolution and no alternative government is able to secure the confidence of the House within seven days, this will cover the great majority of the situations that in practice may arise.

The only situation it will not cover is the stalemate which may arise where those members holding the balance of power will not support the government in its legislative program, but at the same time will not join in a motion of no confidence. It ultimately becomes a matter for judgment whether the political dynamics and pressures that are likely to operate in the real world, and which will undoubtedly encourage pivotal members not to create chaos for its own sake, are such as to make this a real threat to the viability of the system. I do not think it will be, and I am reinforced in that position by a number of commentators, including Professors Sawer and Howard, who have argued that the problem of minority governments will essentially look after itself and that there should be no 'confidence' exception at all to the fixed term rule.

A third general objection is that the fixed term concept, by its very nature, rules out the possibility of a government with a very slender and fragile majority seeking an early renewal of its electoral mandate. Assuming that no government would want to debase itself by passing a 'technical' motion of no confidence in itself, or at least assuming that no government would want to be the first to establish the precedent, this consequence does follow. Again it is a matter of weighing the relative importance of this contingency against the variety of real and present problems which the introduction of fixed term parliaments would solve.

The fourth general objection likely to be made is that the fixed term concept does not travel well. It may be appropriate to the United States, with its quite different presidential system of government, and to Norway and Spain-the only other two countries which, on Inter-Parliamentary Union data, have absolutely indissoluble parliaments-but, it will be said, it is not at all appropriate to Westminster systems of government like our own, where the Executive owes its existence to the legislature, and where there are a mass of conventions governing the relationship. Senator Lewis, in his ASPG workshop paper, has put it thus:

I am cautious about attempting to graft onto our Constitution an alien provision, derived from the constitution of another country. How can it be done without adopting the history, the mores, the checks and balances, and the conventions of the nation from which the concept has come?

The short answer to this is that no other country appears to have our peculiar combination of Westminster and federal government, with two equally powerful Houses. Our founding fathers were well enough aware that in vesting the Senate with the powers they did-equal in nearly every respect to those of the Representatives-they were building in an inherent inconsistency between the principles of responsible government and of federal bicameralism.

How exactly a government could be responsible to two Houses simultaneously, each of which was elected on an entirely different basis and was likely to divide on different lines, was a problem they left to future generations to solve. Essentially, they just hoped that good sense would prevail, and the problem would simply go away-and for 74 years that is exactly what happened. But now it is necessary for us to resolve the problem and, being an unusual problem-one that simply does not arise in Westminster systems elsewhere-it demands a specially tailored solution. It may be that other possible solutions to the problem are neater and cleaner-for example, the ALP policy, to which I still remain committed as a longer term goal, that not only should the Senate have no power to reject or block all money Bills, but also its power over all other classes of legislation should be reduced to that of mere delay for a maximum of six months. But the task for the present is to find a middle of the road solution which has a real chance of being implemented, and I believe that the fixed term parliament solution fits that description.
The Bill

The text of the proposed amendment is necessarily somewhat long and complex, because of the range of technical matters with which it is necessary to deal, but the main elements in the Bill can be stated quite simply.
Basic Fixed Term Rule

New section 28 of the Constitution-clause 6 of the Bill-provides for a basic three-year term for the House of Representatives, with elections in future being required to be held, subject only to the two specific exceptions relating to no confidence motions and deadlocks which I will come to, on the third Saturday in November every third year, following dissolution of the Parliament on the last Thursday in October. New section 5, clause 2 of the Bill, provides that the Governor-General has no power-the no confidence and deadlock exceptions to one side-to dissolve the Parliament other than at this time; and a new section 64 of the Constitution, clause 10 of the Bill, makes it clear that the Governor-General cannot cut short the life of a government by dismissing his Ministers except upon them losing the confidence of the House. By amendments to sections 7, 9 and 13 of the Constitution-clauses 3, 4 and 5 respectively of the Bill-Senate terms are described as equivalent to two House of Representative terms, and the conditions are created for Senate elections to be always held at the same time as House of Representatives elections. Further amendments to sections 12 and 32 of the Constitution in clauses 5 and 7 of the Bill ensure that writs for House and Senate elections are issued at the proper time.

The Bill, it will be noted, is drafted specifically on the assumption that the House of Representatives term will remain its present three years, and that the Senate term will be twice that-normally six years, again as at present. There is strong argument to be made for the Representatives term to be extended to four years, following the example now being set in the States. The Bill could easily be altered to accommodate this change. It is a more familiar and easily understood change than the fixed term concept, and it might well attract strong cross-party support. The difficulty with the four year proposal, however, is that it immediately raises the question of the duration of senators' terms. The only practical alternatives are a Representatives-length four years for senators-which is my preferred solution, and likely to be that of the ALP-or eight years, twice the Representatives term, which I would regard as unacceptably long, but which seems to have many supporters within the present Parliament, particularly on the Government side. In short, it seems unlikely that a consensus can readily be reached on the extended term issue, and since this is not only logically distinct from the fixed term issue but also a substantially lower constitutional priority, it has been thought preferable for present purposes to let the present situation as to the length of the term continue.

A question arises as to whether it is necessary or desirable to specify an actual date, namely, the third Saturday in November, as the ordinary due date for elections, particularly since the choice of any particular date, however much in accordance with precedent and however conveniently it may fit the annual Budget cycle, is likely to excite a degree of controversy. Technically it is not necessary to specify any particular date; it could simply be provided that the next election date should be no more, or less, than three years after the last, but this creates the possibility that, in the event of a double dissolution occurring at an odd or difficult time of the year, for example, January, or Easter, or in Budget month, the Parliament would thereafter-or at least until the next double dissolution-be locked into an awkward electoral cycle. It was also felt desirable to introduce-as an extra disincentive to extraordinary elections-as much certainty, regularity and familiarity into the election cycle as humanly possible. As will be seen below, the difficulty in restoring a November election date cycle even after an extraordinary dissolution is easily overcome.

If the objection to any particular date being set is that some disaster may intrude to make it in fact impossible to hold the election on that date, one can only reply that the Americans seem to have been lucky in this respect now for nearly 200 years in the dates of their Presidential elections. In the event, however, that some spectacular hazard did make polling impossible, no doubt the courts would find it possible to beat off any vexatious litigant claiming the nullity of an election held on the closest possible alternative date; it should not be impossible for the courts legally to come up with some application of the principle lex non cogit ad impossibilia, or in English, the law does not compel the impossible.
First Exception: No Confidence Resolution

Section 5-clause 6-provides for the House to be dissolved in the event that a formal resolution of no confidence, of which at least 24 hours notice has to be given, is passed against the Government, and that there is no further resolution passed by the House within 7 days expressing confidence in an alternative Ministry. The House is expressly required to meet within seven days, if it is not otherwise scheduled to do so, in order that this confidence question can be tested. By virtue of new sections 13 and 28, an election must be held for the Representatives-and half the Senate-four weeks after the dissolution.

It should be noted that there is no obligation imposed upon the government to resign immediately upon the passage of such a no confidence motion; its obligation to do so, on pain of dismissal under the new section 64 if it does not, arises only after a motion of confidence has been carried in an alternative Ministry. In the event that no alternative government can be formed in this way, the defeated government will remain in office during the election period. In the event that the government does resign after the passage of a no confidence motion, the Governor-General is free to appoint an alternative Ministry but he must, under the new section 5, dissolve the Parliament in the event that that new government does not secure the confidence of the House.

There is no specific provision made to cover the situation where a Prime Minister or one or more of his Ministers simply resigns without there having been a no confidence resolution passed. By virtue of section 64, the Governor-General would simply act to fill the gaps, and his judgment would then be subject to testing in the ordinary way by the no confidence provisions.

The loss of confidence provisions outlined here have been drafted to cover a situation which, it seems generally agreed, should amount to an exception to the fixed term rule, albeit that changes of allegiance in the lower House have not forced a single election since Federation, and that it is unlikely that they will be any more common in the reasonably foreseeable future. It has been suggested by some that it may be possible to use the section 5 no confidence dissolution procedure to drive a coach and horses through the whole fixed term concept, the argument being that all the Government has to do to bring on an early election at a time of its own choosing, is to arrange for a so-called 'technical' no confidence motion to be passed by its supporters in the House of Representatives. All one cay say to this is that while it remains a theoretical possibility, it is very difficult to see it being applied-at least for the first time-in practice. A government which is seen to be willing to express no confidence in itself is going to have a lot of difficulty plausibly claiming the confidence of the electors.

Even if it could live with this potential embarrassment, for a government to act in the manner suggested would be a flagrant breach of the spirit of the new provisions, and it could be expected to incur a good deal of wrath from the media and other opinion leaders if it tried it on.
Second Exception: Senate Deadlock

It is proposed that the other-and only other-circumstance enabling an early election to be called in breach of the basic fixed term rule, should be the case of a sustained deadlock between the two Houses, which the government in the House of Representatives chooses to break by advising a double dissolution. The main reason for preserving this possibility is to give the House of Representatives some weaponry with which to fight an Opposition-dominated Senate bent on destroying, delaying or emasculating its legislative program. It is a matter for judgment as to just how significant a weapon the threat of a double dissolution is these days. Much obviously depends on the political circumstances prevailing at the time, and it is difficult to usefully generalise.

It should be noted that in the Bill, as it is drafted, the Senate's opportunities for harrassing the government are significantly limited. The proposed new section 53-clause 8 of the Bill-removes the right of the Senate to hold up for more than one month the passage of any money Bill, including the annual Supply and Appropriation Bills. Largely this merely formalises what would happen anyway under the basic fixed term rule, since if a Senate simply cannot force an early election upon the House against its will there would be no political advantage-and in fact a good deal of disadvantage-in its creating a Supply crisis. It is true that with section 53 amended in this way there is also no point in an Opposition building up a 'stockpile' of twice rejected Bills, which it can then-as happened in 1974 and 1975-demand the government use, in the context of a supply crisis, as a vehicle for calling an early election. This removes a little of the room for manoeuvre which the Senate would have otherwise retained, but is unlikely in practice-with governments being much more cautious about creating stockpiles in the future than they were in the past-to have amounted to much of an advantage. In any event, with section 53 amended in this way it is appropriate to remove money Bills altogether from the ambit of section 57, and the Bill-clause 9-does just that.

A more significant and far reaching change to section 57 is the incorporation in it of the recommendations of the all-party 1959 Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. The main change is the addition of an alternative option for a government when its legislation fails to pass the Senate after successive presentations three months apart. Under the new section 57 the government of the day will have the option of advising either a double dissolution, as at present, or a joint sitting in lieu thereof. This is consistent with the general policy of the Bill, which is to insist so far as possible on the fixed term principle being maintained, and to ensure that extraordinary elections are kept to an absolute minimum. Although first appearances are perhaps to the contrary, this new option has some advantages from the Senate point of view to the extent that it means that the Senate does not necessarily risk an election, as it does at the moment, by maintaining its objections to a Bill for longer than three months.
Restoring the Election Cycle after an Extraordinary Dissolution

With the possibility thus created, under sections 5 and 57, for extraordinary elections to be held before the ordinary three year term has expired, it is necessary to make some provision to ensure not only that House and Senate elections occur simultaneously-accomplished by new sections 9, 12 and 13-but also that the ordinary election cycle is restored as soon as possible. One alternative would be, at least in the case of a section 5 dissolution of the House of Representatives, simply to provide for the incoming government to see out what was left of the term of its predecessor, and then for another election to be held at the due date in the normal way. The main difficulty with this is that it creates the possibility of elections being held very closely together-perhaps as little as a month apart-and that it is one of the objects of the fixed term parliament amendment to avoid the expense and inconvenience of elections which are not, on any view of democratic principles, absolutely necessary.

This difficulty could in turn be solved by fixing some band of time-say three months prior to the ordinary election date in November-whereby if an extraordinary election were held during this time it would be unnecessary to hold a further election on the ordinary due date.

The Bill in fact adopts a variation of the last mentioned proposal. Section 28, clause 6, provides in essence that if an extraordinary election is held within a period six months prior to the ordinary election date in any year, then the term runs for three plus years, for example until the ordinary date three Novembers hence, whereas if the extraordinary election occurs within six months following the ordinary November date in any year, then the term runs for three minus years-for example until the ordinary date three Novembers hence. Thus, for example, assuming an election is due in the ordinary course in November 1983, an extraordinary election occurring anywhere between June 1981 and May 1982-for example six months either side of the closest 'ordinary date', November 1981-would require the next election to be held in November 1984.
Conclusion

This Bill grapples with problems of great complexity, but it is difficult to overstate their constitutional importance. If the Bill is passed by this Parliament and then by the Australian people in a referendum, it will amount to probably the most far-reaching change to our constitutional arrangements since Federation. It is perhaps easy under these circumstances to dismiss the Bill as essentially some kind of academic pipe-dream with no ultimate chance of attracting the broad cross-party support which we know to be a necessary-if not sufficient-condition of securing constitutional reform.

But I remain reasonably confident that when its implications are fully absorbed and understood-and even more importantly when the alternatives are considered-a new fixed term parliament system will be seen by most members and senators as the only presently realistic solution to the institutional problems inherent in our present Constitution.

To ensure that the terms of the Bill are fully understood, and that there is ample time for reaction to flow back in not only from politicians and other parties but also from the community at large, it is proposed to defer debate on this Bill until early in the Autumn session next year. If significant reform is to be achieved the process of building consensus must be followed out, however laborious and frustrating for all concerned it may be. I simply express the hope that in the debate which will arise we all resist the temptation to engage in cheap and easy political point scoring, and approach the exercise in a co-operative and constructive spirit. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As extracts from a paper I gave at a workshop conducted by the Australasian Study of Parliament Group earlier this year have been quoted by Senator Evans in his second reading speech I think it might be a helpful contribution to the debate to have the full text of that paper incorporated in Hansard. Accordingly, I seek leave to have it incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALASIAN STUDY OF PARLIAMENT GROUP
THIRD ANNUAL WORKSHOP
FIXED-TERM PARLIAMENTS
General Paper by Senator Austin Lewis
''Liberty has never come from the government . . .''
Woodrow Wilson

1. The current enthusiasm for the concept of a ''fixed term'' for the House of Representatives appears to be related directly to the events of 1974-75 and the sudden interest then in the constitutional powers of the Senate over all Bills, but particularly over money bills-an interest which was minimal on the occasion of the 1974 double dissolution but which erupted in 1975 into what has so often, then and still, been described, in accordance with the modern ''headline catching'' manner, as a ''constitutional crisis''.

2. The background papers (and Professor Howard's previous papers) tend to comment at length (in what is known as a ''single issue'' fashion) on the subject of the Senate and its powers. The fixed term proposal is taken as having, as its starting point, the desirability of establishing a back door method of ensuring that the Senate's powers are limited, not by formal amendment (the difficulty of which is recognized, particularly in Dr Colin Hughes' paper) but by so restricting their operation that, in the words of Senator Evans, it would be more likely to be politically acceptable than a direct challenge either to affirm or deny those powers.

3. Is this a genuinely sufficient reason for introducing a fixed term system, with the problems inherent in such a system? Should the Constitution be altered just to suit the wishes of those who are preaching an anti-Senate line? We should be very wary of altering the Constitution so that it fits the current political and party set-up, which may well change in the future. A fixed term House of Representatives might be suitable for the present situation, where there are two opposing political groups with a high degree of stability, but if Australia should develop a European-type multi-party set-up or return to a 19th century instability in political allegiances (either is possible) a fixed term House of Representatives could be a nuisance; and does ''stability'', in the minds of its proponents, really mean executive domination and inviolability? A fixed term would mean that no government need fear the perils of mismanagement, corruption or incompetence as no mechanism would exist to demand an appeal to the electorate. It is immaterial whether such a government would be banished from office at the end of its term. What is of vital importance is that the nation could have suffered irreparable damage while a government thrashed about aimlessly but secure in the knowledge that nothing could force it to the polls.

4. The great authorities on the British and American Constitutions, such as Walter Bagehot on the British side and Woodrow Wilson on the American side, believed that the fact that the lower house can be dissolved at any time and the executive can appeal to the electorate is one of the great strengths of the British as against the American System. It would be foolish to abandon this feature of our Constitution without more careful consideration of its advantages.

5. There are valid reasons why a government should want to have an early election without being defeated in the lower House, apart from the desire to choose a convenient time, which many, including Senator Evans, seem to think is the only reason for governments wanting early elections.
For example:

(a) a government with a small majority may be about to make some grave change of policy, but may wish to seek the opinion of the electorate; Oppositions abuse governments for taking serious steps for which they have no electoral mandate; how are they to seek a mandate with a fixed term House of Representatives?

(b) A House of Representatives due to some party split, may harass and frustrate a government without passing a motion of no confidence, thereby preventing an election while maintaining a weak government in office; why should not a government in such a situation be able to appeal to the electorate?

6. If the majority of the House of Representatives seeks to overthrow a Government and instal another government in office, without holding an election, why should not the defeated government be able to appeal to the electorate to test the opinion of the country on the change? There are good grounds for saying that the recent change of government in Papua New Guinea, for example, was undemocratic in that the electorate did not have the opportunity of endorsing the new government.

7. Many astute modern politicians, for example, Mr Norman St John-Stevas, a former Leader of the House of Commons, in his introduction to the collected works of Bagehot, have declared that the supposed hold which a Prime Minister has over his followers by the threat of an early election is illusory.

8. There may be good reasons for postponing or bringing forward an election, particularly to avoid holding an election during some grave crisis. It has been well pointed out that the Americans have been extremely lucky that their presidential elections have not fallen due at times of grave crisis; for example, if President Lincoln had been elected a year later or had had to stand for re-election a year earlier the secession of the Southern States would have succeeded. What if the British had been forced by a written Constitution to hold an election in the summer of 1940 (during the Blitz)?

9. There is no guarantee that a House of Representatives with a fixed term would provide a more effective check and scrutiny of the executive than does the present House. To the contrary, a very respectable argument could be made out that the combination of party discipline and the 'unavoidability' or inevitability of electoral events might well produce an even more stagnant chamber, with an entrenched executive free from any real influence.

10. Perhaps some real consideration should be given to the proposition that the present non-fixed term of whatever length (most commonly described as a choice between 3 and 4 years) is perhaps not as bad as some fixed term proponents claim. Perhaps, also, with the passage of time, some consideration should be given to the proposition that, in the Australian federal system-and this should be stressed, as the Australian Federal Parliament is not directly comparable with any other legislature-the checks and balances provided within the Constitution worked as they should in both 1974 and 1975. But the argument that a constitutional crisis occurred in 1975 has become part of the received wisdom of political debate. May I suggest for serious analysis that, on the contrary, constitutional safeguards operated as they should in 1975?

Much has been made of the partisan role of the Senate and the Governor-General at that time. Are we to suggest, though, that party played no part in the House of Representatives? Let us speculate for a moment whether there might have been a disaffected group of Government members in the Lower House. What option was open to them in a Parliamentary system? Would it have been possible, under Constitutional conventions and practices governing the conduct of the House of Representatives in Australia, to vote against their Leader on the floor of the House, or against a significant measure introduced by the Government of the day? And let us try to be realistic-is it conceivable that members who are totally dissatisfied with their Leader would vote to bring about an election at a time when their own seats would be in greatest jeopardy?

I do not pretend to be describing what might have been happening at the time: I merely suggest that the enormous concentration on conventions supposedly applicable to the two other constituent parts of Parliament has ensured that consideration of conventions applicable to the third component-the House of Representatives-has been studiously ignored.

In this same vein, the assumption that in 1975 the Governor-General was 'final arbiter' in dismissing a constitutionally elected government may also be challenged. Is it not reasonable to suggest that his action ensured that the electors-surely, within a parliamentary democracy, the absolute arbiters between competing contenders for governmental power-were, by the so-called 'arbitrary' action of the Governor-General, permitted to cast the final judgment? No clear solution has occurred to many people since those events, other than (a) abolition of Senate powers and, consequently, (b) absolute domination and freedom of executive action.

11. It is interesting to look at the situation in the United States. Watergate occurred in June 1972. Nixon resigned in August 1974, but the people did not get a chance to vote out his successor until November 1976, and President Carter did not take office until January 1977-4 1/2 years after Watergate.

Of course, there has always been criticism of the fixed term in the United States, but in the wake of Watergate and the rising concern about world events there has been a resurgence of that criticism. So while we are debating the merits of fixed terms, they are debating the merits of flexible election dates.

12. So far as the length of Parliamentary terms is concerned, it is worth pointing out, as a matter of historical interest, that despite the constraints perceived in the present 3-year term, only once in the history of the Australian Federal system has the House of Representatives been dissolved ''by effluxion of time'', in accordance with section 5 of the Constitution. Only on very few occasions has the House of Representatives lasted for three years from the date of the previous election: in fact, the average ''life'' of a House of Representatives since 1901 has been about 2 1/2 years.

I note that Senator Evans puts forward the view that, if the term of the House of Representatives is extended to four years, a four-year term for Senators is the best available option, on the ground that a term longer than 6 years-the only reasonable alternative under a 4-year Parliamentary system- would make Senators less accountable to both party and people.

Serious consideration needs to be given, however, to preserving the continuity of the Senate itself-as distinct from the length of Senators' terms. Let me put to you an unashamedly biased Senate view on the implication, contained in Senator Evans' paper, that all Senators should be elected together at the same time as Members of the House of Representatives.

My view is that the Parliament-as an institution-has previously maintained whatever support it has (however little that may unfortunately be) through the activities of the Senate and, in particular, its Committees-and that those few favourable concepts that exist in the perhaps mythical ''public mind'' owe much to the scrutiny, the critical and constructive roles, which flow from a popularly elected proportionately-representative, independent House, where the members have a sufficiently long term to develop and pursue interests, and the chamber itself has a continuing existence, largely unfettered by government domination. The most simple example of such benefits is in the capacity for the Senate's Committees to get on with the job ''notwithstanding any prorogation or dissolution of the House of Representatives''. The alternative of ''shutting up shop'' to suit the convenience of the government of the day is not one that appeals.

13. If Parliament is to survive, let alone prosper, it must maintain its independence. A lack of capacity in the Houses to express freedom of action-whether by overturning governments or otherwise-restricts the effectiveness of the people's representatives. It places them more and more under the yolk of executive domination. I suggest that we should consider whether the fixed term proposal would go any distance towards giving the Parliament independence. I am cautious about attempting to graft on to our Constitution an alien provision, derived from the Constitution of another country. How can it be done without adopting the history, the mores, the checks and balances, and the conventions, of the nation from which the concept has come?

In your determination to ensure that the events of 1975 never happen again, you are prepared to guarantee an elected government a term of 4 years, regardless of its behaviour. I do not see that as in any way advancing the freedom of the people-the Americans knew about the tyranny of government, and look at the safeguards in their Constitution, which we do not have. Let me quote to you something from Woodrow Wilson:
''Liberty has never come from the government . . . The history of liberty is the history of the limitation of governmental power, not the increase of it.''

SPEECH.PARA: That the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302 and made under the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976, be disallowed.

I want to put a couple of questions. Is it possible to defer paying tax for five months and then receive indefinitely an effective 23 3/4 per cent interest rate on a deposit in a government trust account? Is it possible to defer paying a $30,000 tax bill for three years by depositing $50,000 in a trust account for one year on which the depositor gets almost $5,000 in interest and evades forever a $4,000 tax bill? The answer to both those questions is yes, if a person has an off-farm income of $35,000 or above and substantial farming interests. Well-known groups of people who fit into that category are Cabinet Ministers and other Pitt Street farmers. This tax haven is not a function of previously unrecognised loopholes or of bizarre High Court judgments in favour of tax dodgers. The tax haven which I have outlined is the product of a series of deliberate government decisions, the last of which was contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302 which I have moved to disallow. The actual motion is that the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations (Amendments), as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302 and made under the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976, be disallowed.

Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302 increases from 7 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent the interest rate payable on funds lodged in a trust account known as income equalisation deposits. Superficially it seems quite reasonable that interest should be increased from 7 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent. Because that seems, superficially, reasonable the Government thought it could get away with the serious extension of a pre-existing tax haven. It is reasonable until one discovers that the deposit is deductible from taxable income. In fact, it can be deducted from taxable income before it is actually made. If one is one of the privileged people who qualify for participation in this tax haven one gets 9 1/2 per cent on one's money. One also gets 9 1/2 per cent on the taxpayers' money-on money that would otherwise have been paid in tax if the deposit was not made. If one is wealthy-that is, if one has an income of above $35,000-one can deposit $100 in an income equalisation deposit, which is, I stress, a trust account, a gilt-edged government security. By paying that $100 into the trust account, one's taxable income is reduced by $100 and the tax that one has to pay is reduced by $60. So, in effect, one deposits $60 of the taxpayers' money and $40 of one's own money. On that $40 one gets $9.50 interest every year, which, on the $40, is a rate of 23.75 per cent.

If it is hard to understand what I have just outlined and why this is a tax haven-a rort-imagine capital being subscribed to a company on a new share issue or on share purchases being fully deductible from taxable income five months before the share purchase is made. That is precisely what we are talking about here. We are talking about an investment like buying shares which is totally deductible from taxable income and may be deducted five months before the share purchase is made. Imagine subscriptions to government loans being deductible in advance from taxable income. Would anyone suggest anything so ludicrous as to make subscriptions to any old government loan fully deductible from taxable income and still attracting very close to the present rate of interest?

Among several spurious arguments circulated today by the National Farmers Federation is the argument that the interest paid is, itself, taxable. That, according to the National Farmers Federation, demonstrates that there is no rort or anomaly involved. Sure, the interest paid on the deposit is deductible. So is the interest paid on government loans, on savings bank accounts, or fixed deposits, and on building society accounts, and so it ought to be.

Is it possible to defer paying tax for five months and then to receive, for an indefinite period, an effective interest rate of 23 3/4 per cent on a deposit in a government trust account-a gilt-edged government security indistinguishable from a Commonwealth bond? Is it also possible to defer paying a $30,000 tax bill for three years by depositing $50,000 in a trust account for one year on which almost $5,000 interest would be received and a $4,000 tax bill would be evaded forever? The answer to both those questions is yes, one has an off-farm income of $35,000 or above and substantial farming interests. Cabinet Ministers and other Pitt Street farmers are people who come readily to mind who fit into that category.

SPEECH.PARA: This tax haven is not a function of some previously unrecognised loophole in tax law, or of bizarre interpretations by the High Court in favour of tax judgments. The tax haven, which I have outlined, is the product of a series of deliberate government decisions, the last of which is contained in Statutory Rule 302. That Rule increases from 7 per cent to 9 1/2 per cent the interest rate payable on funds lodged in the trust account known as income equalisation deposits. That is superficially reasonable, given the present level of interest rates. The knowledge that it is superficially reasonable no doubt prompted the Government to believe that it could get away with what it has attempted to do. It seems reasonable until we discover that the deposit is fully deductible from taxable income. In fact, it can be deducted from provisional tax before the deposit is even made. If one is a member of the privileged group-a very small group that qualifies for this privilege-one gets 9 1/2 per cent on one's money. One gets also 9 1/2 per cent on the taxpayers' money-money which would otherwise have been paid in tax if the deposit was not made. If one is wealthy-that means if one has an income above $35,000-one can deposit $100 in an IED. That reduces one's taxable income by $100 and the tax payable by $60. So if one deposits $100 in fact $60 of it is taxpayers' money and $40 is one's own. Every year one gets $9.50 interest on the $40 which one has deposited, which gives an effective interest rate of 23 3/4 per cent. I stress the words an effective interest rate of 23 3/4 per cent.

If it is hard to understand the arithmetic behind that, just imagine capital subscribed to a company or money spent purchasing shares on the stock exchange being fully deductible from taxable income five months before the shares were bought. Imagine subscriptions to government loans being deductible in advance from taxable income. Among several spurious arguments circulated today in a letter from the National Farmers Federation is the statement that the interest paid is taxable, which of course it is and so it ought to be. But the argument goes on to imply that the fact that the interest is taxable invalidates the fact that the effective rate of interest for someone on the maximum marginal tax rate is nearly 24 per cent. It is true that the interest paid on the deposit is taxable. So is the interest paid on government loans, savings bank accounts, fixed deposits with banks and building society accounts, and so it ought to be. But the only account into which the original deposit is tax deductible is the income equalisation deposit tax account. In that letter the National Farmers Federation is attempting to equate unlike things. Resorting to that sort of spurious argument further tarnishes its credibility which has already been seriously damaged by this issue. Because of the unique provision that the deposit is tax deductible, the effective interest rate for a depositor is positively tied to his or her taxable income. The higher the income, the higher the interest rate, which is innately inequitable. The National Farmers Federation restated defence of that proposition reveals something about its priorities and concerns about which I may say more later.

Prior to the gazettal of Statutory Rule 302 the effective interest rates for a depositor who has an income above $34,500 was a very generous 17 1/2 per cent. For someone whose income was below $17,000 it was a moderate 10.3 per cent. After Statutory Rule 302 was gazetted the effective interest rate for the high income taxpayer is 23 3/4 per cent and for those who earn less than $17,000-the low income taxpayer-the effective rate is 14 per cent. Honourable senators note that the increase in the interest rate for the high income taxpayer is 6 1/4 per cent and the increase in the effective interest rate for the low income taxpayer is 3.7 per cent. This tells us something more about how unequitable this proposition is.

I do not object to paying more than a 10.3 per cent interest rate under present circumstances. What I do object to is paying the rich nearly twice the interest rate that is paid to the poor for the same deposit. I object very strongly to the creation of a tax haven, especially by a government which purports to be cracking down on tax dodging at the very same time as it is seriously exacerbating, expanding and extending a pre-existing tax haven which it has created. I object very strongly to governments creating tax havens for Pitt Street farmers, including Cabinet Ministers. Moreover, this will actually harm low income farmers or anyone whose primary interest is in agriculture. The point that the creation of tax havens actually harms those who are interested in farming was put quite lucidly by the former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr Geoff Miller, at the Agro 79 Conference in Perth in March 1979. He said:
Farmers should aim at achieving tax equity with other people in the community but not tax concessions not shared with others.

Tax concessions result in excessive entry into agriculture for the specific purpose of receiving the economic reward associated with the concession. Rural land values and the costs of other limited resources such as livestock and credit are inflated by this process.
Although individuals may benefit, the benefits of tax concessions to rural industries as a whole are likely to be negative.

This gross inequity in the present system sponsored by this Government of paying higher rates of interest to people with higher incomes is avoidable. The Industries Assistance Commission, in its original report on this matter in 1975, recommended that interest be paid on the deposit at a higher rate-incidentally, at the medium term bond rate which is currently between 12 per cent and 13 per cent-net of tax which would otherwise have been payable. Had that proposition been adopted, the effective rate of interest for all depositors would have been identical. The Government rejected that recommendation and opted for the policy of paying to the highest income depositors almost twice the rate of interest payable to the lower income depositors. I would support, and the Australian Labor Party would support, an effective rate of interest above 9 1/2 per cent if it was paid on the deposit net of tax deferred. I certainly will not support paying 23 3/4per cent to anyone, let alone help create tax havens for Pitt Street farmers and Cabinet Ministers which have been engineered by those Ministers.

I do not want to make too much of this point, but it was revealed some two years ago that the Prime Minister's wife and members of her family received, under somewhat sordid circumstances, government loans at 4 1/2 per cent. The question which arises is whether the wife of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and her relatives are currently receiving effectively 23 3/4 per cent by lending money to the Government. On two occasions-on 27 and 29 October-I sought from Senator Carrick, as the Minister representing the Prime Minister, a guarantee that people who come into the category, which includes half of the Fraser Cabinet, were not exploiting the tax haven that they had created by this decision to pay almost 24 per cent in interest. I received evasive answers from Senator Carrick at the time. Today, Senator McLaren received from Senator Carrick a further communication regarding those questions, which said that some 200,000 individuals would be eligible. Incidentally, only 12,000 have actually taken advantage of the scheme, but I will deal with that later. In response to the questions which Senator McLaren and I had asked, which were explicitly seeking a guarantee from the Prime Minister that neither he nor any of the other Ministers who are qualified to participate in, to take advantage of, or to exploit this tax haven were actually doing so, I received this reply:

. . . In addition, at meetings of Cabinet and its committees Ministers are required to disclose to their colleagues any interests which they have or which they know a member of their immediate family has, which conflict or might reasonably be thought likely to conflict with their public duty as a Minister. Ministers who disclose such interest only take part in the discussions in question . . .

The important point is that the Prime Minister is still evading the question as to whether he or any of the other Ministers clearly qualified to do so are exploiting the tax haven which they have created.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whom are the disclosures made to?

—They are made to the Prime Minister, so he said. It is not a question of whether this is disclosed to the Prime Minister; it is a question of whether it is disclosed to the public. The public is entitled to know whether Cabinet Ministers are using this as a means of tax evasion, of tax deferral, and a means of securing almost 24 per cent interest on a security which is indistinguishable, security-wise, from Commonwealth bonds.
—Surely that must be made public.

—The Prime Minister refuses to make it public. The Ministers know that they can get away with it. They know that this is a highly complex issue and they think that they can get away with it. I might add that so far they have got away with it with an effrontery that it is almost impossible not to admire. The National Farmers Federation claimed today to be concerned about the effect of the disallowance of this regulation on struggling, low income farmers. In response to that I say that if the National Farmers Federation were really concerned about the effect on low income farmers it would back the IAC recommendation that interest not be paid on the tax deferred components of these deposits. Instead, the National Farmers Federation or its predecessor opposed that IAC recommendation-an opposition re-endorsed by the National Farmers Federation today. The unfortunate but I suppose predictable fact is that most farmer organisations present the perspective of the high income farmers who, incidentally, often have large non-farm incomes and dominate the farmers' organisations. I know that there are some exceptions. I know of at least one farmer leader from Western Australia who acknowledges that this is a rort which is indefensible by any rational or reasonable person.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I refer to the degree of participation in the scheme and the degree to which this would affect those who are actually farmers. Of the 200,000-odd primary producer taxpayers who are eligible to participate in this scheme only 12,000 have actually lodged deposits. My source for that is page 33 of the last report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. I add that if Statutory Rule No. 302 is allowed to stand the number of depositors may not go up very much but I guarantee that the amount which is deposited will.

This tax haven set up by a series of Government decisions is very complex. The Government thought that the very complexity of the scheme would protect the Government from the exposure of its own infamy. This plan involves interaction between provisional tax, taxation averaging for primary producers, marginal tax rates and the rules governing the timing of deposits and their withdrawal. I will not try to explain in detail those interactions, rather I will take a couple of specific cases; for example, someone with an off-farm income of $60,000-again, a Cabinet Minister comes readily to mind-and a substantial farm income of, say, $25,000. At the end of March next year such a person could reduce by $30,000 the provisional tax assessed as payable by him on that day. In other words, he could avoid paying $30,000 in tax. To validate that action he must deposit $50,000 on or before 31 August of next year, that is, within five months. The $30,000 in tax remains unpaid tax for as long as the $50,000 remains deposited in the IED. Therefore, the break-up of the $50,000 investment is $30,000 from the rest of the taxpayers of Australia and $20,000 from the taxpayer who has the deposit.

On that deposit which, remember, includes $20,000 of the depositor's money, $4,750 is paid in interest-a rate of 23 3/4 per cent-and the deposit may be left there indefinitely. The taxpayer, or depositor, on an effective deposit of $20,000 of his own money picks up every year $4,750 in interest for as long as he cares to leave the money there and for as long as Statutory Rule 302 is not struck down by this Senate; that is, if one likes to look at it as an ongoing investment. There are other alternatives. Some one may look on it as partly an investment but primarily a means of deferring and evading taxation.

Let us take another hypothetical situation, someone with a farm income of $50,000 and $40,000 in off-farm income. On 31 March of next year such a person can reduce the provisional tax bill due for payment by him on that day by $30,000, provided that on or before the end of August of next year he deposits $50,000 in an IED. He may then withdraw that deposit on 1 December 1983, one year and one day after making it. As a result of that transaction he will receive $4,750 in interest for the one year of the deposit. The $30,000 in taxation, the payment of which was deferred as at the end of March 1982, would not be paid until 31 March 1985. In other words, the taxpayer will have borrowed $30,000 from the Government for three years and paid no interest, and will have lent $50,000 to the Government for one year and received almost $5,000 in interest.

That is not the end of it. The same taxpayer, who meets the criteria that I have stipulated, at the end of the exercise, for the three years in question, would have a total taxation bill of $132,420. If he had not manipulated his taxable income, through the use of an income equalisation deposit, the tax payable would have been $136,399. In other words, the taxpayer borrows $30,000 from the Government for three years and pays no interest, lends $50,000 to the Government for one year, gets almost $5,000 in interest, and evades forever the payment of $4,000 in taxation. The National Farmers Federation, in its letter circulated today, acknowledges that my arithmetic, in previous examples I had circulated, was correct. It said that they were extreme examples which made unrealistic assumptions, such as there being constant farm income, so I did another exercise, which again assumed high off-farm income and a fluctuating level of farm income of the type that is commonly encountered-indeed fluctuating between $20,000 and $40,000. I seek leave to incorporate a table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
