TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayer represented in the table which has just been incorporated has a farm income which varies throughout the period in question from $20,000 to $40,000 and a constant non-farm income of $40,000. Let us say that he or she puts $25,000 into an income equalisation deposit on 31 August next year and takes it out on 1 September 1984. For that 12 months, with $25,000 in the deposit, the taxpayer gets $2,375 in interest. In doing that, the taxpayer defers paying $15,000 in taxation from the end of March 1982 to the end of March 1985 and also permanently avoids paying $2,234 in tax. This is not an unrealistic example, but a very realistic one, since the National Farmers Federation wants to debate it on that level. The rewards for the taxpayer are that the taxpayer lends $25,000 to the Government for one year and gets $2,375 in interest; the taxpayer borrows $15,000 from the Government for three years, pays no interest at all and evades forever $2,234 in tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation also claimed in today's letter that my examples were dependent on:
. . . primary producers continually receiving farm income levels at the highest marginal tax rate . . .

That is just factually wrong. They depend upon no such thing. They depend upon a high level of income being maintained whether or not it is farm income. I have cited a not atypical case; indeed, it is a case which would go very close to fitting precisely half the Federal Cabinet. With those sort of rewards, does anyone believe that Pitt Street farmers will not gobble up such a proposition, especially if other avenues for tax avoidance are closed off? Will many new Pitt Street farmers not do exactly what Geoff Miller said they would do-I have already quoted that view-to, I stress, the disadvantage of all bona fide farmers who want to remain farmers? The small farmers in particular, who do not use IEDs anyway, will become hurt by that process.

The National Farmers Federation in its letter said that it knows of nobody manipulating IEDs to avoid tax by destabilising taxable incomes. Incidentally, I note that the tax reward for destabilising taxable income utterly contradicts the very reason for the existence of income equalisation deposits which is supposed to be to smooth out fluctuations in taxable income. There may not have been many doing it up to now, but with 24 per cent interest going for a deposit as well as all the other incentives that were previously available, one would have to be very naive to believe that it will not be exploited in the future.

To stop that exploitation, that ripping off of the taxpayers, that undesirable encouragement of off-farm capital into agriculture, it is essential to disallow this regulation, which is the last of a series of regulations and rules that an incompetent or malevolent government has introduced. The Senate cannot correct all of those past mistakes but it can stop this latest and most serious extension of a government-created tax haven. As in so many other cases with this Government, what is displayed here is gross incompetence, inequity and a stench of corruption. Are the Ministers who made these rules actually exploiting them? I have absolutely no doubt that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) is as disgusted by this statutory regulation and the things which preceded it as I am.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh continues to make statements imputing all sorts of things about other people for which he has no substantiation. I think we should ignore that part of his speech and address ourselves to the matter that is before the Senate. Perhaps we ought to begin by asking whether Senator Walsh speaks for the Australian Labor Party, or are we to look at the statements of those who represent certain areas of interest as spokesmen for the Labor Party? Senator Walsh shows a continuing capacity to ignore the policy of his own party and places his colleagues in a difficult and embarrassing position. I think it will be of interest to some of his colleagues on the front bench and those in his party who have an interest in primary industry matters to read what he said tonight about the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme. I understood that the Australian Labor Party supported the policy of the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme. I heard from Senator Walsh tonight how he would like to see the scheme implemented and the changes that he wishes to make. He referred to the Industries Assistance Commission recommendation with regard to it. I wonder whether he was stating Labor Party policy in the speech that he just gave?

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the statement on 19 August of the Australian Labor Party spokesman on primary industry, Mr John Kerin, we find that he welcomed the general economic approach of the Government in the Budget. He made certain comments regarding the Budget's effect on the rural sector. He welcomed the general economic approach of the Government and he further said that primary producers would welcome the Government's continued approach of fighting inflation. I think that that was a fairly sensible approach to his area of responsiblity. In criticism of the Budget, however-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about the question?
—Just listen to what the spokesman for primary industry said. Apparently the honourable senator does not know.
—You don't want to talk about that because you know it is indefensible.

— The honourable senator has made his speech. I will make mine. When Mr Kerin was making a speech on this subject for the Australian Labor Party he said that he had hoped that the Government would have lifted the interest paid on income equalisation deposits.
—For the lower income group.

— He did not say for the lower income earners. He said he hoped that the Government would lift the interest paid on income equalisation deposits. Mr Kerin made that statement on behalf of the Labor Party. It was his Budget statement. Perhaps we ought to say that this is precisely what the Government has done. It has lifted the interest rate that is paid on income equalisation deposits; it has done the very thing that was suggested by the spokesman on primary industry for the Labor Party. We ought to look then at why the Government has increased the interest rates payable on these deposits. Perhaps some background ought to be given. Senator Walsh traversed some of the background to the introduction of this scheme. It was introduced by the Government in the 1976-77 Budget. It was one of a number of initiatives taken for the benefit of the rural sector. Under the scheme-I think some of these facts are known quite widely-eligible primary producers can obtain an income tax deduction in the year that income equalisation deposits are made, a deduction equal to the amount of that deposit. That was the purpose of the introduction of the scheme. When deposits are withdrawn they constitute assessable income in that year. That adjustment is made to their income tax assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of this scheme is to provide a means whereby primary producers can act themselves to smooth out their income flows for taxation purposes by making deposits in high income years and withdrawals in low income years. In this way they can reduce the adverse effects on their taxation liabilities which would result from the interaction of a progressive tax rate scale and fluctuating incomes. That is the aim of this scheme and that is how it works. Smoothing out farmers' income flows through the use of income equalisation deposits could have other advantages. First, by facilitating saving by farmers in good years it could relieve pressure on the Government for financial support when downturns occur. Further, it could assist in smoothing out fluctuations in farm investment, with beneficial effects on service and supply industries.

In order to make use of the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme, a primary producer has, of course, to part with some cash during the period it is on deposit; consequently, interest is paid on that deposit. However, to allow for the fact that part of the deposit represents tax saved rather than an investment as such, the interest rate paid is set below the rates payable on other Commonwealth securities. When the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme was introduced in 1976 the interest rate paid on deposits was set at 5 per cent. At that time it was considered that that rate provided for the bulk of the deposit subscribers an effective rate of return on the investment component of deposits, similar to that which could be obtained on comparable securities. So in 1976 the rate was 5 per cent. In August 1980 the income equalisation deposit interest rate was increased to 7 per cent in recognition of increases which had occurred in interest rates generally since the scheme's inception. So the interest rate increased from 5 per cent to 7 per cent between 1976 and 1980.

Since August 1980 there have been further general increases in interest rates. For example, between August 1980 and August 1981 the rate of interest payable on two-year Commonwealth Bonds increased from 11.5 per cent to 14.65 per cent; the interest rate payable on five-year Commonwealth Bonds increased from 11.8 per cent to 15 per cent; and the interest rate on Australian Savings Bonds increased from 10.25 per cent to 12.25 per cent. In view of these increases in rates during that year from August 1980 to August 1981, the Government decided that the income equalisation deposit rate should be increased further, to 9.5 per cent. That is the change that we are discussing here tonight-the increase from 7 per cent to 9.5 per cent, taking into account those other increases in interest rates that I have just mentioned. The new rate took effect from 23 October this year and it applies to the income equalisation deposits made before that date as well as to deposits made subsequently.

I am very surprised that the Opposition is seeking to disallow this regulation approving the latest increases in the income equalisation deposit rate. Does anyone serously believe that the interest rate payable on income equalisation deposits should remain fixed while interest rates on other securities-such as Commonwealth bonds, private sector debentures and bank and building society deposits-increase substantially? After all, part of an income equalisation deposit represents an investment and it is only proper that the interest rate paid on this investment should be kept in line with interest rate movements in the financial market generally. The Opposition motion, if passed tonight, would unfairly penalise the depositors by pegging their interest rate at its August 1980 level despite the fact that since then interest rates generally have moved upwards. The Government is not prepared to accept such a course of action and it stands by its decision to increase the income equalisation deposit rate from 7 per cent to 9.5 per cent.

I have noted the many figures given by Senator Walsh and I think that they could bear examination. Perhaps the interaction between the IED Scheme and the tax averaging provisions could cause some anomalies. If the figures, when they are checked, show that anomalies can be sustained in the way that Senator Walsh has put them forward I suppose we will accept that an interaction of two policies can raise anomalies. The National Farmers Federation, whose letter was quoted in some detail by Senator Walsh, raises the point that Senator Walsh's Press release takes no account of the people using the scheme in bona fide circumstances, the people who are participants in a scheme that was introduced to assist them with their fluctuating incomes. After all, the introduction of an income equalisation deposits scheme was one of the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission. Senator Walsh has told us that his approach would be that it was recommended by the IAC. With regard to the statement that he has made on that, I am advised that it was not done in that way solely because of administrative impracticability.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not impracticable.
— I ask Senator Walsh to listen. He may learn something.
—You never know anything; you are just advised on A, B or C. I am telling you that it was not impracticable. Some changes would have had to be made.

— Senator Walsh may know more than the officers who are advising the Government and who have given me a note so that the Senate can be advised, even if Senator Walsh understands every facet of the recommendation and the administration of it. That was not done, as I have stated, because of administrative impracticability. Interest is accrued continuously, but there would have been no way of knowing the tax saving or the net deposit until an assessment had been issued. In the meantime interest would have been accruing. An interest cheque may have had to be posted before the assessment of tax was made at that time. It was considered that this was an administrative difficulty. That was the reason why the Scheme was introduced in the way in which it is now administered.

SPEECH.PARA: We have spoken of anomalies. At present a review is being undertaken with regard to the matter of assistance for those in the primary industry sector. Anomalies and all sorts of matters are being addressed within the context of a review of the effectiveness and efficiency of the tax equity and income stabilisation arrangements for primary producers. The review is being carried out by the working party which is preparing a policy discussion paper on agriculture. If, as a result of that review, there are matters which need to be addressed relating to the efficiency, the equity and the interaction of policies that presently exist I am sure the Government will give them consideration. Acceptance of Senator Walsh's proposal to return the interest rate to 7 per cent would result in an effective yield which is well below the market rates for the great bulk of actual and potential income equalisation depositers who use the scheme to stabilise their income.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your proof for that? What is your evidence? Have you got an income stratification for depositors?

— I have the fact that last year the rate was 7 per cent. Interest rates on all investments have increased. It was the Government's proposal to increase the rates modestly-from 7 per cent to 9.5 per cent-in this Budget proposal. This proposal of the Government ought to have the support of the Senate. I would think that Senator Walsh is somewhat chastened by the letter from the National Farmers Federation which takes issue with the statements he has made. As he would recollect from the time that he was more directly involved in these policy matters for the Opposition, he would receive a hostile reception within farming areas for the attitude which he now propounds. The Farmers Federation has stated that it would have no hesitation in giving his attitude appropriate publicity. Issues such as this where we have the spokesman for the Australian Labor Party welcoming the general economic approach and suggesting that it would be desirable for the Government to increase interest rates in this Budget in the way that it has now done would, it would seem to me, place Senator Walsh in a position of some embarrassment in relation to his own colleagues, including the Opposition's spokesman on primary industry. I suggest that the Senate should give support to the Government's proposal and ignore the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Walsh tonight.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 November 1981.
Clause 6 (Determinations with respect to fees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the Senate was debating the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 we got to the stage of dealing with clause 6 of the Bill which provides that the Minister for Education may effectively, by instrument in writing, determine what fees shall be paid by students in respect of second degrees. At the stage of the adjournment, the Australian Democrats had moved an amendment which in effect provided a mechanism whereby the Minister would still be empowered under clause 6 to make a declaration in respect of fees but that declaration would have no effect until it was approved by both Houses of Parliament. I think that is an effective summation of the proposal put forward by the Australian Democrats. I remind the Senate that Senator Macklin advanced argument in respect of the proposal on the basis of his view of the proper role of delegated legislation. Senator Missen advanced argument against the Democrats' proposal on the basis of a totally different view of the appropriateness of this provision as delegated legislation. Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Opposition, indicated our total opposition to clause 6.

SPEECH.PARA: I will indicate an additional reason why we will not support the Democrats' amendment and why we will vote against clause 6 to reject the power of the Minister to make such a declaration in respect of fees altogether. I understand that one of the functions of the Australian Democrats here is, to put it in Senator Mason's terms, 'to keep the bastards honest' or to put it in Senator Carrick's more gentlemanly terms, 'to keep the illegitimates honest'. I saw them exchanging views on that on television one night.

TALK.START.PARA: —They lack the vigour of the hybrid.

—Be that as it may, I understand that to be the stated purpose of the Australian Democrats. An additional political reason why the Australian Democrats' amendment should not be accepted, and indeed should not have been moved if their role in this place is to keep the bastards honest, is simply that, prior to the last election on 8 October 1980, the Minister for Education Mr Fife, said this on the subject of tertiary fees:

SPEECH.PARA: There continues to be speculation about Government plans to re-introduce fees for tertiary education. I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible re-introduction of tertiary fees.

That was 11 days prior to the last election. With respect to the Australian Democrats, what they are doing by this proposed amendment is ignoring the clearly stated intention of this Government about the reintroduction of fees. They are ignoring the Minister's considered statement that there should be no further speculation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no further speculation.
—No further speculation?
—No, he did not say that. He said there was then no consideration of that.
—Oh, come on!
—That is all he said.
—For how long has the honourable senator been here?
—For as long as you have, Senator.

—Yes. Eleven days before an election the Minister said what I have just quoted. Is the honourable senator saying that that was just a sort of way of explaining that the Government had not decided to introduce fees at that stage? If the honourable senator is as naive as that there should be a new political party in this place labelled the wets and its members should not just be subject to a nickname as they are in Great Britain.
—I do not mind the expression at all.

—Well, in the context of this Government, I sympathise with the honourable senator. The point of the matter is that the Minister, in spite of Senator Missen's overwhelming charity, if we can call it that, made it quite clear that he wanted to put an end to speculation about this issue. The Australian Democrats' amendment keeps alive the issue of possible introduction of fees for post-graduate degrees. There is always the possibility-I hesitate to give this example-that on some occasion after the Minister had made a declaration and fees had been approved by the House of Representatives a declaration of the Minister could be introduced into the Senate and by some magical exercise which none of us can anticipate at the moment that declaration could be approved by the Senate. To take an example, I remember an incident--
—One of your people would miss a division.

—I was just going to give that example. We could take the example of a situation last year when the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Democrats-there were no followers at that stage-made impassioned speeches about a certain issue in this place and then when the vote was taken on it happened to have gone home to bed.
—Who was keeping whom honest?
—That is right. But the fact of the matter is that when a vote was taken on an issue which was of expressed importance to the Australian Democrats--
—Rubbish.

—Senator Chipp and Senator Mason were in bed-I am not suggesting together, senator; do not get offended. There were no geese that night to wake up the Democrats and save Australia from the horrible fate it suffered as a result of that vote that night. That could happen again. So long as we have a situation of the Democrats' proposition floating about we still have the possibility of fees being introduced in some untoward bizarre circumstances like the ones I have described.
—They could just as easily reintroduce clause 6.

—No. With respect, the Government could not because a Bill would have to be introduced into the House of Representatives and passed by that House. Even the Democrats would be awake by the time a Bill was passed by the House of Representatives and introduced into this place. Someone said the other night that the Democrats are like literate billy goats rummaging in the policy dust bins of other people's policies. The Democrats would read the House of Representatives Hansard and be alerted that such a Bill was coming to this chamber. Senator Haines would know that. I must say that in the conduct of discussion in this chamber the Australian Democrats know that what I am saying is said in the greatest good humour and friendliness because I do not in any way wish to offend them. I just want to alert them to the possibility of what might happen.
—You mean five sleepers, not just two.

—That is right. What I have said is always a possibility. I want to argue on behalf of those who will be the unhappy victims of this legislation if it is passed or if the Democrats' amendment is passed. People who are planning academic careers of one kind or another need a degree of certainty about what the future holds for them; there is no doubt about that. If they are planning a post-graduate career and they are in not particularly affluent circumstances, they want to know where they are going in respect to the fees issue; and they could have no confidence about it were the Democrats' amendment adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I want to make is somewhat consistent with a point that Senator Missen made last night. Is this Parliament continually to be an arbiter of fees? For example, let us suppose that the Minister introduced a declaration in relation to fees for, say, the medical profession and we have been having a barney in here about the virtues of the medical profession, which is not particularly highly regarded by the Australian people. Were that issue to come before the Senate would we then debate, as a group of experts, questions of respective fees for respective courses and so on? I would have thought it highly inappropriate that we should do that. That is a matter for the Minister to determine on a broad across-the-board basis in relation to post-graduate fees generally and is not a matter which should be determined by detailed debate in the Senate or the House of Representatives. The Opposition's concern that this legislation should be dealt with appropriately at this time, that the clause should be rejected and that the Democrats' amendment, for the reasons I have stated, should not be supported, however well intentioned it may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button made a big point about statements made by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) prior to the last election in which he gave a promise, it is alleged by the Opposition, that fees for tertiary students would not be reintroduced during the three years of this Government. What he said was that the Government was not presently considering any fees. I have already admitted in my speech at the second reading stage that there is a spectrum of interpretation of those words, but I certainly reject from that spectrum that the Minister was lying or that he made a firm promise which is now being denied. I reject that utterly. I believe the Minister for Education committed himself prior to the last election to the statement that the Government was not at that stage considering the introduction of fees. Let us look at the matters about which the Government did make very clear statements. I refer to its very clear promise that there would be maximum responsible restraint on government spending. As a result of that clear promise, the Review of Commonwealth Functions was set up shortly after the election and that spending restraint was applied to the field of education as much as to other areas. As a result of that promise being followed up by the Government, we have the decision by the RCF that there would be a partial reintroduction of fees.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Australian Democrats spokesman, Senator Macklin, was speaking about this he talked about it being a matter of extreme importance to the community. I believe it is of importance to a section of the community, but there are in the debates in this Senate many matters of more direct importance to the community. I do not really believe that the reintroduction of fees of up to $1,000 maximum in a year for 8,000 students-perhaps fewer, the Democrats suggest-is of enormous concern to the community. Does anybody receive letters other than from students or academics, those who are directly involved in that small part of the community? What is of concern to a part, as we all know, to quote John Donne, is of concern to all of us. I would not want to take this too much out of perspective because the alternative, in terms of the concerns of this 8,000, is an increased levy or tax upon the whole 8 million taxpayers of Australia. One could argue that the 8 million are concerned with restraint in spending. That restraint, as a promise of the Government in the last election campaign, has to be balanced with the concerns of the 8,000 who may be required to pay up to $1,000 in fees. The only other point I want to make relates to the Australian Democrats motion. Senator Missen has already said that it is a very rare procedure here to have the affirmative form of review of a determination by the Senate. I do not think--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there anything wrong with that?

—No, there is nothing intrinsically wrong with that, but I believe it is misplaced. More importantly, there does need to be some clear statement of the Senate's mind in this matter and I believe that now is the time to state it. If the Democrats' amendment is adopted by the Senate and if that is the form in which clause 6 of the Bill is passed, then some 15 sitting days after the Senate returns in February, with universities and colleges taking enrolments, it is possible-depending on which side of the bed the Democrats got out of to come to the Parliament on the day-that the Democrats would approve or disapprove the determination according to whether they thought it was a money Bill or according to whether they thought that the referendum of party members suggested that they should do so. I believe that degree of uncertainty about a determination being disallowable-if the Democrats' amendment is adopted tonight-is an uncertainty that students, staff and the community at large do not seek. I believe, therefore, that the Democrats' amendment is misplaced and that we should reject it. I believe also that we should reject the amendment moved by the Opposition, for reasons that have been well canvassed in the earlier speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of some distinguished guests, who are from the State legislatures of the United States of America, under the leadership of Senator Doyen. I bid them welcome on behalf of honourable senators and trust that their time in Australia will be a happy and fruitful one.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As our proceedings are being broadcast, I rise to make a few remarks about some of the comments that Senator Button has seen fit to make; not so much about what he said but about his motivation for saying what he did-all the rubbish that he has said about Australian Democrats senators being in bed when votes were taken. He knows the truth of that as well as I do. I have observed Senator Button around this place for a good many years. He always has the sort of Don Quixote attitude of rushing around and charging at different windmills when he is either worried or not quite sure of whether his position is the right one. This is a classic case of that, so I think we can dismiss the other irrelevancies of what he had to say a few moments ago and come right back to what the Australian Labor Party is up to over this matter. Senator Button is so badly rattled because he knows that the amendment represents sanity and a reasonable compromise in this matter. It has been urged by the Australian Democrats in that light.

SPEECH.PARA: But if the Labor Party and the Government want a confrontation, a head-on collision over this matter-as has been their custom for so many years-and if they want to take up the time of the public of this country and inconvenience it to the extent that they apparently want, purely from the viewpoint of a couple of gangs of eight-year-olds in the playground, to take a head-on collision course over this matter when either or both of them could accept this amendment, then so be it. There are only five of us here and we are not really in a position to influence them other than in what we say. If we cannot persuade them to agree to the Macklin amendment-I assure honourable senators that it is a simple exercise in democracy, which is something we could have a lot more of in this country with benefit-perhaps we have not been persuasive or eloquent enough. Perhaps Senator Macklin will be more eloquent than me. I am merely trying to put the simple proposition that here is an amendment which will give all of us what we want. Is it a stupid proposition? Is it an unreasonable or undemocratic proposition that a Minister's determination in a matter as important as this should not be subject to affirmation of the votes of the Houses of parliament? Why do we have Houses of parliament? Let us get back to that point. Why do we bother to have a Senate? Why do we bother to have a House of Representatives if we say that the whole thing is to be run by two, three or four members, or by one member, of the Executive of this country?

I commend this amendment to the Committee, Mr Temporary Chairman, and through you urge honourable senators to vote for it. By doing so, they will show the people of this country that they are above petty confrontationist, squabbling politics and the sort of verbal diarrhoea that Senator Button indulged in earlier, and one can describe it as no more than that. I suggest to him that he should elevate his tone of debate somewhat if he wants to get somewhere in this place. Honourable senators rise above that and consider this amendment for what it is-a genuine, reasonable, democratic compromise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to indicate that the Government will oppose both the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats and the foreshadowed amendments of the Australian Labor Party. The Government has given a policy determination in clause 6 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill to impose fees for higher degrees. That is the Government's policy. It intends to do so. The fact of the matter is, and the public should understand this, that although there has been an inter-familial squabble here tonight there will be a quite incestuous partnership as between the Democrats and the Labor Party when it comes to the final vote tonight. The political incest itself is very evident because, as I understand it, we will see tonight a situation of quite some intriguing design. The Democrats are saying by inference that there should be fees because they are saying that fees shall be determined by positive vote of both Houses. So let that be clear. The Democrats' amendment is an acceptance of the principle that is a right for fees to be determined.
—They could hardly vote against the whole clause.

—Therefore they could not under any circumstances vote against the clause. They are saying that the way for fees to be determined-and naturally there will be fees-is for them to be determined by vote of both Houses. Of course, because of the pairing arrangements and other things, my understanding is that the Democrats, having failed to get their amendment accepted, will then vote for the deletion of the clause. The truth of the matter is that the Democrats have put on a phoney fight here tonight to pretend that there is a difference between them and the Labor Party, but the real intention of the Democrats is to destroy the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate upon the substance of this matter has taken place in this chamber and in another place on the second reading motions. It is not now the time to debate the merits of the matter. The fact is that the Committee has before it a choice. The Government has determined that there should be fees and that the Minister should have the right of determination, which is a normal condition in an infinite amount of legislation that goes about this place. The Democrats say: That being so, then the way to do it is by positive determination in the chambers. The Labor Party says: There shall be no fees. We shall watch how the Democrats vote when it comes to the question of 'no fees'.

I take the point that tonight there has been some very interesting discussion on the relative honesty and integrity of individuals. I only wish that Hansard could record the number of statements and contradictions of the Democrats. Because we are dealing tonight with matters affecting money and supply, I could not resist remembering that it is 11 November and recalling that for six years the great sin has been an Opposition blocking Supply. Let me quote some of the things that were said tonight at 6.40 p.m.:
Peter Harvey: 'It was possible that unless the Government agreed to Senate reform it too could face the blocking of supply.'
That is a question asked by a television interviewer. Senator Gareth Evans replied:

It is not within the realm of the reasonably foreshadowed, but it is possible and the Government should not in its own thinking rule out entirely the possibility of the Labor Party moving in that direction.

Now that, if we are talking about keeping the hybrid illegitimates honest, is a classic. For over six years there has been the statement that the great and cardinal sin in this place is to block money Bills and Supply. Tonight there is this exposure. I do not want to delay the Committee. I merely indicate that the Government will oppose both of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a pity that, on an issue as important as this one is for this country, we should have had such a trivial and disgraceful example from a number of speakers which really did not have very much substance and, in fact, did not attempt to come to grips with the type of proposition that is put forward in this amendment. A number of senators ranged over a number of issues that were obviously their own pet concerns. They used the time of the Senate in relation to those matters rather than addressing themselves to the issue. I will comment on a number of points made in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, Senator Missen raised the point that he thought that the affirmation of both Houses of Parliament should be reserved for important issues. He said that he did not think that this was one of those issues. In other words, he did not think that this was an important issue. That same line of thinking was reiterated tonight by Senator Teague when he said that all I was concerned about in my speech on the second reading was the fee issue and whether that was of vital importance to the electorate. Unfortunately, if Senator Teague had listened to or read the speech that I made on the second reading he would know that I did not mention the issue of fees at all. I concentrated entirely on the matter of the destruction of tertiary education in this country. I said that that was a vital issue. I still believe that it is a vital issue. I believe that the country believes that it is a vital issue even if Senator Teague does not.

The matter that we debated last night and that Senator Button alluded to again tonight was the fact that clause 6, to which I moved an amendment, indeed gives the Minister for Education a discretionary power in relation to the imposition of fees. We have suggested that, if the Minister were to set fees such action should be subject to the affirmation and the approval of both Houses of Parliament. That is precisely what we are saying. There is absolutely no inconsistency between that and our opposition to fees.

We have offered to the Committee what we believe is a reasonable compromise. We have been attacked by the Australian Labor Party as suggesting that really we do want fees because we have moved this amendment. The example ran something like this if I do not misrepresent Senator Button's position: He said: 'Let us look at the possibility of, at some stage, the House of Representatives passing a determination and then if some senators were absent that could be put through the Senate'. The example that he used related to the absence of Australian Democrat senators who were ill at the time and who, in fact, were absent for a vote. But, unfortunately, the example that Senator Button chose was a rather poor one. The reason is that, if a Bill to introduce fees had passed the House of Representatives in exactly the same way as a determination and was, in other words, sitting outside the door of this chamber, if any senators were absent which gave the Government a majority in the chamber, it could as easily pass a Bill as pass a determination. Senator Button accepted this because the example he used concerned the passing of a Bill. So there is no substance in the suggestion that this would in any way make it more probable for fees to go through rather than for a Bill to go through. When a Government has a majority in this place it can suspend Standing Orders, move the gag, or do what it likes and have something through in double-quick time. The numbers speak very loudly in this chamber.

That point aside, I move on to a couple of other matters that were raised. One matter relates to the fact that we put up these amendments, that this is really a phoney fight, and that later on we will be voting with the Australian Labor Party. If that statement were contained in the speech of anybody other than the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) I think it could graciously be ignored as being an aberration of a senator late at night. The fact that the Leader of the Government chose to use that matter as his major point I think needs answering. We have voted in this House constantly in relation to this issue. The Leader of the Government and other Government senators know that we have voted with them on many issues. Members of the Labor Party also know that we have voted with them on many issues. We will continue to vote on the issue and we will continue to maintain that stance. There does not happen to be any possibility in this chamber other than that of voting with the Government or with the Labor Party simply because their members vote en bloc on these issues. If there were other types of combinations I imagine that that would be a delight not only to this House but also to the electorate at large. Therefore, it is utter nonsense and it is an absurdity to claim that when we vote with the Opposition or with the Government we are necessarily in league with them. Given recent occurrences and other occurrences that are in the wind we believe that there will be a shake-up of the political structures in this country in the not too far distant future. Then we will be quite happy to allow the remnants of the Liberal Party and the Labor Party to vote with us and we will not make accusations in that regard. Indeed we had present in the chamber yesterday a representative from the Social Democrats. We expect that such a party will emerge shortly in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Competition for you.

—We do not mind. We welcome competition. It is a free enterprise party. I reiterate the point that I made in relation to our amendment. We hope that it will be viewed as a reasonable compromise. Obviously that has now been lost. There is a preference to go into a fight on this matter and to leave our universities up in the air. Senator Teague suggested that if our amendment were carried it would have exactly the same effect. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) presumably would not take very kindly to Senator Teague's implied suggestion that he is not doing his job properly. I imagine that the Minister for Education already has his determination in hand, and has completed the planning for the introduction of fees. There is absolutely no reason why he should wait until next year. If in fact this amendment were carried he could take his determination into the House of Representatives next Tuesday and have it brought into the Senate tomorrow. The whole matter would then be cleaned up. There is absolutely no problem preventing the matter from being settled this week in the Senate and on Tuesday of next week in the House of Representatives. I hope that the Minister for Education has done his homework and has not left these types of things up in the air as was suggested by Senator Teague.

SPEECH.PARA: We put forward these types of suggestions from time to time in the hope that various groups in this chamber may be able to agree not to get all that they want but at least some movement in these areas. For example, in relation to this Bill we hope to be able to dissociate rapidly the motion of funding universities from the idea of whether or not we will charge fees. If the Government had to introduce this particular provision we would have much preferred-I suggested this yesterday-that it did so as a new policy, in other words in a separate Bill so that it could get the spotlight free from the emotional atmosphere that is now being created and the instability in the minds of our tertiary institutions.

We hoped that we would have been able to have this debate as a separate debate and the issue carried or lost on its merits. We hope that in future new policies being implemented in Bills may be dealt with in that fashion rather than being tied up with other elements that have the full support of this chamber. If that were the case on this occasion this chamber would be only too eager to move to vote for the money for our tertiary institutions. I hope that in future the Government may accede to what I believe is a legitimate request on the part of senators that we have the chance to discuss new policies as part of separate Bills. Thus we would avoid repetition of the rather disastrous situation we face at the moment with threats hanging over our universities and colleges of advanced education that they might lack funds for the start of a new academic year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate I outlined some arguments against the reintroduction of fees at universities and colleges of advanced education and I do not intend to pursue those arguments again tonight. However I wish to follow one argument which was presented by Senator Teague. Probably for the first time in this debate Senator Teague and I are on the same wavelength. I want to mention the point that Senator Teague raised about the chaos that would occur if the Australian Democrats' amendment were passed. I am not sure that Senator Teague used the word 'chaos' but there would be chaos between now and, say, the middle of the first semester next year at universities and colleges of advanced education.

SPEECH.PARA: How could that occur? The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) could make a determination in relation to fees but he could make that determination the day after this chamber and the House of Representatives had adjourned for the summer recess. If the Minister made such a determination, presumably at that point that determination would be lawful. It would have to come before both Houses of Parliament within five sitting days of those Houses of Parliament resuming in 1982. Suppose we came back in mid-February. Five sitting days after we came back could take us, quite conceivably, into March. It would not be necessary for the Minister to table that determination until, say, March next year. That is not at all a far-fetched supposition. If we came back later than mid-February the tabling date could be towards the end of March, but let us say that it is the beginning of March-within 10 sitting days both Houses of Parliament have to come to some decision about the determination that the Minister has made. As Easter is about that time of the year, it could be mid-April before 10 sitting days expire after the first five sitting days.

What will happen in the meantime? The universities will have to make a decision about whether they are going to charge these fees, which at that time will be lawful. Probably some of them will do so; some will hold off, thinking they will have to wait until the Parliament has made a decision. The ones which hold off might find that the determinations become lawful because of some chance happening that the fees are ratified by both Houses of Parliament. They would then have to go to their students and collect fees or suffer the consequences of not doing so, the consequences being that they would lose some of their revenue. The ones which charge fees might find subsequently that the fees are not ratified by one of the Houses of Parliament. What would they do then? They might have to refund the fees to all of the students. In the meantime there would be all this uncertainty at universities and colleges of advanced education. It could conceivably begin at about the beginning of December and finish at about the end of April next year. This sort of thing can happen if this amendment is passed. Senator Teague mentioned it this evening. I think it is one of the points which must be brought forward and recognised before we actually vote on the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That clause 6 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised a matter last night during the Committee stage of this legislation. My approach to it was to ensure that the Houses of Parliament were given the opportunity to examine the determination made by the Minister if clause 6 were to be approved and if, of course, the consequential amendments which require a positive vote by the Senate were also to be approved. The position we have now reached is, unfortunately, that the proposition put forward by Senator Macklin has been pilloried to a certain extent by the Opposition and perhaps to a lesser extent by the Government on the ground that it is an unusual procedure, namely, that the clause would have required a positive vote of both Houses of Parliament within a particular period to validate the instrument. Whether there was merit in that argument-I could not see a great deal of merit in that argument and that is why I voted for the amendment-the issue still stands. The issue, quite frankly, is whether the Parliament should have the responsibility in some form of overseeing the determination made by the Minister, if the Parliament gives the Minister the power to make a determination. Unquestionably, the people of Australia, if the matter were put to them, would answer in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The question then remains as to how that can best be done in a manner that is not inconsistent with approaches in regard to subordinate legislation. Indeed, the Senate has been in the forefront of argument supporting the proposition that it should have the right to scrutinise subordinate legislation and, within the appropriate time, to disallow that ordinance. I remind the Senate that it does not take as many members to disallow an ordinance as it does to approve a particular proposition. On reflection, of course, I think that had the whole of the Senate supported the Australian Democrats' proposition, it would have worked in our favour on this occasion, but it could well have worked against us on some future occasion. The time-honoured approach that has been taken in respect of the scrutiny of subordinate legislation, namely, by way of disallowance is one which surely should receive some consideration by the Committee. Indeed, it is my intention now to test the Committee in respect of this issue to see whether, in fact, it is prepared to adopt that approach. I ask that my amendment be circulated. I move:
Page 11, clause 6, after sub-clause (6), insert the following sub-clause:

'(6A) Sub-sections (1), (3), (4), (5), (5A) and (6) of section 48 and section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply to an instrument signed by the Minister under this section as if that instrument were a regulation.'.

I remind the Committee that all the arguments that have been adduced by the Australian Democrats in support of their previous motion apply, of course, to my motion. My motion provides to the Parliament, indeed, to both Houses of Parliament, the opportunity to examine the instrument and to disallow it if either the House of Representatives or the Senate chooses to do so. I believe that it is not necessary for me to outline to honourable senators, as they are aware of the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act in respect of the way these matters are drafted, that the instrument signed by the Minister under clause 6 would, in fact, apply as if that instrument were a regulation and, therefore, would be subject to disallowance by both Houses of Parliament.

I believe that my proposition will overcome the objection that certain people had to the proposition put forward by the Democrats-though I do not have that objection-that it was unusal and that, in fact, it could have reacted against us in a certain sphere although not on this issue. I submit this amendment to the Committee without further argument. I rest my case on the fact that this is not an unusual proposition. It is, in fact, consistent with what we do with all other subordinate pieces of legislation; that is subject them to the scrutiny of both Houses of Parliament, either House of which is entitled within the specified time to disallow that particular instrument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the amendment which, although it comes as something of a surprise to honourable senators who have not seen it before, relates to an area in which there is a great deal of interest in the decisions made, many of which are not covered by regulations in such a way that they are, for example, reviewed by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. They are not really looked at by the Senate at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust that the Government will accept the amendment because it seems to me desirable that reasonably important decisions such as this should be subject to review by the Parliament. It is important that as much as possible of the subordinate legislation that is given effect by Ministers or statutory organisations be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. I took the view that, in light of the positive way in which the Australian Democrats amendment was presented, it was not of sufficient importance to require that that sort of procedure be followed. However, it is a procedure which should be adopted more in the future. On the other hand, the type of procedure that we have at the moment-that which is more regularly used and is the subject of action by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee of the Senate-ought to be fostered as far as possible. When the issues concerned obviously are controversial, or may affect-as the Regulations and Ordinances Committee criteria provide-the rights and liberties of the citizen, or indeed any of the other criteria set down by the Committee, it would be desirable that such decisions be subject to review. I hope that this amendment, which we now see for the first time, will be acceptable to the Government and that the suggested provision may be inserted in this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it clear earlier this evening that the Government would, of course, prefer that no amendment be made to the substantive clause. The Government has looked in the past at the question of disallowance procedures but felt that it was better to have the clause as it is. However, I am able to say that the Government will accept the amendment, which would permit the insertion of disallowance provisions. That, of course, would go a very considerable way towards meeting the wishes of those who want inserted provision for the scrutiny of fees by the Parliament. They would then have available to them the regulatory procedures that are standard to this Senate, and accepted. As a test of those who say that their purpose is the scrutiny of fees I commend the amendment to honourable senators and announce that the Government will support it.

—I indicated that the Opposition opposed the proposal of the Australian Democrats. It did so because the proposal leaves the issue of fees in limbo. It is inconsistent with the stated undertakings of the Government prior to the last election and I think it goes without saying that, in the circumstances, we would not be attracted by Senator Harradine's proposition. Senator Harradine said his was not an unusual proposition. It was unusual to me until a couple of minutes ago in the context of this debate, but the reality of Senator Harradine's proposition is simply this: For all its shortcomings the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats, as we noted at an earlier stage, did require an affirmative vote of both Houses of the Parliament for the declaration of the Minister to be approved and have effect. The effect of Senator Harradine's proposal is that there would have to be positive action for disallowance by either House of the Parliament. As I believe Senator Carrick would recognise, to obtain positive action for disallowance, given the crude numbers of the 1981 Senate, would require an affirmative vote of 33 senators. I just point out to the Australian Democrats that that would be the requirement of--
—So it is not on merit that you plead; it is on numbers.

—Oh no; we have had the arguments about merits at great length. If I might say so, I did not think that Senator Carrick would remind us of those arguments because I thought he lost them. It comes, of course, to a question of determination of what the Senate wants. I remind Senator Carrick of events in 1975 and what took place between 1972 and 1975. Numbers have not been unimportant in the Senate. On this issue of the introduction of fees, if we want the possibility of the introduction of fees, if we want students who are seeking to plan careers and so on in terms of post-graduate degrees to be plagued by uncertainty in the future, then the mechanism which has been devised, I think in quite good faith by Senator Harradine, would be the means of creating that uncertainty-very much so. So there is a relationship-if I might put it in this way-between the numbers and the merits in relation to this issue.
—You surprise me.

—Senator Carrick says that I surprise him. I would have thought that he would be the last person to be surprised. That is why the Opposition would not look on Senator Harradine's proposition with great favour. Those who are concerned that fees should not be imposed and that there should be some certainty about the situation should not, I think, be attracted at all by this proposition.

—Senator Button talks about numbers and merits. His judgment on the question of merit, as he put it in his argument, is subjective. I do not believe that he has in any way convinced this side of the chamber that Senator Harradine's amendment brings the world of uncertainty that we see in the amendment that was put by the Australian Democrats. Senator Harradine's amendment takes a much more normal form and clarifies the fact that determinations made under this clause or instruments of the Minister may be disallowed by the Senate. It is in a form which provides that other regulations or decisions by Ministers of a regulatory nature may be disallowed. Insofar as it is then a concession to that power of the Senate, I see it as something which is acceptable and which does not have the world of uncertainty that Senator Button is concerned about-it also concerned me, as I said earlier-and which is contained in the Democrats' amendment. Therefore I believe that not only Government senators but also Australian Democrat senators-indeed, the whole Committee-may readily support Senator Harradine's amendment.

—I just remind the Committee that the Opposition intends to oppose clause 6. We have prepared 30 consequential amendments which have been circulated in my name. Following the successful opposition of that clause it is our intention to move them en bloc at the end of the Committee debate.

—The only substantive argument put forward by Government senators in relation to the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats was, I believe, that the issue was not important enough for the affirmative vote of both Houses of this Parliament. The difference between the Democrats and the Government is that we believe not only is it important enough but also it is of vital importance for this country. It is for that reason that we cannot accept anything less than the affirmative vote of both Houses of the Parliament for the future of this country, and we will not do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the comments by Senator Macklin about this matter. All of his statements made in support of the amendment that he put forward for the instrument to be the subject of scrutiny in the Houses of Parliament were, word for word, the ones that are appropriate for use in support of my amendment that is now before the chamber. I could read from the Hansard each and every one of the words that Senator Macklin stated in support of his proposition in support of the proposition that is now before the chamber. There is no difference, in essence, between the previous motion which was put forward and this particular amendment. It would ensure the ability of both Houses of Parliament to scrutinise what, as has been indicated, is in reality subordinate legislation. It would ensure their ability to scrutinise the instrument that the Minister would be enabled to determine as a result of the passage of clause 6. Let honourable senators be reminded that the Australian Democrats were prepared, if they were supported in their previous motion, to vote against the deletion of clause 6. Now they are faced with the very real prospect of their desire being fulfilled. By means of this amendment they are faced with the prospect of the Government voting, together with me, to give them what they wanted. Now they say that they are not prepared to accept that and presumably would vote against the whole of clause 6. In my view, as I deliberately stated last night, a distinction ought to be made between the imposition of fees on higher degrees which, if effected, would substantially interfere with the research being undertaken in universities which is so vital to the future of Australia. There ought to be a distinction between an imposition of fees for those degrees and the imposition of fees in respect of people who are doing perhaps third or even fourth degrees at their leisure.
—What is wrong with that?

—I will tell the honourable senator what is wrong with that. There are a few layabouts who are prepared to do third and fourth degrees-I am not talking about second degrees. I will take the honourable senator into a factory if she wants and I will challenge her to stand with me and to say to the workers there: 'You are paying for these layabouts to do third, fourth and fifth degrees on your money'. I will tell the honourable senator who will vote for her and who will vote for me. We are talking about the people that are using the system for third and fouth degrees, the professional university students. They are invariably the ones who are taking away from our sons and daughters the opportunity to get their first degrees. The money bowl's funds are not unlimited. Let me make perfectly clear what honourable senators are doing tonight: They are allowing that type of operation to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I am opposed very strongly to the suggestion made by the Government that it will impose fees on higher degree students and that it certainly will impose fees on some second degree students. Therefore, if the Government persists in that attitude I will oppose outright clause 6. I will have no option but to oppose it. But we have an opportunity now to have the best of both worlds. We have an opportunity to give the Government the right to ensure that the taxpayers' money, the workers' money, is not frittered away on people who are prepared to use the system, year in year out, until they are about 50 years of age, when they can go on sabbatical leave. I am saying to the Australian Democrats that they have an opportunity right here and now to have the best of both worlds. The Government has said that it is prepared to support this proposition. All that is needed for the proposition to succeed is for one solitary Democrat or one of the members of the Australian Labor Party to make a stand for the workers of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you think we are opposing fees?
—Oh, my dear, why is the Labor Party opposing fees? It is opposing fees--
—So that the workers can go to university.

—Yes, the workers are prevented from going to university because the layabouts are getting third, fourth and fifth degrees and preventing our sons and daughters from going to university and getting their first degrees-in other words, their meal tickets. All I say is this: I am providing an opportunity, which is accepted by the Government, for us to have the best of both worlds. If the introduction of an instrument applying to higher degrees or indeed to some second degrees were proposed, we would oppose it and it would be out on its neck.
—What if the instrument does not differentiate?

—If the instrument did not differentiate it would be out. That is the point. If the Government proposed introducing an instrument consistent with what it has been saying, including the imposition of fees for higher degrees and so forth, I would vote against it, as would the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats. The point is that under this amendment that I am putting forward tonight--
—That is an impressive argument.
—I am glad to hear Senator Evans saying that it is an impressive argument.
—I have four degrees. Sssh!

—The honourable senator had to pay for some of them, I think. Quite seriously, there is now an opportunity for the Senate to act responsibly on this issue. We have heard the Democrats saying that they are prepared to go to the barricades on this matter. If the Democrats do not support this amendment they are prepared to go to the barricades for the layabouts who are getting their third, fourth and fifth degrees on the backs of the workers. That is the only measure on which they are prepared to go to the barricades. Yet they are prepared to allow the sales tax proposals which will impose a burden on the workers to go through. Let me make it very clear that we have narrowed down the area on which the Australian Democrats are prepared to go to the barricades. They are prepared to do it for a handful of people who are getting their degrees on the backs of the working class. The Australian Democrats are not prepared to go to the barricades on the other question-that of sales tax-which is a very real issue not only for the workers but also for the university students. The Australian Democrats and myself have received reams of representations from universities and other institutions in respect of the sales tax issue. The students must spend all of their days writing letters. I appeal to the Democrats and to just one member of the Australian Labor Party to get up and to support this amendment. If they do, they can have the best of both worlds. If they do not, they are acting blindly.

—I have discovered an avid reason for opposing Senator Harradine's proposition. The reason is simply that I do not think any honourable senator-in the context of numbers in the Senate it would be Senator Harradine-should be invested with the burden of determining whether regulations should be disallowed in the circumstances which Senator Harradine has put. One could imagine regulations being brought in prescribing certain classes of degrees and so on and categories of students who would have to pay fees. Senator Harradine would then have the unenviable task of going through those regulations to determine who were layabouts and who were the proper recipients of further training. All of these decisions would have to be made by the Senate in the context of those regulations.
—There is a committee to help him-the Regulations and Ordinances Committee under Senator Lewis.

—I would not have thought that was entirely the appropriate committee to deal with a matter which seems to have become as politicised as this issue is. I would not have thought it would be within the function of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in the circumstances which have been put forward. Senator Harradine has illustrated in a colourful way, I think, some of the passions and prejudices which come into this issue and which would again be aroused in the context of determining whether regulations should be disallowed. That is simply undesirable in the present situation. We could not support the amendment which Senator Harradine suggests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard a lot of rhetoric tonight and very little about the real issue which is at stake in this matter.
—That is a pretty good argument.

—I think that it is the fundamental argument, if I can put it that way. I am not too sure that I would agree in passing with what Senator Harradine has said about all these layabouts who run around getting three or four degrees. It is hard enough work getting one. I do not really believe that there are too many people who laboriously work their way through degree after degree purely for the sake of getting their fees paid for them. I just cannot believe that this is a big issue. After all, students have to support themselves through this time and frequently they cannot get a job. I cannot believe that is really an issue which is at stake. I think that the number of people who are the so-called professional students who go on getting degrees one after another is rather small in real life. Senator Evans admits to being one of them. He arrived in this place eventually, but I do not know whether that is an argument for people taking large numbers of degrees.

SPEECH.PARA: To take a more serious view of this matter, the Australian Democrats are fully aware that the Government is taking a false direction in education and it is doing it for ignoble reasons of political expediency. It wants to show somebody-I do not know who; perhaps some extreme right wing person somewhere-that it will economise or cut down in some way and that we will save some money. How much money will be saved? How much money? I have talked to people in universities about this and it appears that by the time they have gone to the trouble and expense of collecting these fees we will be lucky to have $3m a year from them for this country. What are we sacrificing? What is the Government proposing to sacrifice for that? It has decided in its wisdom that this country is to become a banana republic of the worst sort; we are going to discourage people from going on to further and higher degrees. We are not going to compete in the world of modern technology. We are not going to do what every other modern Western society is doing and make it as easy as possible for people to educate themselves to their fullest potential. Oh no, we are not going to do that. We are going to say to these people: 'We are not going to allow you to do that; we are going to make it hard for you'.

That will be at the stage where a graduate, perhaps in his twenties and who may be married with a family and who is feeling the economic pinch, feels that he might go on and obtain a further or higher degree. The Government is going to say: 'You are going to be positively dissuaded from doing this'. But there is one section that the Government is not dissuading and that is the people whose parents have enough money to support them to enable them to get through. That is what this debate is really all about. If we in this country are to compete in the future in the world of modern technology we must have a situation in which we educate as many of our young people as possible to their highest potential. We have to make every opportunity available to them to do it. The Australian Democrats see that we have a responsibility in this matter. We perceive it and we will not shirk it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because of recent rhetoric which seems to be utterly self-contradictory. We heard Senator Mason say that if we introduce fees for higher degrees that will decrease the number of students coming to universities and we will not be on a par with other countries which are so much better than us. But, on the other hand, he says that there is not much money involved in it-only about $3m-so perforce only very few students can be affected. So that we have no doubt in the world about the situation, the argument that is running is that things are done better in other places and that we ought to learn from overseas. I will look at where we could learn from. In Belgium fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In Canada fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In France fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In Italy fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In Japan fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In the Netherlands fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In the United Kingdom fees are charged for first, second and higher degrees. In the United States of America the situation is the same. Incidentally, the fees in those countries are much higher than what has been argued here. There have been two arguments and I will let them fall. The arguments have been that if we charge fees we will be putting Australia in a detrimental position compared with countries overseas and yet there is clear evidence that the majority of overseas countries charge fees, and much higher fees.
—Why did you-you yourself-say that you would never change them?

—Why did the Opposition say that it would never block Supply? Let the physician cure himself. The fact is that on both those matters the arguments fall. If it is true that overseas there is a burgeoning of students into universities where fees are charged at all levels, clearly charging fees only at the higher level will not be detrimental to getting students into the universities. Secondly, if we do our sums and if what Senator Mason has suggested is true, clearly only a relative handful of people will be affected. I commend the amendment and ask that the Senate proceed with securing the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to two issues, one raised by Senator Harradine and one by Senator Carrick. The substantive point that Senator Harradine raised was in relation to people running around and getting additional degrees. He linked that with the possibility of a determination which may be able to avoid that situation and still allow genuine people to proceed on to second and higher degrees. I believe that that in fact is probably a correct answer. In other words, we would not be able to get such a determination on the Government's own admission.

SPEECH.PARA: In reply to Senator Carrick, I would certainly believe that an additional course in comparative education would be useful. The point was raised that a large number of countries with which we like to compare ourselves charge for first, second and higher degrees. That certainly is the case. Unfortunately we are not speaking from the same base line. From the end of the Second World War until the present time, some of the countries mentioned by Senator Carrick have funded education at a per capita rate in excess of four or five times our contribution. We have underfunded education woefully for years. Now we are saying that we do not need to give special advantages to our citizens to allow them to become educated. Other countries have established a benchmark. They have managed to get their population educated. The United States of America has managed to educate over 50 per cent of its population in tertiary instututions. However, the number of people attending our tertiary institutions is dropping every year. Imagine that-in a growing country our numbers in tertiary education are dropping every year. Somebody might like to stand up and contradict that. That is what is happening in this country; that is the reality of tertiary education in this country. I believe we have to get our priorities back into perspective. We are talking about our own citizens and our own country. We have to give special advantages to our citizens in an area in which we know investment will pay off-and it pays off handsomely in education every time. That is why we put money into pre-schools, primary schools, secondary schools, colleges of advanced education, tertiary and further education colleges and universities. We do so because it pays off every time. Every dollar we put in we get back double.

TALK.START.PARA: —Declare your interests.

—That is the way it should be done. I do not mind admitting that I was employed at a university. I am quite happy that I was employed there because I was able to carry out a task which I thought was fruitful and useful. In fact I sought election to this place to carry out a task which I also thought was fruitful and useful. If the honourable senator wishes to denigrate universities, go ahead and do so. If he wishes to denigrate academics, do so. I do not mind. I will stand up any time for the people who are trying to work for education in this country because they are doing the work and they deserve the support of this country and certainly the support of this chamber. Unless at some stage we manage to get our priorities right people in 30 or 40 years time will look back and say: 'That is where the whole thing started; that is where people were so short sighted that they decided to sell our entire research effort and our higher degree effort down the drain because they thought there were a few votes in it'. There may be a few votes in it-I do not know. I think it might be underselling the electorate to suggest that there are. But let us admit that there may be a few votes in it. The Government can look to the short term; we will look ahead to the long term. I would not care if I were to lose my seat over standing up for what I believe because at least I would know that I had stood up for a principle and at least I would know in 20 years time that I had not been a party to the destruction of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had a university education. However, I know a fact when I see one. What has been stated by Senator Macklin is not a fact for two reasons. Firstly, he said that my major and essential point related to layabouts. I made that comment as an aside. His second point was that in any event he had been advised by the Government that it would be administratively impossible to separate the genuine students from the others. I have just been to the Minister's advisers and sought their opinion. I have been informed that it is not administratively impossible and that quite frankly it is perfectly possible.

I do not know whether that is the reason that exercised the honourable senator against my proposition, which is based word for word on his wording of last night. Each word of his proposition can be applied to my proposition. It gives to the Parliament the power of scrutiny of this instrument. It is there for the asking. SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly under clause 6, with which we are dealing, the Minister may, by instrument in writing, do so-and-so. It lists certain exemptions. But the Minister does not have to make an instrument to do anything. He can, if he wants to. For example, he may, by instrument in writing signed by him, deal with fees in relation to persons who are doing a third degree and exclude persons who are doing higher degrees. He can do that. Quite frankly, as I said, it would be up to us to indicate before he made the instrument that we would not buy that but would buy something else. If the Senate wanted to do that by positive resolution, that is okay. Then the public could see, not by a back door method, what we were doing about this important issue. I again say that it is most extraordinary that, to quote Senator Macklin, the Democrats are prepared to go to the extent of a double dissolution on this particular matter when they have the opportunity of both worlds here for the asking.
