TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other important aspect of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981 to which I think the Committee's attention should be drawn. It is best described by the Minister's words in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides funding consistent with the decisions taken by the Government for the rationalisation and consolidation of resources in higher education.

That passage goes on to deal with colleges of advanced education and leads into another passage in the second reading speech which announces a plan whereby funds for 1982 for a number of colleges of advanced education 'for which acceptable consolidation arrangements have not yet been received, have been included in the legislation in a national unallocated reserve'.

The Minister is saying that certain amalgamations of colleges and, in certain instances, of colleges and universities should take place. If they do not take place the normal funding for those colleges will not be available in the next year, 1982, and the moneys which would normally be appropriated to those colleges, or universities in particular cases, would be paid into what is called an unallocated reserve.

In a sense I think it is a fairly efficient means of doing business if one wants to bring about a quick result in relation to particular matters. I want to draw the Committee's attention to the consequences of that result and to the way in which, in a sense, it was arrived at. Of course, it was not arrived at by the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) in any educational context. It was arrived at by the Review of Commonwealth Functions in the context of an ideological exercise which had nothing specifically to do with education, educational functions, questions of access to education and educational aims. The Victorian Minister for Education, Mr Hunt, referred to the report as being unilateral, blunt, insensitive and ill-considered and disclosed no appreciation whatever of the problems involved for staff, students and institutions.

It is to those matters that I wish to refer briefly. If one looks at the razor gang exercise in which 30 colleges of advanced education were selected as a result of flicking through the Tertiary Education Commission's report, then one sees, in a sense, the ineptness of the exercise. One would have thought, for example, that in any comprehensive educational plan, as distinct from ideological stunt, dealing with rationalisation and amalgamation of colleges, a number of highly expensive single purpose colleges such as the Queensland Conservatorium of Music, the Orange agricultural college and the Victorian pharmacy college might have been considered. But if one looks at the role of the Tertiary Education Commission in relation to amalgamations of institutions one sees the sorts of guidelines which initially the TEC recommended. In its report for the 1982-84 triennium it made the following points: That teacher training numbers needed to be reduced; that the TEC was not prepared to allow proliferation of liberal arts courses to take up the slack; that the colleges needed assistance to diversify into business studies and technologies; and that where it could be shown to result in genuine economies and more viable institutions the TEC would support the integration of colleges. Finally, it recommended that flexible plans and options for colleges to amalgamate and diversify be investigated and completed by 1984. The TEC went on to recommend that colleges be given additional funds in the form of temporary development grants to tide them over the transition period.

That was the advice of an expert body which was given prior to the decision of the razor gang. It is advice which is calculated and planned to achieve amalgamations of colleges over effectively a three-year period. I must say on behalf of the Opposition that we have no objection to the amalgamation of a number of colleges, having regard to excess capacity particularly in the teaching profession. Indeed, Senator Carrick will remember that two or three years ago I discussed this issue with him when he was Minister for Education. We have no objection to the criteria and suggestions of the Tertiary Education Commission for amalgamation. It is quite clear that in a sense at least they are rational decisions based on a concern that student intakes should be directed more appropriately into areas of study which are of more relevance in the current economic climate and indeed to the future of this country; that a proliferation of unnecessary courses should not be encouraged in order to help colleges to survive in circumstances in which they should not survive; and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Based on educational grounds.

—Based on educational grounds. I am glad that we are in agreement on that point. All those things were recommended by the Tertiary Education Commission. I believe that at that stage those propositions of the TEC would have had the support of anybody seriously concerned about education and a national government approach to education. They certainly would have had the support of the Australian Labor Party. There is no doubt that there was a proliferation of colleges in the 1960s and early 1970s which in a sense with hindsight was undesirable. Of course, it has been recognised by educational authorities because a process merger and amalgamation has taken place, admittedly at a slow pace. The consequences of ignoring the recommendations of the TEC report and embarking on the exercise upon which the razor gang embarked are: A lot of turmoil and distress amongst colleges, the students and staff of colleges and, in some senses, universities; and a lot of concern about their future which would have been totally unnecessary if the advice of the TEC had been taken at an earlier stage. Of course that was not done; the so-called razor gang entered the field with the sorts of results that Mr Hunt, the Liberal Minister of Education in Victoria, described.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of colleges, of course, are still badly affected by the situation. The Institute of Early Childhood Development in Melbourne, which comes to mind, is a college which has performed a highly specialist and, I think, a very highly regarded role in Victoria. I am not saying that the Institute of Early Childhood Development should not be persuaded to go into some form of amalgamation with another college in Victoria. What I am saying is that an institution which has provided a unique service and has been very highly regarded in Victoria should not be steamrollered, in the way that it is by the effective arrangements in this legislation, consequent upon the razor gang's decision, to rush to a decision about amalgamation with some other college.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also very difficult to tell what it should amalgamate with.

—That is the difficulty. A variety of suggestions have been made about Hawthorn and Deakin University. I think it is necessary that such a college should go through a process of adjustment, but it should have time to do it. Very grave difficulties are being experienced by an institute such as that, and there is a lot of community concern that it should be forced into this situation. I do not know what the Minister's intentions are about the Institute of Early Childhood Development, amongst other institutions, at this stage. Certainly I know that I wrote to him three or four weeks ago about the matter and have had no answer to the specific questions I raised in that letter. That is a matter of concern. Of course, the Institute of Early Childhood Development is not the only one involved. Other institutions both in Victoria and elsewhere, are similarly concerned. There are cases where the Government in the State in which an institution is situated has indicated its opposition to the proposals which have been suggested by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The fact that the State opposes the proposition, when the Commonwealth pays for those colleges, does not necessarily mean that the program should not go ahead. It does mean that it should be considered in a rational way, in the way in which the Tertiary Education Commission first suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently, a Tertiary Education Commission report on progress on consolidation in advanced education was given to the Minister for Education on 4 July this year. It sets out the progress of some of the proposals. I think it is to the credit of a number of institutions concerned, and in part to the credit of the Commonwealth Government, that some of those proposals have already successfully gone ahead. In respect of those which have not, a very difficult situation has arisen, and it is one which should be appreciated and accommodated by the Government as soon as possible by an announcement of its intentions. The position, certainly as far as many of these colleges are concerned, is highly confused, and that is a cause of concern. In respect of that confusion, there is an apparent lack of communication, either between the State co-ordinating authority and the college or the state co-ordinating authority and the Commonwealth Government, which is highly undesirable in what should be a smooth operation. The entire suspicion one can have about this is that it is another example of rather ad hoc and hasty planning to which the Tertiary Education Commission has now become a party in the sense that it is the instrument of Government policy in relation to this matter. It is not a satisfactory planning exercise and it has an expedient and cosmetic nature about it which is, as I say, undesirable.

The only other matter I wish to mention is the sort of matter we ought to be debating in this place in discussing such legislation. I refer to the proliferation of teacher training institutions which took place and what the real demand for trained teachers is likely to be in the decades ahead. It is a matter which Senator Macklin, I think, touched on in an earlier part of this debate. I do no more than point to the difficulties which have been caused and hope that the Government, at least in relation to colleges such as the Institute of Early Childhood Development, Hawthorn, Frankston, and the Melbourne State colleges, being institutions which are in my State, will have a little more patience and care, if it is the Government's will that they do amalgamate, at least in seeing that the amalgamations are accommodated in a more planned and steady way than is possible under the proposals currently before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the passage at this stage of clause 3 of the Non-Government Schools (Loans Guarantee) Amendment Bill. The purpose of the Bill is twofold. It extends the eligibility of guarantees for Commonwealth loans to proposed, as well as existing, non-government schools in the States and, as well, enables such guarantees to cover interest payments. These new provisions are in addition to present provisions which relate to the repayment of principal moneys obtained to finance approved building projects at non-government schools. The Opposition does not oppose the second of the new provisions. However, at this stage it does oppose the extension of the scheme to proposed or new schools. I must make it clear that our opposition will not affect established school systems such as parish systems because it is not a requirement that their loans be guaranteed by the Commonwealth Government. The non-passage of this clause does not mean that new schools which lack sufficient community support would not go ahead. It does mean that their loans would not be guaranteed by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose the extension of Commonwealth loans to any new or proposed school because there is throughout the education community a great deal of disquiet amongst parents, teachers and educationists about the curriculum and nature of some new schools which have emerged recently. The registration procedures of State education departments should control the educational standards of schools which can obtain registration within their systems. However, at this stage that is not the case. In some States registration procedures merely relate to health standards and the provision of physical facilities. They do not address satisfactorily questions of curriculum, how the children are taught, the nature of the philosophy of the school and so forth. A great deal of concern exists in the education community about the proliferation of schools which have what one could kindly describe as an eccentric curriculum and teach values which many in the Australian community would regard as divisive and anti-democratic. The State governments are similarly concerned about the proliferation of these schools. At this stage State Education Ministers recognise that the current procedures for registration of the schools are inadequate. That recognition is demonstrated by the fact that they have set up a working party to examine those procedures. The Opposition believes that it is irresponsible of the Federal Government to encourage and facilitate new schools, many of which have curricula of questionable educational benefit, while such a review is taking place at a State level. When State procedures are revised and updated the Federal Opposition will be happy to reconsider its stance on this Bill. We are happy to see diversity in education. We are happy to see Commonwealth laws extended to non-government schools which have a valid educational curriculum and philosophy. However, until we can be assured by State education Ministers as a result of their review, that this is the case with all the schools that gain registration we will oppose clause 3, which extends loan guarantees to new and proposed non-government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission considers the loans guarantee scheme to be not a separate program but rather an integral part of the overall building and equipment program for non-government schools. Loan guarantees are available to assist those schools that need to complement a capital grant with repayable loan moneys. Also, the scheme provides a means by which some support can be given to a proposed school development which, though worthwhile, may not have sufficiently high educational and financial need (relative to other applications) to attract a capital grant within the very limited funds available. Accordingly, the same procedures apply for consideration of applications by Planning and Finance Committees and the Commission, regardless of whether a project is ultimately recommended for either a grant or a loan guarantee.

With regard to new school developments, Planning and Finance Committees are required to examine proposals very carefully. In addition to the normal assessment of education and financial need, the criteria of public demand, existing availability of student places, seriousness of purpose of sponsors and viability apply to new school proposals. Planning and Finance Committees must be provided with convincing evidence to support the projected enrolments being claimed by the proponents of a new school and they are required to consider-as far as can be estimated-the effects on enrolment structures at existing schools (including government schools). The probability of a new school being registered by the State is also fundamental to the Commission's consideration of a capital proposal.

The Schools Commission planning and finance committees were set up by the Whitlam Government as the key recommending bodies with regard to new schools. Clearly, what is now being said by the Labor Party is that it is rejecting the very mechanism that it has supported over the years. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise tonight the matter of the closure of the Box Hill Community Youth Support Scheme group. It is a matter that has caused great consternation to people in that area. Several members of parliament have received complaints about this rather high-handed action. I think it is ludicrous that the Box Hill CYSS group has been suspended and is facing termination when the Government intends to issue new guidelines in February. There is no doubt that the Box Hill CYSS group has been one of the successes in Victoria, especially in the metropolitan area. The operation in that suburb is known as 'Shopback'. In 1981, 156 people were enrolled there, which is a far greater number than that of many other CYSS groups in Melbourne. The average monthly participation in that group is 45 people. The average daily attendance is 25 people. The number of participants who so far have gained jobs in 1981 is 47. At least 16 people have been involved in the work experience program that has been instituted and about 22 are involved in community service. These figures compare very favourably with many metropolitan CYSS groups.

SPEECH.PARA: The Box Hill and Nunawading area has many special problems; namely, there is a lot of fighting amongst street gangs, there is a very high proportion of unmarried mothers and there are great problems in accommodating homeless youth. The Shopback in Box Hill has tackled all these problems head on. It has reduced the amount of gang warfare in that area. It has run education courses using eight sessional teachers on a one-to-one basis. It has instituted work experience programs and sex education courses. It has had very close links with the job centre in that area. It has managed to provide dental and medical services to the participants of the scheme. It has even published its own newspaper which is called 'Street Talk'.

The success of this dynamic CYSS group is based on very active and experienced project officers who have been given complete support by a very involved committee. Too often one finds in CYSS groups that the project officers are too young to be able to control and develop programs. In the case of Box Hill, there were very experienced people. They have had a wide range of experience in social welfare work. Nearly all of the members of the Box Hill CYSS committee have been active in social welfare in the Box Hill-Nunawading area. Why then, one might ask, has the Box Hill CYSS group been suspended? I believe it has been subjected to a campaign of smear and innuendo and that the State CYSS committee's decision to suspend it was based on misunderstanding and false information.

I am not asserting that the Box Hill CYSS group has had no problems in the past. The main criterion by which it should be judged, however, is how effective it has been in the community. I intend to examine the background of the Box Hill CYSS suspension. I hope that the Government might be able to resolve the matter within the next few weeks. Throughout the whole of 1981 the committee repeatedly asked for a joint meeting with the State CYSS committee which controls all the CYSS groups in Victoria. The State committee refused, but it did send a field officer out to the Box Hill area on two occasions. At the last meeting the field officer attended a discussion about the future guidelines in response to a request from the new Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Neil Brown. The committee pointed out that education was a key to employability. The field officer insisted that education was outside the guidelines and said that the State committee would not give Shopback more than $30 a week for educational or sessional teachers. The organisation received $60 a week in 1980.

On 2 October the chairman of Box Hill CYSS was notified by Mr Graham Harris that the State committee on 1 October suspended Shopback from 9 October and was recommending termination to the Minister. When asked for reasons the executive officer of CYSS, Mr Mike Sullivan, said that they were being sent. On Wednesday, 7 October, a letter was received saying that Shopback was suspended due to critical reports being received. When asked what the appeal procedure was, the executive officer told the chairman that there was no appeal procedure but that the Committee could write to the Minister and the State committee. At 4.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 7 October, Mr Graham Harris, who had refused to tell individual members the reasons for the suspension, agreed to disclose these to the whole committee. He said, having been approached by the State committee one week before its meeting on 1 October, that he wrote saying that he thought the project was no longer viable. When pushed for reasons he cited bad Press, police problems and difficulties with a Box Hill Council youth worker.

All of these matters had been discussed at length at the committee meetings at which Mr Harris had been present, had offered advice and had contributed to the discussion and decisions made. The background to the State committee's decision appears to be that the Nunawading North neighbourhood centre from where the original people started off the CYSS group, had an undesirable influence on the committee. Yet only the chairman, who does not have a vote, and two other members of that committee come from the Nunawading neighbourhood centre. The chairman of the CYSS group is a technical and further education teacher at the Box Hill college. That college, through the Principal, Geoff Fountain, has supported the work of the neighbourhood centre because Mr Fountain knows of the value of its work with unemployed people.

I am disappointed to think that the major report on this group has come from a fairly young and inexperienced public servant when compared with the experience in social welfare of people who are involved on the ground. He seems to be, I think, biased against the neighbourhood centre. This person has solicited critical comments from two or three members of the Box Hill CYSS committee and has used these to show that the project was in serious trouble. When confronted by the Box Hill CYSS chairman, Bruce Stewart, it became apparent that the State committee had been seriously misinformed. At no time was any criticism checked with the chairman of the Shopback committee. Every endeavour seems to have been made to bypass him and the whole committee. No evaluation of the aims, methods and results of the project was carried out. Mr Harris was asked to form a new committee and start a new project before the current committee was even informed of its suspension.

The State committee will of course not change its decision and the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs is naturally loth to go against the decision of the State committee on the basis that the committee had threatened to resign if he overrode its decision. I must say at this point that the Minister, Mr Brown, has been sympathetic in this matter but of course takes his advice from the State committee, whether the decision was made on good or bad information.

What were the reasons used by the State committee? The main one was problems with the police. On 24 June the chairman of Shopback wrote to the Minister of Police, the Chief Commissioner of Police and the District Superintendent of Police asking for an urgent meeting to discuss lines of co-operation between police and the Shopback staff. The letter made an official complaint, carefully documented, concerning the behaviour of police who entered the participants door, ignored the project officers and teachers present and started questioning participants. Be it a school or any other organisation, it is normal when police officers enter premises for them to go through the normal and proper channels of seeing the people in charge first. The police concerned were members of the Criminal Investigation Bureau from Box Hill who had arrested some of the ex-members of Shopback. The point at issue was the professional responsibility of adults at Shopback. Shopback received adverse publicity when a local newspaper reported a court hearing in which it was alleged that members of Shopback had been drinking on the premises of Shopback and then had stolen a car. Most of this was erroneous reporting. The facts are that the drinking occurred in a carpark adjacent to Shopback. There is a strong directive that no drinking shall take place on Shopback premises and certainly none took place on that occasion.

Several reasons have been given for the suspension of Shopback. The suspension letter quoted serious criticism from Mr Graeme Harris, the Commonwealth Employment Service and the police and adverse Press publicity that followed some of these criticisms. Only Mr Harris admitted to writing anything, and that was that the project was simply no longer viable. The manager of the CES and the police have denied making any criticism to the State committee. On 19 October some of the Shopback committee members had a cordial and fruitful discussion with Superintendent Plant, who agreed to reissue instructions that the police were to go to the office door and ask for the project officer. The committee instructed the project officers to co-operate with the police and to follow the instructions. So the problem with the police has been solved, but CYSS is still suspended. The State committee further told the chairman of Box Hill CYSS that Shopback did not have enough local support. The chairman detailed practical support from 95 groups and individuals in the Box Hill area. I seek leave to have a document showing this incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention to a disgraceful situation which has come about in the town of Northhampton, north of Geraldton in Western Australia. I particularly wish to draw this situation to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, who also represents the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) in this chamber, as this situation concerns the irresponsible behaviour of a member of the medical profession towards his Aboriginal patients. Northampton is a small town about 50 kilometres north of Geraldton. It has only one doctor, Dr R. Hutchinson. The Aboriginal population in Northampton is about 75 and, like the majority of Aboriginal people in this country, many of them live in underprivileged circumstances and on low incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an unfortunate but well recognised fact that Aboriginal people throughout Australia do not enjoy the relatively good health enjoyed in general by the non-Aboriginal population, and the Aboriginal people of Northampton are no exception. When they are ill the Aboriginal people of Northampton have little choice but to go to Dr Hutchinson, the sole doctor in the town. Their only alternative is at Geraldton, some 50 kilometres south, where there is an Aboriginal medical service and a hospital. However, expense and difficulties of transporting sick people the 50 kilometres to Geraldton have prevented many Northampton Aboriginals from utilising this alternative.

Before the 1 September changes to the health care system, it was the practice of Dr Hutchinson to bill patients directly and, in the case of his Aboriginal patients, not to use his discretion to declare patients disadvantaged and send their bills direct to Medibank for payment. I must point out that at this stage my information is that Dr Hutchinson has never refused to see a patient because he was in debt to him. However, over the last two years several Aboriginal families have built up considerable medical bills which they have been unable to pay. Six cases have come to my attention so far. They are: Colleen Drage and Maurice Newgie, who have five children aged between six months and six years; Horace and Laurel Drage, a middle-aged couple with no children; Fay and Clayton Drage, who have four children; Victor and Marjorie Mourambine, who have six children of their own and are fostering another child; Stewart Mongoo and Joan Drage, who have six children; and Maxine Drage and Dennis O'Dene, who have five children. In all six cases, the families are battling to meet financial commitments and to maintain a reasonable standard of living. In all cases the breadwinner of the family has at some stage during the last two years been out of work and in receipt of social security benefits. In one case the family is in arrears with a hire purchase company and is having difficulty in maintaining rental payments on the family home.

Most of these families are in arrears with their doctor's bills to the extent of several hundred dollars, and the doctor involved, Dr Hutchinson, has proceeded with legal action to recover his money. Therefore these Aboriginal families now have to cope with visits from debt collection agencies, summonses, and appearances in court. These families are being pursued by the law only because they have committed the crimes of being poor, being sick and being black. Between them they support 27 children and by the look of their medical accounts, which I am prepared to table if the Minister wishes, they do not enjoy a high standard of general health. Two of the men involved, Mr Clayton Drage and Mr Victor Mourambine, are attempting to repay their medical debts in instalments from their meagre incomes. When situations such as these come to my attention, I cannot help but feel outraged that Aboriginal families should be put through such hardships unnecessarily. These people, under the Government policy operating at the time, were entitled to 'disadvantaged person' status and thus to free medical care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that before 1 September?
—It was before 1 September.
—How were they entitled to disadvantaged status?

—Because they were on unemployment benefits. Their income levels, according to the Government's criteria at the time, entitled them to disadvantage benefits, but the doctor refused, for his own reasons, to accord them such status and consequently billed them. They have been denied their entitlement under previous Government policy to free medical care and now face legal proceedings and possibly gaol. I consider that this situation is a stinging indictment of the health care policy of the Government and its effectiveness in looking after Aboriginal people. I say that because such a situation would not arise if we had a universal health care system such as the Medibank scheme which was in force under the Labor Government. While the current Government insists on running down public health services and forcing people to rely on the private sector, such situations will continue to arise. I do not think the 1 September changes to the health care system will alter the situation for a large number of Aboriginal people who, for reasons that I am sure will be well known to the Minister, will not apply for a disadvantage health card.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this matter this evening because I would like the Minister to indicate to the Senate what he is prepared to do to assist the six families whose positions I have outlined. In the majority of cases the medical items involved in the outstanding bills are not items which are scheduled at over $20 and which, therefore, would have been payable by Medibank for any uninsured person. Will the Minister continue to allow these six Aboriginal families to suffer the extra burden of trying to pay outstanding medical bills for which they should never have been liable in the first place? Will he allow them to go through the insecurity and the anxiety of legal proceedings and possibly imprisonment for these outstanding bills or will he take some action to have the cost of these bills met by the relevant Commonwealth authority? These are the questions I put to the Minister this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two senators have contributed to the adjournment debate tonight. Senator Robert Ray has set out a problem in relation to the Box Hill Community Youth Support Scheme project. As I listened, I think he provided considerable detail about the problems facing the project. I understand that what he wants me to do is to draw the problem to the attention of the Minister and to seek the Minister's reconsideration of the decisions which have been taken. I will undertake so to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan has raised, I think it is fair to say, on an ex parte basis at this stage a problem in a town in Western Australia and asked what I intend to do about it. I suppose that as a first step I had better do what anyone would want to do, that is, seek from the doctor his account of what has happened and his side of the story and try to put together, from what Senator Ryan has said and from what the doctor may say, a composite picture of what has gone on. It might be appropriate to send to the doctor a copy of the Hansard report, to seek his comments urgently and then to make my decision.

My understanding is that the new arrangements for disadvantaged persons no longer depend upon any assessment by individual medical practitioners. Irrespective of whether people will or will not apply, there is now a capacity for people to be classified on the basis of their financial need-to say to the doctor that they are disadvantaged people and they have been so classified. Of course, to that extent they are better off now than they were before. They can now claim that kind of classification. As I say, I am not prepared to comment on an ex parte basis, but I hope that all medical practitioners will seek to offer treatment where it is needed, especially when they are the sole practitioners in a town; that they will recognise the special needs of Aboriginal people for health care; that they will recognise the special problems facing Aboriginal people; and that they would approach matters such as the ones outlined by Senator Ryan in a compassionate and reasonable way. It is for that reason that I want to know from the doctor himself whether there is another side to the story. If I obtain that information, I will pass it on to the honourable senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981, (Hansard, page 498) Senator Button asked me a question without notice concerning the leaking of the 1980-81 Budget. In the course of responding to the honourable senator I undertook to seek some further information and pass it to him.

ANSWER.PARA: I have now consulted with the Treasurer and with the Attorney-General and we are of the view that it would not be appropriate for an Australian Federal Police report on unauthorised disclosure of information from the 1980 Budget to be tabled or otherwise published. A police report on such matters is in no way analogous to the judgment or report of a judicial officer. A police report is made for the purpose of prosecution or administrative action in relation to an offence investigated, and not for the purpose of informing the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981, (Hansard, page 1534) Senator Haines asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Wireless Telegraphy Regulations specify fees payable for radiocommunications licences. State Emergency Services (SES) in common with most other users are required to pay those fees. As part of its 'user pays' philosophy, the Government has decided that radio frequency management will be completely self-supporting financially, that is, those who use radiocommunication services must pay for them directly rather than the general taxpayer subsidising functions of Government. This means that any concession in fees to radiocommunication users like the SES must be paid for by some other radiocommunication user. Consequently the Government considers that the SES and other like services should seek sufficient funding to pay for licence fees just as it does for other goods and services.
